headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Q2 2010 Molex Incorporated earnings conference call. My name is Bobby and I will be your moderator for today. At this time all participants are in listen-only mode and later we will conduct a question-and
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Q2 2010 Molex Incorporated earnings conference call. My name is Bobby and I will be your moderator for today. At this time all participants are in listen-only mode and later we will conduct a question-and-answer session. (Operator instructions)
I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today Mr. Steve Martens, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please proceed.

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bobby. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for taking time for joining us today. I am joined on the call by Martin Slark, our Chief Executive Officer, Dave Johnson, our Chief Financial Officer and Liam McCarthy, our Chief Operating Officer.
componenttext:
Thank you, Bobby. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for taking time for joining us today. I am joined on the call by Martin Slark, our Chief Executive Officer, Dave Johnson, our Chief Financial Officer and Liam McCarthy, our Chief Operating Officer. Please note that this call is being recorded and will be available for replay by accessing the Investor Relations section of our website. Presentation materials are also available on the website. As usual we would like to limit this call to one hour. When we get to Q&A, we ask for one question per participant and one follow-up question. Thanks.
Before we turn our attention to the quarterly results, let's review our Safe Harbor Statements on slide one and two of the presentation materials. During the course of this presentation, we will be providing forward-looking information and referring to non-GAAP measures. Please read carefully the forward-looking statements section of our press release and Form 10-K for an understanding of the risk and uncertainties associated with forward-looking information and the reconciliation of non-GAAP measures to GAAP. For your convenience, we have included these materials in our presentation. They are also available from our website, www.molex.com in the investors section.
And now, Martin will review order and revenue results for the quarter.

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve, and welcome everyone to the second quarter of fiscal year '10 earnings release conference call. If you turn now to page three, this chart demonstrates our order trends over the past several quarters. Orders grew sequentially 7% in the De
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve, and welcome everyone to the second quarter of fiscal year '10 earnings release conference call. If you turn now to page three, this chart demonstrates our order trends over the past several quarters. Orders grew sequentially 7% in the December quarter to 778 million. This represents our third consecutive quarter of significant growth and we are now 38% about the order rate experienced in December 2008 quarter.
Looking back at our guidance provided in the last call, we stated the normal seasonal trend would generally have ordered slowing in late November or certainly early December. This is not the case this year and in fact, orders increased sequentially in November and then surprisingly they were up again sequentially in December. The strength of these bookings will give us momentum for the second half of our fiscal year. Needless to say, we are quite pleased with the pace and breadth of the recovery in our overall business which we think reflect stronger end-market demand, good new-product strength, continuing success with our focus (inaudible) program particularly in Asia.
It is worth noting that our bookings are still 13% below the peak that we achieved in Q3 of fiscal year '08 and channeling materials are in good shape. Looking at our bookings for the last quarter, we are therefore cautiously optimistic about the prospects of the calendar year 2010.
If you turn now to page four, we show our orders by industry. Hear you can see that the consumer electronics industry showed a lower than normal seasonality and was only down 3% from the September quarter. That reduction for that quarter is very low. This market however was still up 38% year-over-year. Consumer Electronics sold well during the Christmas season particularly in Asia. And having just spent a week in Japan, we don't see any evidence of excess inventory that needs to be burned off at this time.
Going forward, we are encouraged by the not large number of new products recently introduced to the Consumer Electronics show which was certainly not the case a year ago and as well as expectations that Chinese New Year and the World Cup will drive strong demands to TVs this year.
LCD TVs are expected to be up 16% in 2010 to 170 million units including 41 million LED backlit TVs and approximately 1 million 3D TVs. These new TV models have higher connector content which is a positive for Molex. The automotive markets continue to improve steadily from relatively low production levels a year ago. Orders were up 6% sequentially it up over 60% from what was a disastrous quarter the same quarter in 2008.
Automobile inventories remain low and selling rates have held up reasonably well even though government stimulus packages have been withdrawn. Third-party projections suggest that modest unit growth will continue in this sector through 2010. With improving production rates in Asia and the U.S. and decline in Western Europe.
In addition the continue to see strong demand for products similar to those sold in consumer electronics markets to support new functionality such as rear-view cameras, navigation systems, HD and satellite radios and (inaudible) network opportunities is providing the possibilities for Molex to sell not just the connector but value added assembly into this market.
We are seeing strong demand for notebooks service storage and networking products in the data market where orders were up a very strong 9% sequentially and 55% over prior year levels. This is largely due to the third enterprise spending as companies are beginning to replace aging hardware as well as the need for capacity increases due to video and other high-volume data downloads. We believe that the data market will continue to grow in 2010 as we are now receiving orders to delivery in the June quarter. Our major customers in this sector also seeing optimistic over the prospect of 2010.
The overall Telecom market was up 8% sequentially and 22% year-over-year. The infrastructure and smartphone sector was the strongest. Middle rate [ph] cell phone volumes were down as well as the cell phone market in Japan. We have seen a large number of new product design wins in both their infrastructure and smartphone sector. Wins in the smartphones sector will continue to help out sales through Q4 this fiscal year and into Q1 of next fiscal year.
Our industrial business improved significantly again this quarter with a 20% sequential and 26% year-over-year increase. This market tends to track with GDP growth and we expect the pace of recovery to accelerate as GDP growth rates increase and eventually in Europe.
We are very pleased to see significant growth coming out of the Woodhead acquisition with good progress particularly in the manufacture automation and alternative energy markets. Our share in the medical and military markets are still quite small, but we had very good projects under way in both markets which resulted in very significant year-over-year and sequential booking growth rates.
If you now turn to page five, we will look at our order trends by channel and by geography. On a channel basis distribution show the most significant increase in the September quarter. Our point of sale and point of purchase data which we contract through our SAP system are growing in the same rate. So we have not seen any evidence so far of the distribution partners building up inventory of Molex products.
EMS orders increased 8% in the September quarter, the second straight quarter with significant sequential improvement. OEMs now seem to be moving more business to their EMS partners versus holding it in house, as in demand continues to improve.
On a geographic basis, Asia-Pacific North which is Japan and Korea for us was down sequentially due to seasonal nature of the consumer electronics business so that is downturn is very consistent with the data I gave you for consumer market. All other regions are up quite strongly from the September quarter as well as from last year as the recovery strengthens in virtually every major economy.
We continued to benefit from the rapid recovery in Asia and our large presence there. In the long run, we believe our participation in this region close to 60% of sales and our broad-based strength across all key market segments will translate into significant growth opportunities as well as the penetration of electronic devices into household in emerging Asian countries which is continuing and as we mentioned before, this refresh (inaudible) equipment particularly across the Asian economies.
Turn now to page six, we will look at our revenue trend. We reported an increase of 8% in revenue from the September quarter and an increase of 9% from a year ago. We've now reported three consecutive quarters of significant growth from our low point in the March 2009 quarter. Even with this rapid recovery, we are still 16% below the revenue level realized in the 2008 June quarter. So we still have quite a room to grow and a growing backlog to support that growth.
If you turn now to page seven, which charts our changes in revenue by industry. You are basically looking at the same trends that drove orders. But, obviously with some time legs which vary by industry. If you look at the automotive and data market, they increase the most on a sequential basis due to higher production builds schedule by automotive OEMs and higher enterprise spending. Telecom and industrial each increase 6% sequentially due to infrastructure spending and a modest recovery in the manufacturing automation market. As expected, the consumer market which is flat and a sequential basis due to seasonality.
We are optimistic looking ahead to the March quarter. The order rate was quite strong through December quarter and our backlog has increased. Normally, we would anticipate a 3 to 5% reduction in the coming quarter. However, given the strong order backlog, we are providing revenue guidance of 715 to 735 million for the March quarter, the midpoint of this range is down 0.6% which is obviously lower than normal seasonal reduction.
That's the summary of the revenue and order data and Dave Johnson will now give you more information on our financial results.

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Martin. Turn to page eight please. Page right is our GAAP P&L statement. As Martin said revenue has increase for the third consecutive quarter sequentially and the increased in this current quarter is 8.2% in dollars and 5.5% in the local curre
componenttext:
Thank you, Martin. Turn to page eight please. Page right is our GAAP P&L statement. As Martin said revenue has increase for the third consecutive quarter sequentially and the increased in this current quarter is 8.2% in dollars and 5.5% in the local currency. Gross margin of 29.1% reflects primarily the higher revenue in the quarter. SG&A of $150.1 million increased $4.5 million due to the reinstatement of salaries and benefits and currency exchange, but still came in at the very low end of our guidance range.
Restructuring was $25.6 million, but we will discuss that's a bit more in the next slide. Interest expense and other expense are not unusual, but please, note that we did not get the benefit of exchange gains in the current quarter that helped the September quarter and last year's December quarter quite significantly.
The effective tax rate on a GAAP basis for the quarter was 44.6%. As you will note, our GAAP tax rate has been quite variable due to restructuring and systematic review of tax matters over the last year. The main driver for the higher tax rate in the current quarter was the decision we made to repeat earnings from overseas to support the completion of our restructuring activities.
On a non-GAAP basis, the effective tax rate was 31.4% and we would anticipate that the effective tax rate on a non-GAAP basis going forward would be approximately 30% for the final two quarters of our fiscal year.
And finally, on 174.6 million shares outstanding our GAAP EPS for the quarter was $0.11.
Now turn to page nine, where we detail our GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation adjustments. Beginning with GAAP pre-tax income of $34.8 million and EPS of $0.11, we add back the pre-tax restructuring charge of $25.6 million or $0.13 to arrive at our non-GAAP EPS results of $0.24. The pre-tax restructuring charge was about $7 million higher than our guidance related primarily to the additional non-cash impairment for real estate that we will discuss in more detail when we review restructuring program.
The after-tax restructuring charge of $22.1 million includes a $3 million tax expense for the repatriation of earnings in connection with the restructuring program as I mentioned in our end of the discussion of our GAAP tax rate. As compared to our guidance range of $0.18 to $0.22, we are very pleased to achieve the $0.24 non-GAAP EPS for the quarter.
The chart on page ten details our balance sheet metrics. There were no significant changes to our long-term debt arrangements during the quarter though the absolute amount declined by just over $30 million as we have left outstanding on our revolving credit facility at the end of December. More importantly, net cash of $207 million did not change appreciably from the September quarter. Accounts receivable and inventory continue to be in good control and well below the prior year levels. Accounts receivable days increased one day sequentially to 76 days and inventories decreased one day to 74 days.
Capital expenditure, R&D and cash flow from operations are all very consistent with the sequential quarter. With a significant ramping of demand, we have released additional capital expenditure authorizations for new product tooling that may cause our capital spending to increase in the March quarter. We have been on track with our goal of CapEx at 6.5% of revenue for the first two quarters, but we may see this increased temporarily in the third quarter, but certainly for the right reasons.
The gross margin trend is shown on page 11. Our gross margin of 29.1% is 70 basis points higher than Q1 and 270 basis points higher than the prior year. In fact, the quarter gross margin on revenue of $729 million is approaching the gross margin for Q1 of last year when revenue was $110 million higher. We think however, the gross margin should have been even better than it was. At this stage in the restructuring process, we are experiencing operational challenges related to the production tranfers that are impacting product shipments and also resulting in higher freight and other transition costs. The good news is that these are temporary impacts that will naturally reverse as the transfers are completed.
We talked during the last call about increasing commodity and foreign-exchange transaction cost, we did recognize higher costs in these areas, but they were - we were able to offset these costs with lower price erosion and operational improvements. As predicted last quarter, we did not realize much sequential cost reductions due to the restructuring program but increased cost savings are expected for the next quarter. Therefore, looking forward, we would expect gross margins to continue to trend positively for the down for the year.
Page 12 chart, our SG&A. Please note that we are back to more normal revenue trends we have reintroduced SG&A percentages below the bars on the chart. SG&A for the quarter was $150.1 million compared with our guidance of 150 to $151 million. SG&A increased sequentially by $4.5 million due to $3 million for the reinstatement of salaries and benefits and $2.5 million to simply foreign currencies translation. The weakness of the U.S. dollar between Q1 and Q2 results in all P&L items including SG&A to be inflated. This of course doesn't impact the SG& A percentage but does impact the absolute dollar value. In fact, I think it is important to mention at this point that if the dollar stays where it is today, this will naturally impact our long-term target model. The percentages don't change, but the revenue levels at which we can achieve these percentages will increase due to exchange. The Q2 revenue is about 5% higher at Q2 exchange rates that it would have been at the budget exchange rates used to develop our long-term model.
Therefore, if rates remain where they are, the revenue level at which we plan to achieve our target model of 32% gross margin, 18% SG&A and 14% operating margin has increased from $800 million to $840 million. Remember that our target model is applicable only after all in restructuring savings are recognized so this would mean about a year from now or December 2010 quarter.
Please turn now to our restructuring update on page 13. We are increasingly confident and pleased that we will be 100% complete with our three-year restructuring project by the end of June. By that time, we will have realized 83% of our restructuring savings with the balance of 17% or $34 million to be realized in fiscal year 2011.
As of today, we have closed 13 plants with just one to go. In addition, we have closed or consolidated numerous offices and distribution centers and thicken multiple reductions in force as we have discussed in the past.
Compared to our last reports, we have increased our estimate of the total project cost from $280 to $300 million, so an increase of 20 million. This increase consist of $10 million of non-cash impairment adjustments to properties sold or for sale to reflect the continuing weakness in the real-estate market and $10 million for cash reduction actions that have been initiated as we approach the completion of our program. These additional actions that we have initiated, we expect about $5 million of additional savings. And we have adjusted the chart to reflect the increase in total savings to $205 million.
We continue to believe that the return on this program is exceptional. Now, $205 million of annual savings on $300 million in charges. For use of quantifying the near-term impact, the last line on the chart shows the sequential savings, as expected we have just $1 million of sequential savings in Q2, but anticipates sequential savings of $3 million in Q3 and another $6 million now in Q4. And the sequential savings needed to complete the chart for fiscal year 2011 would be just over $2 million of sequential savings in the September 2011 quarter - I'm sorry, 2010 quarter.
And finally, on page 14, is our forward guidance. Based on the strong bookings that we have experience in the quarter and for through our release today, we expect to mitigate the usual seasonal decline in revenue to a certain extent and therefore believe that revenue for the March quarter will be in the range of 715 to $735 million.
We expect a $10 million of pretax restructuring charge or $0.4 per share, resulting in Non-GAAP earnings per share on the range of 22 to $0.26 per share. That in fact concludes our remarks and we would not be happy to answer any questions you may have.

componenttext: I don't think, Steve we can quantify in terms of the exact dollars, but one of the things we had planned was the going into December, we would see a slowdown in both bookings and shipments. That in fact business remained very strong through the end of the year and so, obviously operational impacts have been slow down some of those tools sized firms and the impact they had on our lead, ship product at the door. And the comment we made, we think that revenues could have been slightly higher. We certainly think that the margins would have been better, had we been able to complete absolutely but to give an example, if you just look at operations in Japan, I'm closing down to two facilities there required us to move over a thousand fold. The good news is that it's all gone but it was a huge task.

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: We don't break out, Steve. I mean, the data, given the call, the cell phone market. But if you actually looked at mobile devices, perhaps in total, sequentially they were up about 4%. With a little lower than we would have anticipated and when we broke th
componenttext:
We don't break out, Steve. I mean, the data, given the call, the cell phone market. But if you actually looked at mobile devices, perhaps in total, sequentially they were up about 4%. With a little lower than we would have anticipated and when we broke that down, we are seeing tremendous revenue pick up throughout over the year in the smartphone market from all the players that you already know. Adapting affecting seems to be the sale of mid-range phones across the world and I think you know who the strong players are in that segment. In fact in the unit sells and the other issue is really some saturation in the cell phone market and taking place like China.
So, I think what happened is the unit sells, I think when the data comes out that industry, will end up being lower than then anticipated in the mid-range and may well be some increase in the real low end there. But the revenue probably held up if you look at the segment overall, that will probably benefit certain players because of the smartphones segment.

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jim Suva from Citi. Please proceed.

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, gentlemen. A quick question, it's pretty understandable that your goal for 800 million gets shift a little bit due to the foreign exchange factors that are going on with the global foreign exchange currencies. Can you comment, does th
componenttext: Thank you very much, gentlemen. A quick question, it's pretty understandable that your goal for 800 million gets shift a little bit due to the foreign exchange factors that are going on with the global foreign exchange currencies. Can you comment, does that include kind of what's going on also with the raw materials and can you remind us about how much of your raw materials are hedging and I believe they roll-off in June and does that 840 million goal of quarterly, does it hold with the current raw material pricing environment? Thank you.

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Jim, sure. This is Dave. The entry is that, the (inaudible) we made in terms of model is purely for translation and as we said there was about 5% and actually a 5.1% impact on revenue now versus the budget rate. So that's a separate thing. My view is
componenttext:
Yes. Jim, sure. This is Dave. The entry is that, the (inaudible) we made in terms of model is purely for translation and as we said there was about 5% and actually a 5.1% impact on revenue now versus the budget rate. So that's a separate thing. My view is that we still are on track to achieve that and are committed to doing so but I will answer your question also specifically about the commodities.
We have hedged about 25% of our copper spend this year and about half of our goals spend. Those hedges, to remind you, our copper was hedged at $2. So, now today it's roughly at 3.30 and so obviously we are 26:05 the money on the copper hedge and the gold we hedged at $927 per troy ounce. And today gold is at thousand 98. We're putting the money on both of those hedges. It is reducing the impact each quarter. Your question then to what happens when the hedges come to an end, we have gone through and look at our hedge benefit and see what the impact is. Come July, August, September, the hedges were all put in place at different times so it does not happen all at once, but in the first quarter, the sequential impact of the hedges just coming off completely assuming that the commodities stay where they are at today, is less than $1 million in the first quarter.
Then sequentially into the second quarter, it's another about 1.5 million dollars. So roughly in total $2.5 million, so it comes in two different segments and I believe that, that is certainly manageable within our business for and to achieve our models.

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Jim, this is Martin. One other comment I think when you are trying to look at the margin impact that we found interesting over the last quarter. Is that as raw material costs continued to go up and I'm sure you have seen, one of the things that we have se
componenttext: Jim, this is Martin. One other comment I think when you are trying to look at the margin impact that we found interesting over the last quarter. Is that as raw material costs continued to go up and I'm sure you have seen, one of the things that we have seen going the other direction is the moderation in the level of price erosion. So that has helped us and I think with the strong demand right now and with rising raw material costs, we think we'll see that trend continues. So when we model that forward, we have to look at rising raw material costs such as the price erosion picture and price erosion continues to moderate, which we think it will with the strong demand right now. That is clearly an offset to some degree.

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Great, Thank you. And as a quick follow-up, can you comment on, we have not been in normal situation for demand for quite some time. Can you kind of remind us that what normal seasonality is now with your business, now that you have fully integrated what
componenttext: Great, Thank you. And as a quick follow-up, can you comment on, we have not been in normal situation for demand for quite some time. Can you kind of remind us that what normal seasonality is now with your business, now that you have fully integrated what had and what we accept for normal trend for calendar Q2 in June quarter and the rest of the year in a normal state of the environment?

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Great question, Jim. We have not been in a normal environment for so long. And I think as we said the normal seasonality for Q3 for the January to March quarter, would be down 3% to 5%. We don't think given the current rate of demand we will going to see
componenttext: Great question, Jim. We have not been in a normal environment for so long. And I think as we said the normal seasonality for Q3 for the January to March quarter, would be down 3% to 5%. We don't think given the current rate of demand we will going to see that. Normal seasonality in Q4, I honestly don't know what that will be for Q4 to be up over Q3. And I think probably in the order of 5% or so. But it's hard to, to tell what's going in at this point in time. So, we'll certainly have clearer picture as we get to March.

componenttext: Thank you and congratulations.

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks. Martin, just a follow up on Jim's question about seasonality and obviously difficult to tell what June is going to look like, but we have had three very strong quarters, some of that has been as have you stated in the past due to inventory refresh
componenttext: Thanks. Martin, just a follow up on Jim's question about seasonality and obviously difficult to tell what June is going to look like, but we have had three very strong quarters, some of that has been as have you stated in the past due to inventory refresh or restocking if you will. You get a sense that, that's playing out and particularly as the distributors get to where they need and their customers which tend to like the bigger OEM customers that they sort of get to the levels in line with your demand. Do you think we might see a mini correction if you will or maybe a step down as customers basically just try to deal with what they've got in terms of inventories?

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: It is a great question. I think a lot of people ask the same questions, about the stock market in terms of we have seen such a positive run off. Where does that go? I guess my own view is this, now we're going to see where this is right or not. Is that an
componenttext:
It is a great question. I think a lot of people ask the same questions, about the stock market in terms of we have seen such a positive run off. Where does that go? I guess my own view is this, now we're going to see where this is right or not. Is that and that is why have I like that question. We get every month, we get POSDATA from our distributors and one of the things I was concerned about, with distribution being the strongest channel last quarter, was they building inventory and so that would slow down in this quarter. But, the POSDATA is as strong as the PopData for us, so that is certainly not the case.
And I think as we mentioned, our bookings are still 15% below the peak that they were in the third quarter of '08. And when you look at the top 10 customer that are driving our business and one of the reason I was out in Asia last week was visiting some of those. They had a parity bullish view about fiscal year '10 and seemed to have good customer pipeline to drive that. All I can say you is at this point, I think we are going to see a slight slowdown in February for Chinese New Year, given the impact that had in Asia on our visit. At least the customers we have talked to seem to be pretty confident about things continuing beyond March. I don't think you're going to see the same sequential quarter-over-quarter growth that we have seen in the last three quarters. But I haven't seen any evidence of a correction other than the seasonal ones for the Chinese New Year.

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. That is helpful, Martin. And then just my follow-up in terms of your own capacity and adding some CapEx and adding some tooling. Looking at quarter or two ahead, what kind of revenue capacity will you have going into the next few quarters and will y
componenttext: Okay. That is helpful, Martin. And then just my follow-up in terms of your own capacity and adding some CapEx and adding some tooling. Looking at quarter or two ahead, what kind of revenue capacity will you have going into the next few quarters and will you be comfortable with that and will you have some variable cost there in case we do see things fall off in the quarter or two or you will be able to still maintain those margins?

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I think, the capacity we are riding today it is all product specific. And it is tied to specific customer program and we have as a result of our restructuring, we still have seven million square feet of manufacturing around the world which what we had bef
componenttext: I think, the capacity we are riding today it is all product specific. And it is tied to specific customer program and we have as a result of our restructuring, we still have seven million square feet of manufacturing around the world which what we had before the downturn, it just radically repositioned in terms of where it is. We have the same amount of molding and same capacities and we have obviously moved those tools around. So we don't have to add dollars for that and we think the products specific tools are targeted at customer programs, where they committed to offer those, so they are going to take place. It is the right kind of capacity to be added in terms of its targeted specific programs. Liam McCarthy is here with me and I have been going through the last week, so let's see if he wants to add to that.

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: We are winning a lot of new products. We got a combination of having specific capacity in terms of those which are built up to achieving our revenue target. That they've talked about earlier in terms of our models. And in terms, of course we've got some g
componenttext: We are winning a lot of new products. We got a combination of having specific capacity in terms of those which are built up to achieving our revenue target. That they've talked about earlier in terms of our models. And in terms, of course we've got some generic capacity which we are putting in place in the receiving plants for the transfers. Something like, quite a number of plane lines and a lot of transfer of molding machines, new molding machine. One thing that's really driving is significant investment this quarter and probably next quarter. The sheer number of significant new products, we are winning with and in particular with some customers that are driving growth.

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010

componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. Thanks very much.

componenttext: Great. Thank you. If I can follow up on the handset market, you mentioned strength in smartphones and dampening in the mid range. How does that net out for Molex in count for 2010 as you look at your design activities across the handset market, what are your expectation for handsets overall for this calendar year?

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the question. I think one of the differences is for us is, I think a lot of analyst look at the unit growth of cell phones. I think one of the things that we have realized over the last year through this transition is that more important to us
componenttext: Thanks for the question. I think one of the differences is for us is, I think a lot of analyst look at the unit growth of cell phones. I think one of the things that we have realized over the last year through this transition is that more important to us is the dollar growth in those markets and then also who are selling to in that margin opportunities in some of the most complex devices is better. So, I think, we think overall, if you look at calendar year 2010, we believe that if you look at calendar year '11, the unit numbers of cell phones were down. Our revenue held up reasonably well towards the end of the year based on the growth in the smartphone market. If you look at Calendar year '10, we are not expecting that to be a dramatic growth market for us, but we certainly think that will be over 2009 in terms of absolute dollars.

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I think and I am sure you have seen in some other companies, the discussion in the last few months, we have a lot of this, the procurements and commodity manages that we talked to is about securing supply and talking about the ransom of new product techno
componenttext: I think and I am sure you have seen in some other companies, the discussion in the last few months, we have a lot of this, the procurements and commodity manages that we talked to is about securing supply and talking about the ransom of new product technology. Less about can we get cost reduction on the things we are already supplying and I think part of that is the psychology change in them. If you went back a year ago to the January to March quarter, it was a pretty bleak environment; everybody was looking at how they could change those same costs. And so a lot of discussion than in the price reduction if you want to keep the business. I mean there's always discussion about being cost competitive, but a lot of discussions now are about securing supply and ramping up new products.

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah. Guys, thanks for taking my question. Martin, you highlighted that the order bookings was down I think 13 to 15% from the peak level sometime in '08. When can we see those levels, I mean, do you think we can see this fiscal year or this calendar year
componenttext: Yeah. Guys, thanks for taking my question. Martin, you highlighted that the order bookings was down I think 13 to 15% from the peak level sometime in '08. When can we see those levels, I mean, do you think we can see this fiscal year or this calendar year?

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know. Frankly, I have been very surprised, pleasantly surprised. If you have asked me this time a year ago that I think that our bookings will be up 40% year-over-year, I would never have guessed that would have been the case. And I think the fact
componenttext: I don't know. Frankly, I have been very surprised, pleasantly surprised. If you have asked me this time a year ago that I think that our bookings will be up 40% year-over-year, I would never have guessed that would have been the case. And I think the fact they were up 40% for bookings over the last 12 months is a functional how did the recovery has been and I think we have had a great success with new products and I think Molex continue to invest in the downturn in new products technology is helping us to win more than our fair share and new designs that has always been the strength of the company coming out of the downturn. But I think, we are confident we continue to grow those new products. But I think, getting up the next 15% would be let's face it a normal growth rate for us in a year if we had a normal growth rate for the market. So I can say if the market next year grows 7% to 10% and I think we can clearly by the end of the year getting up to those kinds of levels. But I could not predict what was going to happen this year, so I am certainly not going to do that next year.

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. So coming back to the demand and the fact that we are seeing this demand some level of same power. Is that more Molex specific or do you think that's across industry or in other word, if you look at your top 20 or 30, 40 accounts, is it more like th
componenttext: Okay. So coming back to the demand and the fact that we are seeing this demand some level of same power. Is that more Molex specific or do you think that's across industry or in other word, if you look at your top 20 or 30, 40 accounts, is it more like they are getting market share faster than the overall market? Or what you're seeing is very consistent across the board and in non Molex accounts?

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I think when you look at where the growth has comes from, it's encouraging that it is very broad based. And it's across a lot of different industries as you have heard today. The only industry that was not sequential which is consumer which I think is abs
componenttext: I think when you look at where the growth has comes from, it's encouraging that it is very broad based. And it's across a lot of different industries as you have heard today. The only industry that was not sequential which is consumer which I think is absolutely understandable given the procedural trends. But I would say that one of the things that we're excited about is that if you went back to fiscal year '07, which is the second quarter of fiscal year '07, we had similar bookings and look at where they came from then. The bookings were far more narrowly focused on a limited group of companies. And whereas, today I would say far more broad-based and I think one of the interesting things is that if you look at the first half of this fiscal year, our business is still down for the first six months versus the first six months of last year but are focused accounts are up over 15%. We talked about the 50 companies that we have picked around the world that we were going to focus on and I think we are winning with those companies and gaining share with those accounts. So I think some of this is as gaining shares of the focus account on getting exceptional growth in both levels with new product wins.

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Great. And talking about the focused accounts, is there any one particular geography or one particular end-market that you're seeing perhaps more greater traction or across the board evenly spread?
componenttext: Great. And talking about the focused accounts, is there any one particular geography or one particular end-market that you're seeing perhaps more greater traction or across the board evenly spread?

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: It's spread around across the board in terms of markets because we deliberately did that because we wanted to spread the risk because I think if you went back to '07, some of the growth was too narrowly focused to a few companies in a couple of end market
componenttext: It's spread around across the board in terms of markets because we deliberately did that because we wanted to spread the risk because I think if you went back to '07, some of the growth was too narrowly focused to a few companies in a couple of end markets. So we consciously spread that. I would say if there were geographic biased there has an Asia biased.

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010

componenttext: When you look at your ERP system, how much visibility do you have or how much is it like instantaneous, you have access to the order flow at that very moment and how much visibility do you have with this new ERP system?

componenttextpreview: It's tremendous. I can tell you every morning exactly what our orders were in a global basis, what our revenues were in a global basis and we can tell what it is like customer where our margins are by customer so and I think what is more important is in s
componenttext: It's tremendous. I can tell you every morning exactly what our orders were in a global basis, what our revenues were in a global basis and we can tell what it is like customer where our margins are by customer so and I think what is more important is in some ways that is historic data. What's more important I think is the linking our cell engineers around the world to that and having a global CRM system so we can drive our global project pipeline. So I think having all 700 cell engineers around the world link to the same system particular today with the global nature of the product, because a tremendous amount of the business we do involve designing work in California and the product being sold through CM in Asia, so being able to link that together globally is a huge advantage.

componenttext: I think the gross margin you're seeing now is impacted by the transition cost that we have talked about. There could be as much as $7 to 10 million in cost that we've incurred in higher freight, in training costs and moving to things that are not part of the restructuring they're taking place in this quarter and we'll continue some into next quarter. But those are costs that we will certainly see decreased once we get through the restructuring program.

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010

componenttext: With any acquisitions in the quarter there was a 10 million charge in your cash flow statement and then perhaps related to that, Martin if you could just update as on your M&A thoughts, you got quite a bit of cash building up in your balance sheet and the analyst there I think you talked about certainly the desire to be more inquisitive so we would love to hear your updated thoughts on that.

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. There was an acquisition during the quarter, we actually disclosed and issued a press release. We acquired a company in China that manufactures primarily our ex-products, so strengthen our position in the RF market and strengthen our product profile
componenttext:
Yes. There was an acquisition during the quarter, we actually disclosed and issued a press release. We acquired a company in China that manufactures primarily our ex-products, so strengthen our position in the RF market and strengthen our product profile there. I think you remember when we talked about where we wanted to focus; we said it will be in the RF area. We said it would be in the medical market and also we wanted to vertically integrate some of our value added business. If you look back at last year, we actually completed three acquisitions last year, Fujigami Micro in early part of the year, which helped us with our micro-etch technology, which we are really excited about from the new technology is coming out of that company and that one of the things that helped our growth. 
We acquired the Antenna Engineering Resources of Motorola in Europe in the middle of the year and that the strengthened our antenna business which has broaden our base. And now TN which is the company we acquired in China that manufacturers RF products. We had a very good pipeline and actually we had a review with our global management and part of my objectives when I was visiting Asia last week was to visit some potential targets. Some of these companies are obviously family owned and so the timing of when they take place I think it is not strictly under our control, but our expectation going forward is to have continuous pipeline. Primarily small niche deals, tuck in one that are focused on technology like the one we did last year, but we would certainly keep our eyes open for more medium-size acquisitions that would strengthen our position in the end market.

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: The average lead time given by our customers in terms of incoming orders to us is right around 17 days. The average shipment dates for us is obviously very close to that number. 18 to 19 days. So, we've often said, 70% of what we ship in the month is effe
componenttext: The average lead time given by our customers in terms of incoming orders to us is right around 17 days. The average shipment dates for us is obviously very close to that number. 18 to 19 days. So, we've often said, 70% of what we ship in the month is effectively ordered in the same month. So our visibility is shorter. Having said that, some of the new product programs that we have booked have some schedules that go out into the data market into the fourth quarter, but we have pretty limited visibility going out there perhaps a little more than we would have a year ago but not much and the lead times are still a very tight. We are talking 20 days or less up across our average product line.

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Martin, when we look at over the next year calendar 10, where are you seeing the most activity in terms of your market and what you think the greatest strength will be from?
componenttext: Martin, when we look at over the next year calendar 10, where are you seeing the most activity in terms of your market and what you think the greatest strength will be from?

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: The most activity in terms of geography is clearly Asia, from a geographic perspective. We believe that would continue. I think when we look at end markets, we believe that Telecom infrastructure and data infotech market will continue to be very strong. T
componenttext:
The most activity in terms of geography is clearly Asia, from a geographic perspective. We believe that would continue. I think when we look at end markets, we believe that Telecom infrastructure and data infotech market will continue to be very strong. That is where we are seeing some of the strongest growth today. We would expect consumer probably to be weaker through March and then start to see some of the new products from their going into next Christmas.
And I think industrial and also our expectation is there they will steadily improve through a combination of just unit growth and increased content. Let me give one example, I think the market that got hit the hardest was auto particularly in North America. North American automotive units sales last year were only 10.3 million units. And that's way down from the 17 million plus that was being sold back in 2000. This year, they're talking about that going up to potentially 12 million plus which is still really low relative to the high point, but still a 20% increase over what we saw last year. So I think when you look at those auto and industrial markets, assuming there is a gradual economic recovery around the world, you could see the units in those grow, but not dramatically. I can the dramatic opportunities for us and more in the info tech area and then potentially consumer electronics if some of these new products takeoff.

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: In the March quarter, how should we think about auto and data?
componenttext: In the March quarter, how should we think about auto and data?

componenttext: In terms of revenue for us, I think I would think data would be up significantly based on the backlog we have of product shipping to there already. I think auto would be pretty flat.

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: So data will be up significantly in the March quarter.
componenttext: So data will be up significantly in the March quarter.

headline: Molex Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Auto I think would be flat quarter to quarter.
componenttext: Yes. Auto I think would be flat quarter to quarter.

componenttext: Really just the fact that I think there has been a lot of corporate spend around the world on hardware. The data center refresh and some of our major customers there have orders grown up and forecast go into the quarter and lead us to believe that business will remain strong. It is networking; it is in server; it is in storage; I think those three areas.

componenttext: I think it also in products and data and some of the wins that we talked earlier about winning some corporate customers that are growing pretty well, so it is a combination of the two.

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day ladies and gentlemen and welcome to the third quarter 2010 Molex Incorporated earning conference call. My name is Janeta and I will be your operator for today. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. (Operator Instructions)As
componenttext:
Good day ladies and gentlemen and welcome to the third quarter 2010 Molex Incorporated earning conference call. My name is Janeta and I will be your operator for today. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. (Operator Instructions)
As a reminder this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Mr. Steve Martens, Vice President of Investor Relations, please proceed.

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Hello everyone and thanks for taking some time to join us today for our quarterly call. I am joined on the call by Martin Slark our CEO, Dave Johnson, our CFO and Liam McCarthy our COO. Please note that this call is being recorded and will be available fo
componenttext:
Hello everyone and thanks for taking some time to join us today for our quarterly call. I am joined on the call by Martin Slark our CEO, Dave Johnson, our CFO and Liam McCarthy our COO. Please note that this call is being recorded and will be available for replay by accessing the Investor Relations section of our website. Presentation material are also available on the website. As usual wed like to limit this call to one hour, when we get to the Q&A we ask for one question per participant and one follow-up question.
Before we turn our attention to the quarterly results, let's review our Safe Harbor statements which are on slides 1 and 2 of the presentation materials. During the course of this presentation we will be providing forward-looking information and referring to non-GAAP measures. Please read carefully the forward-looking statement section of our press release and Form 10-K for an understanding of the risks and uncertainties associated with forward-looking information and the reconciliation of non-GAAP measures to GAAP.
And now I will turn the call over to Martin.

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon everyone and thank you again for joining our call and thank you Steve. Before we start the main call, I just wanted to give all of you a quick update on our situation in Japan. As you know we announced publicly on April 9th that we recently
componenttext:
Good afternoon everyone and thank you again for joining our call and thank you Steve. Before we start the main call, I just wanted to give all of you a quick update on our situation in Japan. As you know we announced publicly on April 9th that we recently learned that Molex have been a victim of a fraud on the part of an individual in our Japanese subsidiary. We have engaged legal counsel, Jones Day and they have in turn engaged forensic accountants, Alex partners, to investigate this matter. Based on the investigated input and written oral statements from the individual involved, we believe that he forged documentation that enabled him to borrow money from Japanese banks in Molex Japans name on an unauthorized basis and then concealed those transactions. We believe he used the unauthorized borrowings primarily to fund losses on unauthorized security trades also made in Molexs name.
At this point we believe that the total amount involved in this fraud scheme is approximately $193.2 million of which we have recognized a loss in the quarter of $31 million and disclosed a contingent liability of $162.2 million. The contingent liability represents the current balance of unauthorized borrowings at Molex Japan. Since this matter is the subject of an ongoing investigation we hope that you will understand that we will not be able to answer any questions on this call relating to this fraud, but we will certainly update you as soon as we have appropriate information to release.
Now lets turn our attention on to the quarters results. If you could turn to page three I will start by talking about our order trends. Overall bookings for the quarter were $838 million, up 8% sequentially and 77% year-over-year. Given that this comparison is to the low point of last years downturn we expected strong result. But these results are much stronger than our most optimistic projections.
Excluding last years downturn, our average sequential increase in bookings in Q3 versus Q2 is about 3% to 4% versus the 8% we saw this quarter. The ongoing recovery was clearly far more important than any seasonal factors this quarter. The year-over-year numbers were the strongest that I have ever seen in my career at Molex and as you will hear shortly, our booking strength was very broad based. It is worth noting that our March monthly bookings were a new record for the company and our April run rate is above the level that we have reported for Q3.
Today we have not seen any evidence of double ordering, but we have some distributors trying to rebuild inventory, strong orders for new product launches of some customers and some building of inventory in preparation for a predicted stronger second half for this calendar year. And I will give you a few more data points on your concerns perhaps in that area later in my presentation.
Overall our book-to-bill ratio for the quarter was a very strong 1.11. If you turn now to page 4 I will talk about the changes in our orders by industry segment for the March quarter. Our booking strength as you can see from the chart was very broad based. The percent of our bookings now coming from focused accounts is over 26% of the total. This is further evidence of the success of our focused account program which is helping both our growth and our margins. Automotive bookings were up 8% sequentially and 80% year-over-year. We continue to benefit from incentive schemes in Japan and from some countries in Europe. Although as I sure you know the incentive schemes have now stopped in Germany.
In North America Q1 we saw vehicle sales increasing for the whole market by 16% to 2.545 million vehicles. Molexs order increased for the same period with up over 60%. In China Q1 calendar year 10 passenger car production was approximately 3.5 million vehicles up 84% from a year ago
Molex growth over the same period is up over 120%. We believe very strong evidence that we are gaining shares to increase sales of standard products across multiple platforms particularly in Asia and with the increasing electronic content, particularly in telematics and safety and convenience applications, we see plenty of opportunities for this growth to continue.
Global vehicle production is predicted to increase 8% in calendar year 10 to 61.4 million vehicles and a further 8% onto 66.6 million in calendar year 11. Automotive remains a very large connecting market and with our new structure and our global footprint, we believe we can continue to grow fast in the market and operate far more profitably than we have in the recent task.
If you now look at the data segments, we were up 3% sequentially and 81% year-over-year. Calendar year 10Q1 is normally a weak quarter for the data market because of a lull following strong calendar yearend hardware purchases. Many companies obviously have capital budgets that are structured on a calendar year basis. This lull did not happen this year. Networking was very strong and particularly we had strong orders coming from all of the market leaders in that segment, so it was broad based even within the networking segment.
The service sector continues to strengthen, we are seeing strong growth from new products particularly our new range of IT sockets.
In storage, the migrations and new protocols such as FAT2.0 and 16 gigabits fiber channel is very positive for Molex with the strong product range that we have in that area. Notebooks were also strong with bookings up over 90% for the quarter year-over-year and across the entire data sector we believe that our strong new product portfolio and the strength of our global sales team that is now selling our entire product range is really helping us to gain share in this segment as well. Telecom was up 5% sequentially and 67% year-over-year. The smartphone sector continues to grow quickly with Molex particularly benefiting from the android platform sales.
Midrange was down this quarter, but is expected to recover in Q4. Entry level phones in emerging markets remain strong, but that was increasingly supported by local manufacturers and gray market phones. Overall cell phone shipment were up only 2% sequentially calendar year 10 versus Q4 calendar year 09, but smart phones were up 15%. Whats very obvious and its been very widely publicized is that the incremental revenue growth and profit opportunity in the cell phone market is clearly going to be in the cell phone segment where Molex is very strong. 
Overall the market is expected to expand from 1.21 billion units in calendar year 09 to 1.4 billion units in calendar year 10. But some of the major suppliers that we, some of the major manufacturers that we deal in this segment are concerned about possible shortages of memory and LCD. If that happens that obviously could limit the overall growth of the market. If you look at the telecomm equipment market that was very, very strong last quarter, particularly with customers in Asia and customer supporting the Asian market. There are some players in both North America and Europe who have been very successful in Europe and we have equally enjoyed that success with them. Migration to new platforms is really what is driving this along with new products sales from Molexs company. Consumer electronics was up 6% sequentially and 66% year over year. The growth here is being driven by consumers in Asia particularly in the developing markets.
Some particularly strong segments for us of the digital still camera market where a transition is taking place from digital still cameras to digital still single lens reflex cameras. The reason we bring up that particular difference is that if you look at the connector bond on the difference between DSE and DSLR, is the connector content is about 3X and then obviously helps our sale in that segment. Flat panel TVs where LED backlighting is becoming an increasing trend obviously also increases the content in those devices and that has helped us. 3D TV is still small but is growing rapidly. The other good segments for us are in the consumer market or the gaming market where we are doing very well with all three of the major players, Pachinko and e-readers. Our Q3 industrial bookings were up sequentially a very strong 20% and 80% year over year and we actually had record bookings in March for the industrial sector. In the market the most people still think is generally weak we are very excited to see such strong results from the industrial segment.
As we stated last quarter we are starting to see the benefits of our Woodhead acquisition and the synergy with Molex where we are combining Woodheads industrial experience with Molexs electronic technology. We have seen particularly strong growth in alternative energy markets, security networks, robotics and the semiconduction production equipment sectors. So, we are really pleased to see this and we are really pleased to see the benefits from our Woodhead acquisition coming from.
Finally the medical and military market which are still small market for Molex overall were up 15% sequentially but we are up a 188% year-over-year. We are seeing lots of new product winds in both sectors, we have very strong project pipeline in both sectors and we are really pleased to report during the current quarter one of the major military contractors named Molex as preferred supplier so you can expect to see us to continue to have growth in both of these sectors.
Please turn now to page 5, when I will talk about our order growth by channel and by geography. We saw a strong growth across all channels but distribution in EMS were much stronger than the OEM. Its worth nothing that both of these channels made dramatic cutbacks in inventory levels in the same quarter last year. EMF did this because customers in some key segments took business back in-house to keep their plants busy and distributors credit to them reacted very quickly, so they slowed down their orders that they had placed on supplier.
We are seeing distributors continue to rebuild inventory levels to support increased end demand. As I stated earlier we have not seen any evidence of double ordering, but stronger end demand, slightly longer lead times and greater confidence in the back end of the year is obviously driving stronger orders when we expected. One data point here that might be helpful to our analyst is that normally Molex has about 10% of this backlog which is scheduled out beyond three months.
At the end of March that number had increased to 13% so its higher than normal but as you can see its not materially higher which gives us great confidence that our backlog is strong and its certainly shippable.
Like by geography it should come as no surprise that the strongest year-over-year numbers came from Asia-Pacific sale. The surprise this quarter was the broad based growth in all of our other regions and in particular the strong sequential number in the Americas and Europe.
The sequential growth in the Americas was broad based and in Europe it was driven primarily by industrial market and by the automotive market. APN dominated by Japan was sequentially the weakest but saw a very good pick up at the end of the quarter, as consumer customers started to launch new products for the current calendar year and the lead in toward the selling season at the back end of the calendar year. By the end of this fiscal I think it's worth pointing out that Molex will have more than 60% of its revenues coming from Asia, up from just 50% in fiscal year '07, I think that says a lot about the transitioning of the electronic industry to Asia and also the strong presence that Molex has in that very important angiography.
Now turning to slide 6, several of our key markets normally suffered in the March quarter and looking back over last couple of decades, we normally expect our third quarter revenue to be down sequentially 3% to 4%.
That was clearly not the case this quarter as revenue increased 3.7% from the December quarter and almost 50% from the March quarter last year. This is the fourth consecutive quarter of improvement and we are now just 13% below our peak at $872 million that was achieved in the June 2008 quarter. 
And finally now for me if you turn to page 7, Ill talk very briefly about the changes in our revenue by industry. As you can see on this chart all of the markets improved substantially from the same quarter last year, on a sequential basis, the data, telecom and consumer market were down between 1% and 2% from the December quarter, but that is much, much better than normal seasonality.
Automotive was up 6% and industrial was up 18%. Going forward, we expect to see the strongest sequential growth in the industrial market as our growing market share in that segment continues. Consumer electronics, data and telecom will exhibit above average growth and we expect automotive could moderate somewhat, because clearly some of the strength we've seen has been incentive driven and the expectation is those incentive will be progressively withdrawn as the year continues.
The June quarter is generally our strongest quarter of the year. And our order rates in April remain strong. We are therefore based on our March orders and the April trends we are seeing, providing a revenue guidance of 810 million to 830 million for the June quarter.
Now, let me turn the call over to Dave Johnson, who will take us through the finances in more detail.

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you Martin, please turn now to slide 8 for our P&L summary. As Martin mentioned we are very pleased with the revenue results of $756.3 million, which is well above the top end of our guidance and up sequential and what was normally a, what is normal
componenttext:
Thank you Martin, please turn now to slide 8 for our P&L summary. As Martin mentioned we are very pleased with the revenue results of $756.3 million, which is well above the top end of our guidance and up sequential and what was normally a, what is normally a down quarter seasonally.
Gross margin of 31.2% reflects favorable product mix, better than expected savings from restructuring and the continuation of a very good operating leverage, that we have seen coming out of the downturn.
SG&A at $156.4 million is up sequentially due to R&D costs and variable selling costs not due general admin spending. I will skip all the restructuring and our loss on unauthorized activities in Molex, Japan, since well cover these on the next slide. Other expenses up sequentially due to higher interest expense which was $2.3 million for the quarter and a $1.8 million investment loss, primarily due to our 20% ownership share and a Singaporean Company that we account for on the equity method.
This company is going through its own restructuring activity, which resulted in a loss in that business for the quarter and may continue in to the next quarter. The effective tax rate for the quarter was 30.5% which takes us to net income of $23.8 million or $0.14 per share on 174.8 million shares outstanding.
The chart on page 9 is our GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation as just mentioned GAAP EPS was $0.14 to which we add that $0.04 for our restructuring program and $0.11 for the unauthorized activities in Molex Japan as Martin explained.
This results in a non-GAAP earnings per share of $0.29. This is well above the mid-point of our previous guidance of $0.24 and is the highest EPS that we have reported in six quarters.
The slide on page 10 details our balance sheet metrics. Our net cash has dropped to $160 million from $207 million in the December quarter, this is due primarily to the cash impact of the unauthorized activities in Molex Japan. 
Working capital requirements supports the recent growth in our business and higher capital expenditures. The higher CapEx is related to production tooling for significant new park introductions and select capacity increases for production machinery to keep up with a rapidly increasing demand from our customers.
As one would expect in this demand environment both accounts receivable and inventory are increasing in a fluid dollar terms. However, accounts receivable days sales outstanding has come down from 76 days last quarter to 73 days this quarter.
Going in the other direction inventory days have increased from 74 days last quarter to 80 days this quarter. Inventory increased at the quarter end to support record level of bookings that we experienced in March and really due to the buffer inventories for the final stage of our product transfer activities in connection with our restructuring program. 
Its no (inaudible) that our vendor managed inventory remains in very good shape at well below days and inventory as distributors has not yet increased above normal levels. We have pulled together gross margin SG&A and operating margin trends all on one chart one page 11, primarily to demonstrate the progress we are making towards our goal of 14% operating margins.
Gross margin has trended very well from a low of 18.5% a year ago to a current quarter of 31.2%. This really demonstrates the substantial operating leverage of our new cost structure even in a phase of transition cost such as pride and duty that remain high and increasing commodity costs.
We had better than expected cost savings resulting from our restructuring program, approximately $6 million in sequential savings in the quarter versus the $3 million we had anticipated and most of these savings benefited the cost of sales line this quarter.
Price erosion was not a mature factor in the quarter, as we continue to see slight downward pressure on this metric though still at the upper end of our 3% to 5% annual expected range.
SG&A at 20.7% reflects spending in absolute dollars of $156 million which is approximately $4 million higher than anticipated. The much faster than expected recovery in demand has resulted in higher spending for both R&D and variable selling cost, but administrative costs which are all cost other than R&D and selling costs actually declined sequentially.
In addition, its interesting to note that the total SG&A salaries were flat sequentially. This demonstrates that a sequential increase in SG&A is clearly related to the non-people variable cost that I mentioned which again is cost caused by the faster than expected recovery of our business. As year-over-year growth rates moderate, we expect these variable costs to stabilize.
Most importantly, our operating income margin hasnt improved very steadily from the prior year to the current levels of 10.5% and we would expect a similar sequential increase in Q4 as we have seen in the past two quarters.
On page 12, we show the trend of our return on net assets metric or [RONA] which increased from a low point of 3.7% in Q4 last year to 14.2% this quarter. This is the metric that under our new division structure we have introduced to monitor the overall progress of each division and business unit. 
This is intended to focus our operating units on the key factors that they cant control to improve our return on assets which are operating income, capital expenditure and working capital.
Our internal goal has been to get back to 15% by the end of the year and we are clearly on track to meet and exceed this number by the fourth quarter.
Please turn to slide 13. We are just one quarter away from the completion of our three year restructuring program. We incurred $9 million in primarily cash charges in the quarter, and expect to incur the final $11.5 million in Q4 to complete this $300 million project, which will result in annual savings of at least $205 million.
As mentioned previously, we are very pleased to see savings brought forward into the third quarter from the fourth quarter, we had expected $3 million in sequential savings, but actually recognized $6 million savings as I mentioned.
This then leaves just $1 million of sequential savings for Q4 to get us to our full savings target, but we still expect some additional sequential savings in the  first few quarters of fiscal year 2011.
We are down to one final plant closure in Slovakia and then of course the completion and final set up and smooth transition of all the production transfers. Our guidance for the coming quarter is shown on slide 14. Based on our strong bookings and backlog positions we estimate that after mid point of our guidance revenue is expected to increase by 8.4% to the range of $810 million to $830 million as Martin mentioned. After eliminating restructuring charge of $0.06 our non-GAAP EPS is expected to be in the range of $0.36 to $0.40 and its important to know that this excludes any cost or charges related to the investigation process in Japan.
In summary, we had strong operating results for the quarter and we are confident that we will continue to see improved operating results now in the fourth quarter. We will now open up the call for questions and Id like to state just once again that we will not be able to answer any questions related to the fraud in Molex Japan due to the ongoing investigation.

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
