headline: Molex Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, thanks for taking my question. When we look at the product mix trending over the next couple quarters, can you comment if there's any impact to the gross margins when we see mobile devices, consumer devices contributing more to the mix and less automo
componenttext: Hi, thanks for taking my question. When we look at the product mix trending over the next couple quarters, can you comment if there's any impact to the gross margins when we see mobile devices, consumer devices contributing more to the mix and less automotive?

headline: Molex Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, I would say that our automotive business generally has lower margins than our consumer and telecom business, so lower automotive business certainly wouldnt be negative. And one of the big reasons for the restructuring we did, as you know, was
componenttext: Actually, I would say that our automotive business generally has lower margins than our consumer and telecom business, so lower automotive business certainly wouldnt be negative. And one of the big reasons for the restructuring we did, as you know, was to focus on manufacturing for automotive in really two major plants, one if North America and one in China. So automotive margins are getting better, but I would say theyre below our average, so lower automotive is not a big impact for us.

headline: Molex Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Got you. And then on the raw material side, I think last quarter your expectation was maybe $1 million in fiscal Q1, $1.5 million in the fiscal Q2 for higher raw materials costs. If we could just get an update on how you're seeing raw material prices and
componenttext: Got you. And then on the raw material side, I think last quarter your expectation was maybe $1 million in fiscal Q1, $1.5 million in the fiscal Q2 for higher raw materials costs. If we could just get an update on how you're seeing raw material prices and the impact on the margins over the next couple quarters?

headline: Molex Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. The - those numbers are still roughly the same, that hasnt changed it. That is really basically the impact of coming off of the hedges and that I would still use that in your numbers. When you look at the difference in the last quarter, copper was
componenttext:
Yes. The - those numbers are still roughly the same, that hasnt changed it. That is really basically the impact of coming off of the hedges and that I would still use that in your numbers. When you look at the difference in the last quarter, copper was actually down 2 percentage points or 3 percentage points on average from Q3 to Q4, and gold was up 7 percentage points or 8 percentage points from Q3 to Q4. So that is - the impact not has not been too significant as of yet. Compared to the - that point in time, now, the spot price for gold is down just a hair and copper is about what it was, but still not much of a change even through today.
Just for the information if I may. Weve put our hedges in place and we put our hedge in place for copper at $3.26 and we put our hedge in place for gold at $1,251 per Troy ounce, so those are - the copper hedges ever so slightly in the money and were well below that for gold today. So, just a little bit more information for you.

headline: Molex Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And one point of clarity if I could. The effective tax rate looking out through all of fiscal 2011, did that sort of 27% to 30% apply?
componenttext: And one point of clarity if I could. The effective tax rate looking out through all of fiscal 2011, did that sort of 27% to 30% apply?

headline: Molex Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would suggest to use the 30%, because we have gone through a lot of activity in the last year. I mentioned on one previous call that we had, our new VP of Tax has gone through a lot of change, we have put in place a major process for our tax basis,
componenttext:
Yes, I would suggest to use the 30%, because we have gone through a lot of activity in the last year. I mentioned on one previous call that we had, our new VP of Tax has gone through a lot of change, we have put in place a major process for our tax basis, balance sheet, that has been completed. 
We also changed our internal transfer pricing, midyear this year. My best guess is in that range, I think the best number to use to model is still probably 30%. And we will update you as the quarters go on as we get more clarity around the tax rate.

headline: Molex Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And is there a long-term goal of maybe getting closer to some of peers more advantaged tax rates?
componenttext: And is there a long-term goal of maybe getting closer to some of peers more advantaged tax rates?

headline: Molex Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. To start there and move it down, wed like to be down in that lower rate - the lower range of that 27 would be a good target. But, as I said, until we see - we stop some of the moving parts and there was so many special transactions that too
componenttext: Absolutely. To start there and move it down, wed like to be down in that lower rate - the lower range of that 27 would be a good target. But, as I said, until we see - we stop some of the moving parts and there was so many special transactions that took place this year, Id suggest 30%, but absolutely, Steve, I think our goal would be to bring down below that as the time goes on.

headline: Molex Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks.
componenttext: Thanks.

componenttext: Hi. Try to make these brief. In terms of the hedges, Dave, is it still 25% of the copper and 50% of the gold that you've hedged?

componenttext: No, its about 35% or about a third of each this time. And what our plan is, as we put those in place, and as the quarters go on, and were going to be hedging further out in the future. And as I think I mentioned last time, were going to therefore put in place a process whereby we dont have any clip where the hedges come off. Were going to all those be hedged, but our first startup process is at 33%.

componenttext: And that's a 12 month hedge?

componenttext: Still about 30% for SG&A and about 70% for COGS.

componenttext: Okay. I mean is there any timeline of expect something before the end of the calendar year or is it just too difficult to speculate?

componenttext: Its too difficult to speculate. I think its going to be an ongoing case in Japan. I think weve obviously now reflected it in our financial statements that we are shifting gears now and attempt to get it resolved.

componenttext: I think thats the last question well take this afternoon. Its well over the hour. So I want to thank everybody for listening into the call. And certainly Steve Martens will be available for follow-ups later today or tomorrow. And we appreciate talking to you. Thank you very much.

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: .Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2010 Molex Inc. Earnings Conference Call. My name is Janeda, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for t
componenttext:
.
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2010 Molex Inc. Earnings Conference Call. My name is Janeda, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Mr. Steve Martens, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please proceed.

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Hello, everyone. Thanks for taking some time to join us today for our quarterly call. I'm joined on the call by Martin Slark, our CEO; Dave Johnson, our CFO; and Liam McCarthy, our COO. Please note that this call is being recorded and will be available fo
componenttext:
Hello, everyone. Thanks for taking some time to join us today for our quarterly call. I'm joined on the call by Martin Slark, our CEO; Dave Johnson, our CFO; and Liam McCarthy, our COO. Please note that this call is being recorded and will be available for replay by accessing the Investor Relations section of our website. Presentation materials are also available on the website. As usual, we'd like to limit this call to one hour. When we get to Q&A, we ask for one question per participant and one follow-up question. 
Before we turn our attention to the quarterly results, let's review our Safe Harbor Statements which are on Slides 1 and 2 of the presentation materials. During the course of this presentation, we will be providing forward-looking information and referring to non-GAAP measures. Please read carefully the Forward-Looking Statements section of our press release and Form 10-K for an understanding of the risks and uncertainties associated with forward-looking information and the reconciliation of non-GAAP measures to GAAP. And now, I'll turn the call to Martin.

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you again for joining our call, and thank you, Steve. Before we start the main call, I just wanted to give all of you a quick update on our situation in Japan. As you know, we announced publicly on April 9 that we recen
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you again for joining our call, and thank you, Steve. Before we start the main call, I just wanted to give all of you a quick update on our situation in Japan. As you know, we announced publicly on April 9 that we recently learned that Molex had been a victim of a fraud on the part of an individual in our Japanese subsidiary. We've engaged legal counsel, Jones Day, and they have in turn engaged forensic accountants, AlixPartners, to investigate this matter. Based on the investigators' input and the written and oral statements from the individual involved, we believe that he forged documentation that enabled him to borrow money from Japanese banks in Molex Japan's name on an unauthorized basis and then concealed those transactions. We believe he used the unauthorized borrowings primarily to fund losses on unauthorized security trades, also made in Molex's name. At this point, we believe that the total amount involved in this fraud scheme is approximately $193.2 million, of which we have recognized the loss in the quarter of $31 million and disclosed a contingent liability of $162.2 million. The contingent liability represents the current balance of unauthorized borrowings at Molex Japan.
Since this matter is the subject of an ongoing investigation, we hope that you will understand that we will not be able to answer any questions on this call relating to this fraud. But we will certainly update you as soon as we have appropriate information to release. Now let's turn our attention onto the quarter's results. If you could turn to Page 3, I'll start by talking about our order trend.
Overall bookings for the quarter were $838 million, up 8% sequentially and 77% year-over-year. Given that this comparison is to the low point of last year's downturn, we expected strong results. But these results are much stronger than our most optimistic projections. Excluding last year's downturn, our average sequential increase in bookings in Q3 versus Q2 is about 3% to 4% versus the 8% we saw this quarter. The ongoing recovery was clearly far more important than any seasonal factors this quarter. The year-over-year numbers were the strongest that I have ever seen in my career at Molex. And as you will hear shortly, our booking strength was very broad-based. It's worth noting that our March monthly bookings were a new record for the company, and our April run rate is above the level that we have reported for Q3.
To date, we have not seen any evidence of double ordering, but we have some distributors trying to rebuild inventory, strong orders for new product launches at some customers and some building of inventory in preparation for a predicted stronger second half to this calendar year. And I'll give you a few more data points on your concerns perhaps in that area later in my presentation. Overall, our book-to-bill ratio for the quarter was a very strong 1.11. If you turn now to Page 4, I'll talk about the changes in our orders by industry segment for the March quarter.
Our booking strength, as you can see from the chart, was very broad-based. The percent of our bookings now coming from focused accounts is over 26% of the total. This is further evidence of the success of our focused account program, which is helping both our growth and our margins. Automotive bookings were up 8% sequentially and 80% year-over-year. We continue to benefit from incentive schemes in Japan and from some countries in Europe. Although, as I'm sure you know, the incentive schemes have now stopped in Germany. In North America, Q1, we saw vehicle sales increase for the whole market by 16% to 2.545 million vehicles. Molex's order increase for the same period was up over 60%.
In China, Q1 calendar year '10 passenger car production was approximately 3.5 million vehicles, up 84% from a year ago. Molex's growth over the same period is up over 120%. We believe there's very strong evidence that we are gaining share to increase sales of standard products across multiple platforms, particularly in Asia. And with increasing electronic content, particularly in telematics and safety and convenience applications, we see plenty of opportunities for this growth to continue. Global vehicle production is predicted to increase 8% percent in calendar year '10 to 61.4 million vehicles, and a further 8% to 66.6 million in calendar year '11.
Automotive Group remains a very large connector market. And with our new structure and our global footprint, we believe we can continue to grow fast in the market and operate far more profitably than we had in the recent past. 
If you now look at the Data segment, we were up 3% sequentially and 81% year-over-year. Calendar year '10 Q1 is normally a weak quarter for the data markets because of a lull following strong calendar year-end hardware purchases. Many companies obviously have capital budgets that are structured on the calendar year basis. This lull did not happen this year. Networking was very strong. And particularly, we had strong orders coming from all of the market leaders in that segment, so it was broad-based even within the Networking segment.
The service sector continues to strengthen, and we are seeing strong growth from new products, particularly our new range of IC sockets. In storage, the migration to new protocols such as SAS 2.0 and 16 gigabit fiber channel is very positive for Molex with the strong product range that we have in that area. Notebooks were also strong, with bookings up over 90% for the quarter year-over-year, and across the entire data sector, we believe that our strong new product portfolio and the strength of our global sales team that is now selling our entire product range is really helping us to gain share in this segment as well. Telecom was up 5% sequentially and 67% year-over-year. The smartphone sector continues to grow quickly, with Molex particularly benefiting from the Android platform sales. Mid-range was down this quarter, but is expected to recover in Q4. Entry-level phones in emerging markets remained strong, but only increasingly supported by local manufacturers and gray market phones.
Overall cell phone shipments were up only 2% sequentially calendar year '10 versus Q4 calendar year '09, but smartphones were up 15%. What's very obvious and has been very widely publicized is that the incremental revenue growth and profit opportunity in the cell phone market is clearly going to be in the cell phone segment where Molex is very strong. Overall, the market is expected to expand from 1.21 billion units in calendar year '09 to 1.4 billion units in calendar year '10. But some of the major manufacturers that we deal with in this segment are concerned about possible shortages of memory and LCD. If that happens, that obviously could limit the overall growth of the market.
If you look at the telecom equipment market, that was very, very strong last quarter, particularly with customers in Asia and customers supporting the Asian market. There are some players in both North America and Europe who have been very successful in Europe, and we have equally enjoyed that success with them. Migration to new platforms is really what is driving this, along with new product sales to Molex as a company.
Consumer Electronics was up 6% sequentially and 66% year-over-year. The growth here has been driven by consumers in Asia, particularly in the developing markets. Some particularly strong segments for us are the digital still camera market where a transition is taking place from digital still cameras to digital single-lens reflex cameras. The reason we bring up that particular difference is that if you look at the connector bond or the difference between DSC and DSLR is that the connector content is about 3x, and that obviously helps our sales in that segment. Flat-panel TVs where LED backlighting is becoming an increasing trend, obviously also increases the content in those devices, and that has helped us. 3D TV is still small but is growing rapidly. The other good segments for us in the consumer market are the gaming market, where we are doing very well with all three of the major players, pachinko and e-readers.
Our Q3 Industrial bookings were up sequentially a very strong 20%, and 80% year-over-year. And we actually had record bookings in March for the industrial sector. In a market that most people still think is generally weak, we are very excited to see such strong results from the Industrial segment. As we stated last quarter, we're starting to see the benefits of our Woodhead acquisition and the synergy with Molex where we're combining Woodhead's industrial experience with Molex's electronic technology. We've seen particularly strong growth in alternative energy markets, security networks, robotics and the semiconduction production equipment sectors. So we're really pleased to see this, and we're really pleased to see the benefit from our Woodhead acquisition coming through.
Finally, the medical and military markets, which are still small markets for Molex overall, we're up 15% sequentially but were up 188% year-over-year. We're seeing lots of new product wins in both sectors. We have very strong project pipeline in both sectors and we're really pleased to report that during the current quarter, one of the major military contractors named Molex as a preferred supplier. So you can expect to see us to continue to have growth in both of these sectors.
Please turn now to Page 5 where I'll talk about our order growth by channel and by geography. We saw strong growth across all channels, but distribution in EMS were much stronger than the OEM. It's worth noting that both of these channels made dramatic cutbacks in inventory levels in the same quarter last year. EMS did this because customers in some key segments took business back in-house to keep their own plants busy, and distributors' credit to them reacted very quickly so they slowed down their orders that they had placed on suppliers. We are seeing distributors continue to rebuild inventory levels to support increased end demand.
As I stated earlier, we've not seen any evidence of double ordering. But stronger end demand, slightly longer lead times and greater confidence in the back end of the year is obviously driving stronger orders than we expected. One data point here that might be helpful toward our analysts is that normally Molex has about 10% of its backlog, which is scheduled out beyond three months. At the end of March, that number had increased to 13%. So it's higher than normal. But as you can see, it's not materially higher, which gives us great confidence that our backlog is strong and it's certainly shippable. By geography, it should come as no surprise that the strongest year-over-year numbers came from Asia-Pacific sales. The surprise this quarter was the broad-based growth in all of our other regions and in particular, the strong sequential number in the Americas and Europe.
The sequential growth in the Americas was broad-based, and in Europe, it was driven primarily by industrial markets and by the automotive market.  APN, dominated by Japan, was sequentially the weakest, but saw a very good pickup at the end of the quarter as consumer customers started to launch new products for the current calendar year and the lead-in towards the selling season at the back end of the calendar year. By the end of this fiscal, I think it's worth pointing out that Molex will have more than 60% of its revenues coming from Asia, up from just 50% in fiscal year '07. I think that says a lot about the transitioning of the electronics industry to Asia and also the strong presence that Molex has in that very important end geography.
Now turning to Slide 6. Several of our key markets normally suffered in the March quarter. And looking back over the last couple of decades, we'd normally expect our third quarter revenue to be down sequentially 3% to 4%. That was clearly not the case this quarter as revenue increased 3.7% from the December quarter and almost 50% from the March quarter last year. This is the fourth consecutive quarter of improvement, and we are now just 13% below our peak of $872 million that was achieved in the June 2008 quarter. And finally now for me, if you turn to Page 7, I'll talk very briefly about the changes in our revenue by industry.
As you can see on this chart, all of the markets improved substantially from the same quarter last year. On a sequential basis, the data, telecom and consumer markets were down between 1% and 2% from the December quarter, but that is much, much better than normal seasonality. Automotive was up 6% and Industrial was up 18%. Going forward, we expect to see the strongest sequential growth in the industrial market, as our growing market share in that segment continues. Consumer Electronics, Data and Telecom will exhibit above-average growth, and we expect Automotive could moderate somewhat, because clearly, some of the strength we've seen has been incentive-driven and the expectation is those incentives will be progressively withdrawn as they year continues. 
The June quarter is generally our strongest quarter of the year. And our order rates in April remain strong. We are, therefore, based on our March orders and the April trends we are seeing, providing a revenue guidance of $810 million to $830 million for the June quarter. Now let me turn the call over to Dave Johnson, who will take us through the finances in more detail.

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Martin. Please turn now to Slide 8 for our P&L summary. As Martin mentioned, we are very pleased with the revenue results of $756.3 million, which is well above the top end of our guidance, and up sequentially in what was normally a down quarte
componenttext:
Thank you, Martin. Please turn now to Slide 8 for our P&L summary. As Martin mentioned, we are very pleased with the revenue results of $756.3 million, which is well above the top end of our guidance, and up sequentially in what was normally a down quarter seasonally.
Gross margin of 31.2% reflects favorable product mix, better-than-expected savings from restructuring and the continuation of a very good operating leverage that we have seen coming out of the downturn. SG&A, at $156.4 million, is up sequentially due to R&D costs and variable selling costs, not due to general admin spending. I will skip over restructuring and our loss on unauthorized activities in Molex Japan since we'll cover these on the next slide. Other expense is up sequentially due to higher interest expense, which was $2.3 million for the quarter, and a $1.8 million investment loss primarily due to our 20% ownership share in a Singaporean company that we account for on the equity method. This company is going through its own restructuring activity, which resulted in a loss in that business for that quarter and may continue into the next quarter. The effective tax rate for the quarter was 30.5%, which takes us to net income of $23.8 million or $0.14 per share on 174.8 million shares outstanding. 
The chart on Page 9 is our GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation. As just mentioned, GAAP EPS was $0.14, to which we add back $0.04 for our restructuring program and $0.11 for the unauthorized activities in Molex Japan that Martin explained. This resulted in non-GAAP earnings per share of $0.29. This is well above the midpoint of our previous guidance of $0.24 and is the highest EPS that we have reported in six quarters.
The slide on Page 10 details our balance sheet metrics. Our net cash has dropped to $160 million from $207 million in the December quarter. This is due primarily to the cash impact of the unauthorized activities in Molex Japan, working capital requirements to support the recent growth in our business and higher capital expenditures. The higher CapEx is related to production tooling for significant new product introductions and select capacity increases for production machinery to keep up with the rapidly increasing demand from our customers.
As one would expect in this demand environment, both accounts receivable and inventory were increasing in absolute dollar terms. However, accounts receivable's days sales outstanding has come down from 76 days last quarter to 73 days this quarter. Going in the other direction, inventory days have increased from 74 days last quarter to 80 days this quarter. Inventory increased at the quarter-end to support the record level of bookings that we experienced in March and really due to the buffer inventories for the final stage of our product transfer activities in connection with our restructuring program.  It's noteworthy that our vendor-managed inventory remains in very good shape at well below 30 days, and inventory at distributors has not yet increased above normal levels.
We have pulled together gross margin, SG&A and operating margin trends all on one chart on Page 11 primarily to demonstrate the progress we are making toward our goal of 14% operating margins. Gross margin has trended very well from a low of 18.5% a year ago to the current quarter of 31.2%. This really demonstrates the substantial operating leverage of our new cost structure even in the face of transition costs such as freight and duty that remain high and increasing commodity costs. We had better-than-expected cost savings resulting from our restructuring program, approximately $6 million in sequential savings in the quarter versus the $3 million that we had anticipated and most of these savings benefited the cost of sales line this quarter.
Price erosion was not a material factor in the quarter as we continue to see slight downward pressure on this metric, though still at the upper-end of our 3% to 5% annual expected range. SG&A, at 20.7%, reflects spending in absolute dollars of $156 million, which is approximately $4 million higher than anticipated. The much-faster-than-expected recovery in demand has resulted in higher spending for both R&D and variable selling costs, but administrative costs, which are all costs other than R&D and selling costs, actually declined sequentially.
In addition, it's interesting to note that the total SG&A salaries were flat sequentially. This demonstrates that the sequential increase in SG&A is clearly related to the non-people variable costs that I mentioned, which again is caused by the faster-than-expected recovery of our business. As year-over-year growth rates moderate, we expect these variable costs to stabilize.
Most importantly, our operating income margin has improved very steadily from the prior year to the current level of 10.5%, and we would expect a similar sequential increase in Q4 as we have seen in the past two quarters.
On Page 12, we showed a trend of our return on net assets metric or RONA, which increased from the low point of 3.7% in Q4 last year to 14.2% this quarter. This is the metric that, under our new division structure, we have introduced to monitor the overall progress of each division and business unit. This is intended to focus our operating units on the key factors that they can control to improve our return on assets, which are operating income, capital expenditure and working capital. Our internal goal has been to get back to 15% by the end of the year, and we are clearly on track to meet and exceed this number by the fourth quarter. 
Please turn to Slide 13. We are just one quarter away from the completion of our three-year restructuring program. We incurred $9 million in primarily cash charges in the quarter and expect to incur the final $11.5 million in Q4 to complete this $300 million project, which will result in annual savings of at least $205 million. As mentioned previously, we are very pleased to see savings brought forward into the third quarter from the fourth quarter. We had expected $3 million in sequential savings but actually recognized $6 million savings as I mentioned. This then leaves just $1 million of sequential savings for Q4 to get us to our full savings target, but we still expect some additional sequential savings in the first two quarters of fiscal year 2011.
We are down to one final plant closure in Slovakia. And then, of course, the completion and final setup and smooth transition of all the production transfers.
Our guidance for the coming quarter is shown on Slide 14. Based on our strong bookings and backlog position, we estimate that at the midpoint of our guidance, revenue is expected to increase by 8.4% to the range of $810 million to $830 million, as Martin mentioned. After eliminating the restructuring charge of $0.06, our non-GAAP EPS is expected to be in the range of $0.36 to $0.40. And it's important to note that this excludes any cost or charges related to the investigation process in Japan.
In summary, we had strong operating results for the quarter, and we are confident that we will continue to see improved operating results now in the fourth quarter. We will now open up the call for questions, and I would like to state, just once again, that we will not be able to answer any questions related to the fraud in Molex Japan due to the ongoing investigation.

So that's a market thats been turning up, but just how your performance is relative to the overall market, and what that means for just new design win activity and customer penetration, et cetera?

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: As you probably know, I think that market has been generally strong in terms of end customers that we service. What was interesting this quarter was that we had very strong orders from all of the major players in that segment. We've adopted a policy in th
componenttext: As you probably know, I think that market has been generally strong in terms of end customers that we service. What was interesting this quarter was that we had very strong orders from all of the major players in that segment. We've adopted a policy in these calls of not naming specific customers, but I'm sure you know as well as I do who the major players are in that market. We have a good presence at all of those companies. And what's been interesting first is, say, two, three years ago, is the range of products that were selling into those companies, and we did some analysis internally, is significantly broader than it was three years ago. So as that segment has come back, we have not only benefited from the growth in the segment but increased penetration in that segment because of our broader product portfolio. We're doing very well in the integrated connector modules, we're doing very well in the fiber area, we're doing very well in the backlight market. And so I think the breadth of our product line has particularly benefited up from that segment.

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And if I can follow up on the margins. You mentioned that increased R&D investment. How should we think about more of the administrative costs? And as revenue growth continues to exceed expectations, how are you going to balance that with a focus on the m
componenttext: And if I can follow up on the margins. You mentioned that increased R&D investment. How should we think about more of the administrative costs? And as revenue growth continues to exceed expectations, how are you going to balance that with a focus on the margins in OpEx?

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me take a stab and that, and then I think Dave can probably add some additional data points. I think the point we wanted to stress in the current quarter was that the increase in SG&A came from variable selling costs. And when you've got bookings grow
componenttext: Let me take a stab and that, and then I think Dave can probably add some additional data points. I think the point we wanted to stress in the current quarter was that the increase in SG&A came from variable selling costs. And when you've got bookings growing year-over-year by 77%, you can imagine what that does to things like sales commissions and things like that. We expect that we're going to continue to grow, but the year-over-year growth rate is not going to be at a 77% rate. So we expect those variable commissions, and we've modeled that out will certainly slow down. And certainly, we've had an extraordinary amount of new product work going on and new product introductions. I think the R&D, hopefully, will continue to be strong. But we think we are very happy with what we're doing with our new structure and the fact that we've been able to maintain our direct people costs, and the admin costs actually sequentially went down. So we think we'll be having to leverage that going forward. So think about that staying very flat and thinking about the variable costs starting to moderate as we move forward. Dave, do you want to add?

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And I would just say, specifically for the fourth quarter, I would expect our total SG&A to be at about the same level as it is this quarter, which reflects the continued spending in R&D and sales cost for the reasons that Martin mentioned.
componenttext: And I would just say, specifically for the fourth quarter, I would expect our total SG&A to be at about the same level as it is this quarter, which reflects the continued spending in R&D and sales cost for the reasons that Martin mentioned.

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010

componenttext: And if I could just come back to the comment on R&D, increased investment there. How does that play into how you're thinking about your position within the connector market and potential for share gains as the recovery strengthens?

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I think, Craig, one of Molex's strategies has always been to reinvest aggressively back into the business and to launch a large number of new products. And we have preferred status with all of the industry leaders that we sell to, and we are a very strong
componenttext: I think, Craig, one of Molex's strategies has always been to reinvest aggressively back into the business and to launch a large number of new products. And we have preferred status with all of the industry leaders that we sell to, and we are a very strong organization, and we believe innovation is our strength. And so we don't intend to back off on that, we think that's the best way that we can continue to gain share. And coming out of previous downturns, Molex has always grown faster than the market. And we think we are demonstrating that now and we're very confident in our ability to continue to do it, but you do it through new products. And that's why you're seeing us make the investments.

componenttext: No. And I think if you look under any scenario that you want to project based on the issues we're facing, we continue to have, relative to the industry, a very, very strong balance sheet. As you know, we did three acquisitions last fiscal year. We continue to have a good pipeline there. Many of the companies are family-owned, so the timing of those acquisitions, I think, is hard to predict. But certainly, if we see opportunities that are strategically good fits for us, and we've said we wanted to focus on the RF area, the medical market and potential backward integration for our cable assembly business. As we see good opportunities there, we will continue to pursue them.

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And then as we move into the June quarter, you said the industrial would be the strongest, consumer data and telecom will be better than average. Can you give just a little more granularity on that? Is industrial going to hit double-digits sequential grow
componenttext: And then as we move into the June quarter, you said the industrial would be the strongest, consumer data and telecom will be better than average. Can you give just a little more granularity on that? Is industrial going to hit double-digits sequential growth once again?

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: If you look at Molex's history, generally speaking, from Q3 to Q4, the sequential increase in revenue is about 8%. And we're obviously expecting it'll be much stronger than that. And I think the industrial, we believe, based on the gains we're seeing ther
componenttext: If you look at Molex's history, generally speaking, from Q3 to Q4, the sequential increase in revenue is about 8%. And we're obviously expecting it'll be much stronger than that. And I think the industrial, we believe, based on the gains we're seeing there would be the strongest of that group.

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And then finally, you've had a huge rebound now in sales. It's probably fair to say that you're gaining market share. Do you feel like that's a correct statement, and if so, where do you think it's coming from?
componenttext: And then finally, you've had a huge rebound now in sales. It's probably fair to say that you're gaining market share. Do you feel like that's a correct statement, and if so, where do you think it's coming from?

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it is fair to say, when I look at the year-over-year rebound in our business, I think it is fair to say we are gaining share. But I think we've highlighted which markets they were in. And I think -- we think in the industrial market where we histo
componenttext: I think it is fair to say, when I look at the year-over-year rebound in our business, I think it is fair to say we are gaining share. But I think we've highlighted which markets they were in. And I think -- we think in the industrial market where we historically weren't a big player, I think we're doing very well in that market. And I think the new product launches we have had in the data and consumer markets have helped us as well. I think the automotive market, it's hard to tell, because it's hard to see the impact of the incentives there. But we certainly think that, as the automotive market has shifted to Asia and as you know, China is now producing more cars than there are in North America, our strong presence in Asia benefits us there. I think if you're asking the question how are we doing versus our competitors, I think one of the things that came out of this downturn is that some of the smaller players, and there are 2,000 connector companies around the world, financially found it tough to get through that downturn. And I think the major customers continue to reduce their supply base. So I think if you're a major global supplier, you have the chance to gain share at those customers, and I think Molex is doing that.

I mean, you guys are pretty close to your target model out there and going forward, I mean, not the next quarter but kind of longer-term, what is your level of confidence of sustaining at these levels? Are you going to be looking at maybe revising your target gross margin levels? Any commentary on that? And then I have a follow-up.

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: It amazes me that I think three years ago, when we started our restructuring, we talked about where we wanted to get to. And I think we're now in sight of getting to those numbers and doing what we said we would do. And the first question for an analyst i
componenttext: It amazes me that I think three years ago, when we started our restructuring, we talked about where we wanted to get to. And I think we're now in sight of getting to those numbers and doing what we said we would do. And the first question for an analyst is where do you go beyond that? I think let's just get to our target, first of all. I think we believe that we're improving our operating numbers because we've made some significant structural changes to the company, and we think we can certainly operate more effectively, going forward, both in terms of sales growth and in terms of margins. I think we should focus on getting to our target numbers first and then we'll talk about where we go from there.

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: If I look at your 50-plus strategic accounts, can you give us a sense of what subsegment has the largest exposure in terms of revenues? And also, how much is industrial contributing to those 54 strategic accounts?
componenttext: If I look at your 50-plus strategic accounts, can you give us a sense of what subsegment has the largest exposure in terms of revenues? And also, how much is industrial contributing to those 54 strategic accounts?

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I'd rather not give too much detail about where those accounts are and who they are. I will tell they are spread across all of our end markets, with the exception of automotive and consumer. Because we are already very strong in both of those markets and
componenttext: I'd rather not give too much detail about where those accounts are and who they are. I will tell they are spread across all of our end markets, with the exception of automotive and consumer. Because we are already very strong in both of those markets and the markets there are dominated by a small number of large companies. So the companies then are split, really, between the data markets and industrial markets, but more excitedly, I think in some of the emerging areas such as new energy, such as robotics and things like that. So we try to target solid-state lighting, some of the areas where we've historically not been a strong player in. And this is really what's helped us also in the medical and military markets. I'd say if you wanted a ballpark number on the industrial, probably makes up 10% to 12% of the group.

componenttextpreview: Those costs are continuing at the same level. And as we said last time, they'll abate sometime in next year. Whether they abate in Q1, as we had said, or maybe Q2, I'm not sure now. But they are continuing, and as we mentioned, we have one more plant that
componenttext: Those costs are continuing at the same level. And as we said last time, they'll abate sometime in next year. Whether they abate in Q1, as we had said, or maybe Q2, I'm not sure now. But they are continuing, and as we mentioned, we have one more plant that's being closed toward the end of June, and there'll be some transition costs associated with that one as well.

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Martin, you had mentioned when you were speaking about forward trends of the June quarter is typically, or has been often in the past, the best for Molex. So I'm just curious, was that just -- the intent of that comment just to kind of layout typical seas
componenttext: Martin, you had mentioned when you were speaking about forward trends of the June quarter is typically, or has been often in the past, the best for Molex. So I'm just curious, was that just -- the intent of that comment just to kind of layout typical seasonal trends, or is there anything in the bookings right now that would indicate that you do see a step-back in the September quarter, which is something that you have seen in...

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think -- I'm not giving any sort of view relative to September. As I said, interestingly enough, one of the best analysis we did, because we had a lot of questions about had we seen any evidence of double ordering and things like that. So one of u
componenttext: I don't think -- I'm not giving any sort of view relative to September. As I said, interestingly enough, one of the best analysis we did, because we had a lot of questions about had we seen any evidence of double ordering and things like that. So one of us announced that we'd actually look to see how far out does our backlog go. And only about 10% of it goes out beyond the next three months. Typically, there's about 13% of it beyond that right now. So there's a little bit of forward ordering going on, but I wouldn't call that a large amount. I think it also reinforces the fact why we want to probably stick to quarterly guidance, because given how short-term the backlog is and how low the visibility in the electronics industry, it's hard to go out beyond that. Now, normally speaking, June is normally our strongest quarter, going to the end of our fiscal year. And we obviously see the markets that are consumer-driven, ongoing strength into the first quarter of next year. And then I think what happens as you go into Christmas in Q1 next year depends a lot on consumer demand. But certainly, capital spending across industries where I think it seems a lot of companies have come of out this downturn, flushed with cash, has driven a lot of purchase of data equipment. And consumer spending in Asia certainly seems to be very strong, and we're benefiting from both of those.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the first quarter 2011 Molex, Inc. earnings conference call. My name is Deanna and I will be your operator for today. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. As a reminder, this conference i
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the first quarter 2011 Molex, Inc. earnings conference call. My name is Deanna and I will be your operator for today. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes.
Id now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Mr. Steve Martens, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please proceed.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Deanna. Good afternoon, everyone and thank you for joining us today. I am here today with Martin Slark, our CEO and Dave Johnson, our CFO.Please note this call is being recorded, and will be available for replay by accessing the Investor Rela
componenttext:
Thank you, Deanna. Good afternoon, everyone and thank you for joining us today. I am here today with Martin Slark, our CEO and Dave Johnson, our CFO.
Please note this call is being recorded, and will be available for replay by accessing the Investor Relations section of our Web site. Presentation materials are also available on the Web site. As usual, wed like to limit this call to one hour. When we get to Q&A, we ask for one question per participant, and one follow-up question.
During the course of this presentation, we will be providing forward-looking information and referring to certain non-GAAP measures. Please read carefully the forward-looking statements section of our press release and Form 10-K for an understanding of the risks and uncertainties associated with forward-looking information and the reconciliation of non-GAAP measures to GAAP.
Now, Ill turn the call over to Martin.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve, and good afternoon everybody. If you like to turn to page three, we have added a new slide to this quarters deck, where we have put in a one page summary of what we think are the key points emerging from the quarter we just finished.
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve, and good afternoon everybody. If you like to turn to page three, we have added a new slide to this quarters deck, where we have put in a one page summary of what we think are the key points emerging from the quarter we just finished.
The first point I obviously want to talk about is a quick update on unauthorized activities in Japan. As you already know, the unauthorized activity occurred many years ago when we restated our financial results in June 10-K to reflect the liability of this unauthorized activity.
During the quarter that we just completed, we were served notice of a lawsuit by the financial institution involved. We responded to this complaint and we intend to vigorously defend our position as these loans were unauthorized. This matter is now subject to ongoing litigation. We cant provide additional details at this time or answer any more questions about this particular topic.
Now, we would like to spend the rest of the call talking about our operating results, and we are very pleased to announce the fact that we had record revenues and earnings per share in the September quarter.
Given where we were 18 months ago, this is quite an accomplishment and obviously reflects good progress by the company and tremendous recovery in the electronics industry generally.
Our orders declined from the record levels obtained in the June quarter; however, we still had one of our best quarters ever for orders and the level of business activity certainly remains quite strong.
During the quarter, we made progress reducing our unusual logistics costs as well as improving production efficiencies on transferred production. Corrective actions of these items are largely a function of time, time to build inventory to fill ceilings and time for our manufacturing operations to learn the nuances of working with new equipment.
We continue to improving in these areas, and we expect to see further progress in the December quarter. We also made progress reducing our backlog, which hit an all-time high in the June quarter due to the rapid recovery experienced over the last several quarters.
Backlog was reduced by $28 million from the June levels as we brought online additional capacity.
Finally, we announced a 15% increase in our dividend. We have a long-term commitment to our dividend and given the increase in earnings potential of our new organization and the projected future cash flows, we are very comfortable increasing the payout at this time.
You turn now to page four. Ill talk a little bit about our revenue and order trend. Revenues for the September quarter were an all-time high of $898 million, 3% above the previous high reached in June of 08 and 6% above the June quarter and 33% above the same quarter last year.
Even though orders declined 5% sequentially from the record set in the June quarter at $868 million, we achieved our third best quarter ever for new orders and year-over-year orders were still up 20% and all of that growth was organic.
The order rate was slower during the early summer and strengthened during the September and that strength has continued into October. While previous quarters were helped by incentives and inventory restocking, we believe that our current order rate is now more reflective of end demand.
Its also worth noting that our bookings in the June quarter were up 9% sequentially and 58% year-over-year, so on a sequential basis were comparing ourselves to a record quarter.
Given that the major economies in Europe and North America are recovering slowly, its apparent that the emerging markets, particularly China are driving most of the growth in the electronics sector.
Disposable income in China increased by over 80% during the last five years and this trend is expected to continue as the recovery becomes more consumption-oriented and less dependent on exports.
This shift coupled with the proliferation of mobile devices and related infrastructure, an uptick in enterprise spending on tech hardware, and many new product introductions, we believe we will provide good opportunities to continue to grow our business as we move forward.
You turn now to page five Ill talk a little bit about the order trend by channel and by geography. By channel, orders from distribution decreased by the largest amount, by about 12% from the June quarter.
Distributors seem to have largely replenished their inventories and in my own view perhaps over-corrected on the down side of when the market took its plummet and about over-corrected on the upside and are now in the process of adjusting their inventory levels and the order rates accordingly.
Orders from OEMs and EMS were only down by 2% and 3% respectively. As I said before, we achieved record orders in the June quarter, so the slight decrease particularly in the OEM and EMS sectors is really not surprising in the current quarter.
By region, Europe decreased by 15% from the June rate largely due to the summer slowdown caused by vacations and holidays. Year-over-year Europe was only up 8% and thats largely because Europe benefited the most from stimulus in the 09 period.
Orders in the Americas declined 9% since June, due to summer slowdown in July and August, and due to lower orders primarily from distribution. Asia North increased from the June quarter by 6%, this reflects a strong consumer electronics market for us and strong demand for mobile phones and particularly smartphones.
Asia South was down 4% from June again largely due to seasonal slowdown in orders, but we saw that those orders were up 32% year-over-year. So, our business level in Asia South remains very, very high. 64% of our total orders were from Asia in this quarter.
As a percent of our business coming from Asia just continues to increase as we move forward. This is somewhat explained by the relative strength in markets where production is largely in Asia, mainly mobile phones, consumer electronics and info tech.
Its also the result of the increased consumption of those devices in emerging markets. Its worth noting that our orders in the Asia-Pacific South region alone exceeded the total of our orders in North America and Europe combined in the last quarter.
Now, if you turn to page six, Ill talk a little bit about the change in our revenue and orders by end market. Revenues for the automotive market declined 4% sequentially and orders declined 9% from the June quarter. This was not unexpected and that automotive production usually declines in the September quarter.
On a geographic basis, weve seen favorable results in North America, as the market seems to have stabilized and continues to rebound. September auto sales were the best in 13 months in North America and its worth noting that those records were achieved without incentives, and were now on a run rate to sell about 12.2 million vehicles in North America.
Europe slowed down in part due to the end of most of the stimulus packages across Europe, but also due to the summer holiday period which probably has the biggest impact in Europe.
We have also now fully, evenly balanced between our automotive revenues in North America, Europe and Asia, that business being slipped a third, a third, a third.
Going forward, we expect the North America and China will post the highest growth rates, while Europe and Japan will stay relatively flat. Longer term, we also believe that the increasing electronic content in vehicles will help to grow our automotive business. The data or info tech market performed as expected.
Revenues increased 6%, while orders decreased 3% from the June quarter. Revenue increased in large part due to backlog reductions, while the decrease in orders is due to a small buildup in inventory in the supply chain. This inventory is very product and customer-specific does not appear to be reflective in overall pullback in end market demand.
If you recall, many of the large players in the info tech market were impacted by components shortages earlier this year and at the same time, were very optimistic that demand would be very strong in the second half and that they would all gain market share.
Now that component shortages appear to have been resolved, there appear to be a modest inventory buildup that is being worked through and we believe will be worked through by the end of the calendar year.
Companies still need to upgrade their datacenters and add capacity and we think that that underlying trend will provide ongoing good business as we move into 2011.
We are also seeing just as an anecdote tremendous interest in cabinet computers. And I was recently visiting our operations in Japan, and looking at our customer relationship module. Its interesting to note that were actively working on 50 different tablet computer programs. It just shows theres some tremendous interest in that new format.
If you look now on page six, Ill continue with the commentary relative to the end markets. The telecom market which included infrastructure, networking, as well as mobile phones, performed well overall with revenues increasing 10% and orders decreasing 4% from the June quarter.
Infrastructure revenue was down modestly, however, orders were down by 14%. This business tends to be very lumpy and chunky and has been very strong coming out of the downturn.
We announced seeing a pause in the level of business activity. However, both revenue and orders are well above the prior year levels. Revenue and orders for the mobile phone submarket were very, very strong. 30% up sequentially and 23% year-over-year. This is due into a large number of new products being introduced and a continued shift to smartphones as well as a strong seasonal influence.
Looking ahead, there are many new products in the horizon for the mobile phone market, including HD screen, 4G devices and continued share gains of smartphones as well as the introduction of Android and Windows 7 based devices.
Many of the major OEMs have also done a good job of penetrating new geographies with mobile phones. Overall, we believe that this trend will drive the need for infrastructure to support new devices as we move into calendar year 11.
Despite what you read in the press, the consumer market at least for us has been quite strong. Revenues increased 12% for the June quarter and orders declined a modest 1% which is below the normal seasonal trend that we would see. It is largely due to the number of new product introductions, backlog reductions and the strong influence of a pre-Christmas build.
Even in these difficult times, consumers are choosing to spend their discretionary income on an interesting array of devices, which have increased in connector content. For example, LCD panels, trends include now 3D technology, LED backlighting and an increasing use of these high definition displays in public domains.
While we do not know the exact percentage of end consumption in emerging markets, we do know that this percentage is increasing due to strong economic growth and a rise in consumers in developing countries. This is a long-term trend coupled with the recovery in the economies of the developing countries, and new products offerings will drive growth in 2011 and beyond.
Revenue in the industrial market increased 3% in the June quarter, while orders declined 8%. The reduction in orders from distribution had a profound impact on this market and this is very much a high-mix, low-volume market where distribution is a significant channel.
We continue to see opportunities in automotive and semiconductor equipment as well as with our Focus Accounts. Revenues in orders are up 50% and 43% respectively from the September quarter last year. So, overall relative to a year ago, this market is still very strong.
Orders from our Focus Accounts grew 3% sequentially versus the June quarter and were up 55% from the prior year, well above the growth rate for the total company. These AD [ph] accounts now represent 30% of total Molex orders. We increased the program by 26 accounts this year to further develop our focus markets and find new opportunities for growth. This quarters success represents another step forward in the success of this program.
As we move into the December quarter, we see strong activity in mobile phones and smartphones, a modest level of inventory in the info tech sector, which needs to be burned off, a slight pause in networking and a good, but not great, Christmas season developing for consumer goods.
This leads us to conclude that the December quarter will be the lull and normal season average in terms of sequential growth, but still at a very positive level relative to the prior year.
Our expectation is that bookings will be relatively flat from this point forward through Chinese New Year and based on discussions with our end customers, well then pick up as we move into calendar year 11.
Let me now turn the call over to Dave Johnson, our CFO, who will give you greater details on the financial numbers that weve released.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Martin. Please turn to slide seven, which details our key income statement items. As promised previously, this information is only shown on a GAAP basis beginning with this quarter and going forward. The elements that previously were excluded f
componenttext:
Thank you, Martin. Please turn to slide seven, which details our key income statement items. As promised previously, this information is only shown on a GAAP basis beginning with this quarter and going forward. The elements that previously were excluded for non-GAAP reporting, specifically restructuring and unauthorized activities in Japan are separately listed on the statement so that you can easily compare the period shown. Both revenue and gross profit were all-time records for Molex.
On an organic basis, excluding the impact of foreign currency translation, revenue was up 5% sequentially and 32% year-over-year. SG&A decreased in absolute dollars by $1.6 million sequentially and excluding the impact of foreign currency translation, SG&A decreased by $2.4 million. The unauthorized activities in Japan for September and June 2010 related to investigation and litigation costs.
The $5.5 million expense for the September quarter or $0.02 per share was higher than anticipated, but included all costs to wrap up the investigation phase. We are now moving into the litigation phase.
Looking ahead to the next quarter, we should expect the Japan litigation costs to be roughly half of the $5.5 million amount that we incurred in the September quarter.
The other noteworthy item in the P&L is other expense. This includes equity income and minority investments offset by a foreign exchange loss in the quarter. For the coming quarter, you should assume that this will be other income in the range of $3 million to $5 million and this is a result of the operational results of our equity investments, which are improving.
Our effective tax rate for the quarter was 32.2%. This includes the tax charge of $2.3 million or $0.01 per share, which is due to options that expired under water for which we had previously recognized the tax deduction. Without this charge, our effective tax rate would have been right at 30%.
Finally, we reported record net income of $75.1 million and record earnings per share of $0.43.
Page eight summarizes our balance sheet metrics. Net cash of $73 million reflects a reduction in cash to build our inventory for the conversion from air to sea shipments, also the payment of severance related to our restructuring program, as well as the higher than normal capital expenditure level, driven by new product releases and capital constraints.
I mentioned at our September 9th Analyst Meeting that positive free cash flow generation would begin in the second quarter, and were on track as planned to generate free cash flow, roughly equal to net income going forward. Because of our confidence in generating positive free cash flow, we have increased our dividend by almost 15% to an amount approximating $30 million per quarter.
I would also like to mention that during the quarter, we expanded our revolving credit facility by bringing in three additional banks and increasing the size of the facility to $270 million. At the end of the quarter, we had a $110 million drawn, and therefore, $160 million available under this facility.
The progress toward our 14% operating margin is shown on page nine. Our gross margin improved 70 basis points in the quarter to 30.6%. We reduced our freight expenses from the high level reported in the June quarter, but much of this benefit was offset by higher commodity costs and the impact of foreign currencies.
Commodities and currencies decreased our gross profit by $6 million sequentially after several quarters of nominal impact on these items. The two commodities that impact us the most are gold and copper, both of which increased throughout the quarter and have continued to increase up till the present time.
We have begun to benefit from the hedges, we put in place at the beginning of the quarter for gold and copper, but the hedge benefits are included in the sequential costs that I just mentioned.
With respect to foreign currencies, we net the translation impact, which is positive with a weaker dollar with the transaction impact, which for us is generally a negative with weaker dollar. The weakness of the U.S. dollar versus the yen, in particular, impacted us in the quarter, as for example, we manufacture in Japan, export to Hong Kong and sell into China in U.S. dollar.
We have modeled the impact of both commodities and currencies thus far in the second quarter and expect to have a similar sequential headwind in Q2, as we experienced in Q1 for these items.
SG&A at 17.5% reached an all-time low and exceeded our target goal of 18% for the first time. Looking forward, merit increases which went into effect on October 1 will increase salaries and wages by $4.2 million per quarter of which approximately $2.5 million are related to the SG&A line.
Of course, the ultimate goal is to improve our operating margin. We have steadily increased this metric from 6.8% a year ago to $12.5% in the current quarter. Note that the four previous quarters are adjusted for restructuring in Japan costs, but the current quarter includes a $5.5 million Japanese investigation litigation costs, which reduces the operating margin by 60 basis points.
I think it is also helpful to look back to the period before the downturn. In the June quarter of 2008, at our previous peak of $872 million in revenue our operating margin was 11.3%. We are well above that level today and progressing toward our 14% target.
We continue to show good progress in return on net assets trend, which is depicted on page 10. Despite the higher than usual inventory and capital expenditure levels, our return on net assets surpassed 19% and continues to move rapidly higher approaching our fiscal 2011 target of 20% to 25%.
Finally on page 11, we set forth our guidance for the December quarter. Consideration of the sequential falling of our bookings in the first quarter and the continued uncertainty in the global economic outlook, we have set the midpoint of our guidance to reflect a 3% sequential decline in revenue from the record level reported in the first quarter.
Our outlook for the quarter, therefore is revenue in the range of $850 million to $890 million with EPS in the range of $0.38 to $0.44. As noted on the chart, this assumes an effective tax rate of 30% and no change in foreign currency rates in commodity prices from todays levels.
In conclusion, we are pleased with our progress in revenue, EPS and SG&A spending, all achieving new records. Gross margin continues to be a challenge for us, especially with the headwinds caused by recent currency and commodity price volatility.
However, we are intensely focused on achieving our 14% operating margin target through improvements to our global logistics operations, implementing more effective pricing strategies and mitigating the currency and commodity volatility through our hedging activities.
This concludes our prepared remarks and we will now open up the call for questions.

componenttext: Just to talk about the pricing situation youre right, we have rolled out this new pricing approach using (inaudible) is being rolled out in the current quarter, and we would expect to see the benefit of that in Q3 and Q4 primarily. I guess the other interesting thing just as you brought up pricing, I think one important thing in the pricing area is as you know we track our price erosion pretty closely and price erosion in the quarter actually was relatively low. We took about a 3% to 5% range. It was at the low-end of the range. So I think that is helpful as we move forward as will be hopefully that the price increases that we think well see benefit also in Q3.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Its interesting that I just spent the last three weeks actually on the road doing new product reviews in our divisions and also visiting a number of our major customers. It varies a lot by customer, but you read a lot I think about in the summer, about
componenttext:
Its interesting that I just spent the last three weeks actually on the road doing new product reviews in our divisions and also visiting a number of our major customers. It varies a lot by customer, but you read a lot I think about in the summer, about some of the components shortages that existed, and in some sectors it appears that customers over ordered based on not being able to get product, and now they have more inventories than there end demand is going to use up and particularly in the last quarter. So I think that slowed down orders.
But when I talk to those companies, they are very confident about long-term end-demand and then they see this as an issue to burn through the inventory, particularly with kind of year-end capital spending. So, our expectation is as the bookings in that sector are going to be flat through the end of the year, perhaps through Chinese New Year it would pick up from there. I would say the bigger impact probably been in networking and storage, which is sort of notebook and server markets.

componenttext: Hi, thanks for taking my question. Can you just give us some more color there in terms of whether theres inventory or whether its early signs that end-demand isnt flowing through like it normally is?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, its a great question. Honestly there is a number of moving factors here that we are trying to reconcile ourselves. Obviously, the concerns about consumer spending in North America and Europe are very well publicized and I think there is concern
componenttext:
Steve, its a great question. Honestly there is a number of moving factors here that we are trying to reconcile ourselves. Obviously, the concerns about consumer spending in North America and Europe are very well publicized and I think there is concern about how strong the Christmas season will be here.
The other side of the fence is that you go to Asia and consumer spending there is relatively strong and there seems to be primarily strong demand that the Chinese consumer seems to be very focused on brand-named. So the growth of that market, it tends to be best for the well known global brands where obviously we are well designed in.
So as you saw with our results, our consumer revenues were pretty good last quarter. We would typically see those bookings start to slow down because if its not ordered now, obviously, were not going to ship that in time for the consumer build season because people have got to build those products and get them into the market. So, our sense is that the Europe, North America will be weaker, Asia is pretty strong, and we kind of even build that out to say, it would be sort of flat going into this Christmas.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe if I could follow-up on that same point. As we look into orders shifting more the Asia regions and potentially the Chinese New Year season, how do you expect sort of the bookings and revenues to trend in a normal environment going into the fiscal th
componenttext: Maybe if I could follow-up on that same point. As we look into orders shifting more the Asia regions and potentially the Chinese New Year season, how do you expect sort of the bookings and revenues to trend in a normal environment going into the fiscal third quarter?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: We havent obviously, given any guidance sort of relative to the third quarter. What I would say is that Q1 is typically back-end loaded and that happens because September was clearly the strongest month and bookings have continued to be strong in Octob
componenttext:
We havent obviously, given any guidance sort of relative to the third quarter. What I would say is that Q1 is typically back-end loaded and that happens because September was clearly the strongest month and bookings have continued to be strong in October. This quarter is normally front-end loaded. And then I think what happens in Q3 just looking back over the last 10 years is it depends largely around how inventory we come out of Christmas with.
Weve seen here weve come out of Christmas with limited inventory and things pick up very quickly with the poorest for Chinese New Year, with customers asking to keep plants opened over Chinese New Year and weve seen the opposite extreme, where there is high inventory and people asking us not to keep the plants open. I think the good news though is that people seem to imagine the supply chain very tightly. And so I think the likelihood is coming out of Christmas with a huge inventory bubble is very slim.

componenttextpreview: Hi, yes, thanks. So Martin and Dave, just a couple of question regarding the margins. You talked about some of the headwinds on the materials cost, also some of the issues that you had in the supply chain in Europe. How much is left in terms of those s
componenttext: Hi, yes, thanks. So Martin and Dave, just a couple of question regarding the margins. You talked about some of the headwinds on the materials cost, also some of the issues that you had in the supply chain in Europe. How much is left in terms of those savings or the cost that you need to work off in terms of your supply chain issues in Europe?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me tell you in Europe, the biggest thing that we did in Europe was that we have put in place an automotive distribution center that is now up and running and doing quite well. I guess, when you look at the overall dollar impact of freights, we ac
componenttext:
Yes, let me tell you in Europe, the biggest thing that we did in Europe was that we have put in place an automotive distribution center that is now up and running and doing quite well. I guess, when you look at the overall dollar impact of freights, we actually were able to reduce our freight by almost $6 million in this quarter sequentially. So, we did see some very good improvement in that area.
Longer term, of course, and the reason why our inventory is building is because we are converting from air freight to sea freight and we have gotten probably about 65% of that converted as of the first quarter. We expect to convert that to maybe 80% to 90% by the end of the second quarter, with the goal of being at 95% in the third quarter. So, that is where were focused. Weve been making very good progress and I think were on track for that.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: So if you look at the absolute gross margin, you talked about some headwind on the commodity side, all things being equal and given that you still have some room to improve with those European issues, do you expect gross margin to be up next quarter or do
componenttext: So if you look at the absolute gross margin, you talked about some headwind on the commodity side, all things being equal and given that you still have some room to improve with those European issues, do you expect gross margin to be up next quarter or down again because of the lower volumes?

componenttext: I think if you model our guidance that will imply a sequential reduction in gross margin because of the reduction in volume. Our revenue at this level is down about almost $30 million.

componenttextpreview: And then just a question regarding some product shifts and Martin, you talked a lot about the opportunities in the Tablet PC arena. If you look at that market and the dollar content and your opportunities there versus notebook and as we see a shift from e
componenttext: And then just a question regarding some product shifts and Martin, you talked a lot about the opportunities in the Tablet PC arena. If you look at that market and the dollar content and your opportunities there versus notebook and as we see a shift from either Netbooks to Notebooks, is that a positive for you or negative, when you look at dollar content and if you look at the connector content and those types of products?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think for us I would view it as a positive in that. As you know one of our strength as all of the micro miniature products that come out of our Japanese operation. Frankly, I was surprised when we went through their new product pipeline there, how many
componenttext:
I think for us I would view it as a positive in that. As you know one of our strength as all of the micro miniature products that come out of our Japanese operation. Frankly, I was surprised when we went through their new product pipeline there, how many different programs they were involved in and I think a lot of them, the notebook content has been commoditized over time. We have a strong position I think in terms of the microprocessor sockets there and the IOs.
I think when you look at the tablet computers its good for us in terms of all the micro miniature products that are used in that and I think our share of that market could well be higher because of our strength in that technology.
