componenttext: Yes, sure. Its a great question, obviously not an easy one to answer, but I think our view is that the smartphone market is probably going to be the strongest as we go into the December quarter, given what weve seen in terms of order trends. Our view is that the automotive market is pretty stable right now and probably around that midpoint. Our sense is that consumer will be around that midpoint or slightly better. I think the weak area for us is probably in the info tech market, particularly in networking and places like that would be weaker end segment.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just one follow-up pass for Dave. Just on the balance sheet, it looks like receivables grew somewhat faster than your sales growth this quarter, and also with respect to inventory days, it looks like we saw a pretty dramatic jump and I think you
componenttext: And then just one follow-up pass for Dave. Just on the balance sheet, it looks like receivables grew somewhat faster than your sales growth this quarter, and also with respect to inventory days, it looks like we saw a pretty dramatic jump and I think youve explained part of that due to the this mixture with sea freight, how should we think as we look forward for where your inventory days trend, and if you could just shed some color in terms of what happen with receivable days in the quarter?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just mention the first fact that the exchange also has a very big impact on our balance sheet translation. Our inventory, $20 million of the increase in inventory was due just to exchange and $30 million of the increase in receivables was due to ex
componenttext:
Let me just mention the first fact that the exchange also has a very big impact on our balance sheet translation. Our inventory, $20 million of the increase in inventory was due just to exchange and $30 million of the increase in receivables was due to exchange. Thats a big portion of the increase in receivables, thats why the days in receivables really havent changed. And Id say I wouldnt read much into the change in receivables other than as Martin pointed out, our sales and our business continues to grow in Asia where we have longer terms to our customers and thats what driving that. So, receivables I think is still in very good shape. Exchange was the biggest factor for the period of time.
In terms of inventory, theres really two things that have affected that over the last couple of quarters. Number one what you talked a lot about is just the completion of the restructuring and moving production to new locations, and the buildup of inventory to handle that, we are still going through some of that. So that is one of the factors. This very deliberate air to sea shipment process, which is paying dividends already, is increasing our inventory.
To give you just maybe a sense of that, Ill give you a couple of numbers. Our in-transit inventory, that is the inventory that is on its way either in air on the shipment at the end of the period, is at the end of this quarter was $72 million. A year ago it was about half that level, which gives you a good indication of that. I guess other comments we talked often about the VMI, the Vendor Managed Inventory, hub inventory that is our inventory thats on consignment, that inventory has not increased. That is down, still below 30 days and is in quite good control. Anyway, thats just some color on the inventory side.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: So should we expect inventory days to remain this mid-80 day range?
componenttext: So should we expect inventory days to remain this mid-80 day range?

componenttextpreview: If you remember from our Investor Day, we had talked about 80 days was this years level. It should come down from the level it is today, but I would model it down to about 80 days for the balance of the year. This quarter still, I dont know were
componenttext: If you remember from our Investor Day, we had talked about 80 days was this years level. It should come down from the level it is today, but I would model it down to about 80 days for the balance of the year. This quarter still, I dont know were still so focused on this air to sea transfer. I think it may come down a couple of days, but then trend toward 80 days in Q3 and Q4.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: Who is driving this push from air to sea? Are these your customers or youre doing yourself?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: We are doing it ourselves. And its largely around our automotive product just because the value, the weight ratio of those products is such that air freighting them is not cost -effective, and obviously, the cost of holding them inventory within the co
componenttext: We are doing it ourselves. And its largely around our automotive product just because the value, the weight ratio of those products is such that air freighting them is not cost -effective, and obviously, the cost of holding them inventory within the cost of money is a lot less than the air freight cost of shipping them. The other benefit in the automotive market is the demand is relatively predictable. So we have much longer-term full cost of the automotive customer. It allows you to bring the stuff in by sea and put buffer inventories in place and meet the end-customer demand.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

How do we think about auto in the December quarter typically, isnt it generally up versus kind of a weak September quarter?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, thats why I told that it was down 9% sequentially, but would probably get better in the December quarter, largely around the fact, I think the biggest impact there was in Europe where you had the big shutdowns during the summer holiday periods, an
componenttext: Yes, thats why I told that it was down 9% sequentially, but would probably get better in the December quarter, largely around the fact, I think the biggest impact there was in Europe where you had the big shutdowns during the summer holiday periods, and then youve obviously got a lot of new model launches that take places during the summer too. So our expectation is relative to the September quarter, it will get better and so youre probably flat and you shouldnt see a decline. So I think past marginally better than the midpoint, if were predicting a midpoint reduction overall, but somewhere around that level, but certainly better than it was. It was one of the negative factors in the semi dont see as a big negative factor going into December.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Martin isnt auto generally up in the December quarter?
componenttext: Martin isnt auto generally up in the December quarter?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Normally, it is. I think the one thing that is different there is that such a big part of it now is being driven by China demand. Its normally up in the December quarter because particularly North America and Europe buying Color for Christmas. I think
componenttext: Normally, it is. I think the one thing that is different there is that such a big part of it now is being driven by China demand. Its normally up in the December quarter because particularly North America and Europe buying Color for Christmas. I think that more likely would be a Chinese New Year phenomenal in Asia. So, thats the only factor Id say will be different. But youre absolutely right; seasonally normally December is a better quarter than the quarter thats just ended.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just finally, the Golden Week came earlier this year. Its more of a three-week holiday as we combine two holidays in China versus may be a one week holiday. It seems that orders were probably pulled into September quarter A, do you think thats true,
componenttext: Just finally, the Golden Week came earlier this year. Its more of a three-week holiday as we combine two holidays in China versus may be a one week holiday. It seems that orders were probably pulled into September quarter A, do you think thats true, and B, what type of an impact does it have on your December quarter outlook?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Obviously when you shut down for those Golden Week holidays, obviously a much lower global bookings during that period and then we sort of pick up to more normal daily run rates, when people came back to work at the end of September. So, I dont think a
componenttext: Obviously when you shut down for those Golden Week holidays, obviously a much lower global bookings during that period and then we sort of pick up to more normal daily run rates, when people came back to work at the end of September. So, I dont think any of the September bookings were a result of things being pulled forward as a result of that. The interesting thing is the run rate October is about the same level as in September. So Golden Week, at least impacted just a little bit over those days. I dont think it had an impact on the overall balance of the quarters.

componenttext: Great, thank you.

componenttext: And the next question will come from the line of Shawn Harrison, Longbow Research.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, good evening. The first question I just want to get back in terms of just commodities, $6 million headwind in the September quarter and incremental say $6 million along with FX this quarter. Do you think the price increases youre putting through th
componenttext: Hi, good evening. The first question I just want to get back in terms of just commodities, $6 million headwind in the September quarter and incremental say $6 million along with FX this quarter. Do you think the price increases youre putting through the market starting in a few weeks and rolling over the next say 90 to 180-days will be able to offset what you are seeing in terms of commodity increases, so that will get back to a net zero.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I cant answer that question, I think what it does do I think is that, I was actually looking at the New York Times last weekend and so that against the basket of global currencies. Now the U.S. dollar has declined about 16% in the last four months, and
componenttext:
I cant answer that question, I think what it does do I think is that, I was actually looking at the New York Times last weekend and so that against the basket of global currencies. Now the U.S. dollar has declined about 16% in the last four months, and I think what it does do is it gives us a lot more leverage to make those price increases stick.
What the net impact is I mean, what I look at our results of the last quarter, frankly I think were really pleased that our new model has worked very well and has got our SG&A down below our $0.18 goal, and we proved that at the level of revenues were at, we can hold up our cost at that level. I think the gross margin was not where we wanted to be and it was because of those currency and ForEx impact and it is interesting we went back to 2006, and looked at where they stood then. Had foreign currencies and the commodities stayed flat since we started our restructuring program, our gross margin this quarter were then 34.6%. Now thats not an excuse.
I think our restructuring was to give us a better cost structure. Now we know the pressure has got to be on the gross margin line and I think we attacked that through price increases, we attacked it by focusing old customers with better margins, which is a lot about what our Focus Account Program is and we attacked it through going after our logistics costs, which is also above the gross margin line. I dont think there is any silver bullet there, but I think weve demonstrated through the restructuring that we can get our fixed cost structure in line. Now weve got to go after the gross margin and the fact as we face today are very different a very different from what we faced in 06. But we are not giving up on getting that goal. It just means we have to do some different things and work harder at those to close that gap.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe I guess two brief follow-ups on other topics, just distribution, you saw orders decline but what was distribution sell-through of our product during the quarter across the product line? I guess in the October, did it mirrored that decline in orders
componenttext: Maybe I guess two brief follow-ups on other topics, just distribution, you saw orders decline but what was distribution sell-through of our product during the quarter across the product line? I guess in the October, did it mirrored that decline in orders that you witnessed at distribution or is it more just an inventory destock of Molex products?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: The latter. Distribution end sales were pretty strong and youre going to see the major distributors report their results obviously, and it was more an inventory adjustment versus a drop-off in POS. It was more a POP than a POS impact.
componenttext: The latter. Distribution end sales were pretty strong and youre going to see the major distributors report their results obviously, and it was more an inventory adjustment versus a drop-off in POS. It was more a POP than a POS impact.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: Do you think that was broad-based across connectors or was it more just specific product line that you were selling?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think broad-based across components, at least across our connector product range. There wasnt any specific product lines that we were looking at.
componenttext: I think broad-based across components, at least across our connector product range. There wasnt any specific product lines that we were looking at.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: The final question is for Dave. CapEx at 8% of sales this quarter, what should we target for the remainder of fiscal 11?
componenttext: The final question is for Dave. CapEx at 8% of sales this quarter, what should we target for the remainder of fiscal 11?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: We expect to bring that down to about the 7% level, not to our target yet of 6.5%, but about 7%. As we said, theres been a lot of new product releases that are obviously very positive for us. Thats the biggest driver, but also certain areas where we
componenttext: We expect to bring that down to about the 7% level, not to our target yet of 6.5%, but about 7%. As we said, theres been a lot of new product releases that are obviously very positive for us. Thats the biggest driver, but also certain areas where weve had to add capacity just because to catch up on our delivery. So, I would assume about 7% level for the rest of year.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you.
componenttext: Okay, thank you.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, good afternoon. Question on pricing, is there any way to put a timeline or qualify where you have the best opportunities to pass pricing through and where it is going to be more challenged and where you can do it sooner rather than later? You mentione
componenttext: Hi, good afternoon. Question on pricing, is there any way to put a timeline or qualify where you have the best opportunities to pass pricing through and where it is going to be more challenged and where you can do it sooner rather than later? You mentioned with your focus customers as being one area, but I was just curious so if you could just go through the list?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you look at the overall pricing picture, about as you know 26% of our sales is through distribution. We are contractually obligated to notify distributors of those price increases that data is all gone out and it would impact their backlog from Janua
componenttext: When you look at the overall pricing picture, about as you know 26% of our sales is through distribution. We are contractually obligated to notify distributors of those price increases that data is all gone out and it would impact their backlog from January 1, so orders that are shipped from that date are shipped at the new price. Also, customers that buy from our price book, which I would say, is another 25% are also impacted as the price book goes up. And then you got global customers, who have global pricing contracts and those obviously are negotiated as they come up for renewals, so you would see most of it during the second half of the fiscal year. So I think about it in those sectors and those kinds of timings.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: With those global contracts, youre saying youre confident that as the contracts roll over that you are able to pass it through or? I mean, youre talking about some of your largest customers, right?
componenttext: With those global contracts, youre saying youre confident that as the contracts roll over that you are able to pass it through or? I mean, youre talking about some of your largest customers, right?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it depends by customer and it depends by product line where we have a proprietary product that we are single source. Obviously, youve got much better leverage and I think where youve got very competitive end markets where there are multiple
componenttext: I think it depends by customer and it depends by product line where we have a proprietary product that we are single source. Obviously, youve got much better leverage and I think where youve got very competitive end markets where there are multiple sources where people are competing for market shares, its a lot more challenging. So thats why I think when someone says to you, what the end result of this going to be, its a very complex picture. But certainly there are lot of people who are out there today based on rising raw material costs, and raising labor rates in Asia, all talking about the same thing. So its not an environment where were the only people trying to do it.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great, thats very helpful. Thank you.
componenttext: Great, thats very helpful. Thank you.

componenttext: Thanks, Steve.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question will come from the line of Wamsi Mohan, Bank of America.
componenttext: And the next question will come from the line of Wamsi Mohan, Bank of America.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks a lot. My question is related to both gross margin and SG&A. On the higher revenues out of expected sort of better gross margins and slightly higher SG&A, but sort of the reserve happened in the quarter. So, can you rank order the puts and tak
componenttext: Yes, thanks a lot. My question is related to both gross margin and SG&A. On the higher revenues out of expected sort of better gross margins and slightly higher SG&A, but sort of the reserve happened in the quarter. So, can you rank order the puts and takes on gross margin and SG&A quarter-over-quarter from FX, moving from air to sea freight, volumes and perhaps other things that you might care to elaborate?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think your summary is correct, but I think I made the same comment to an earlier question and that is I think we were pleased with our SG&A, and I think weve proven that the new global structure we have in place and the restructuring weve done ena
componenttext:
I think your summary is correct, but I think I made the same comment to an earlier question and that is I think we were pleased with our SG&A, and I think weve proven that the new global structure we have in place and the restructuring weve done enabled us to hit the 18% goal that we established. But for the ForEx and the raw material costs, we would have hit the gross margin target too, but didnt do that this quarter, but were not using that as an excuse to say that doesnt mean were going to hit our 14% goal in the long run. It means that weve got to do some things differently I think to close the gap between the 30.5% were at now and the 32% target we would have been at.
As I mentioned, just to give you an order of magnitude, had ForEx and raw materials stayed where they were when we started the restructuring in 06 that gross margin this quarter would have been at 34.6%. In terms of rank ordering how we closed that gap I would say that short-term focusing on the logistics costs and operational efficiencies in our plants are the things that will benefit us the most in the current quarter. I would say the price increase would benefit us in Q3.
And then shifting out our customer mix and looking at some of the smaller fast-growing customers where perhaps the margin opportunities are better, which our focus account program is targeted at, is obviously something you see as you move into calendar year 11.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: The follow-up, did you see any purchasing either in distribution or three other channels ahead of your gross price increases in calendar of 3Q that could actually exacerbate the order slowdown later in 4Q?
componenttext: The follow-up, did you see any purchasing either in distribution or three other channels ahead of your gross price increases in calendar of 3Q that could actually exacerbate the order slowdown later in 4Q?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: None at all. I think I know a few analysts were concerned that we might in the September quarter see the impact of that. But actually I think given the inventory adjustment correction that was taking place in distribution that was a non-factor. And the di
componenttext: None at all. I think I know a few analysts were concerned that we might in the September quarter see the impact of that. But actually I think given the inventory adjustment correction that was taking place in distribution that was a non-factor. And the distribution channel is the only place you would see that.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks a lot.
componenttext: Okay, thanks a lot.

componenttext: Sure. The total increase is $4.2 million; that is our annual merit increase that we, as you know, didnt have the last year, and of that $2.5 million impacts SG&A and the balance is in cost of sales.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then a question on the revenue guidance yet again. Midpoints down 3%. In the past, I think that the typical seasonality has been up about 2%. And youve gone into which are the stronger and weaker end-markets so we get that. But the real question I
componenttext: And then a question on the revenue guidance yet again. Midpoints down 3%. In the past, I think that the typical seasonality has been up about 2%. And youve gone into which are the stronger and weaker end-markets so we get that. But the real question I have here is, is that typical seasonality of up 2% still the same or has something changed with regards to the balance of your end-markets or geographic dispersion of your sales that would have changed that?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think youre analysis that, we were backing it to same thing. I think if you look to the last 10 years, the average for the December quarter is up about 2%. I would say that the one factor that is different is if you looked at the bookings that w
componenttext:
Yes, I think youre analysis that, we were backing it to same thing. I think if you look to the last 10 years, the average for the December quarter is up about 2%. I would say that the one factor that is different is if you looked at the bookings that we had in the June quarter, which were an all-time record and were up almost 60% year-over-year, and where our revenues are now I think weve had an unusually high trend.
The other thing thats caused, you to look back at that 10 year period, you had some economic cycles that have kind of distorted where the seasonal trend will be. In total, we would have expected to see a slight decrease and we project bit prudently I think projected that based on what we saw in bookings trend over the last quarter.
Just seeing that like you see a 5% reduction in bookings, the biggest correlation with Molex generally is as weve looked over the years is sort of looking at what the trend is in bookings in the current quarter versus where revenues go in the next quarter. So, seeing the 5% reduction is why we felt that given the backlog we have to ship, we wouldnt see that bigger drop or why we felt we would down about 3%.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: The corollary here though is or the plug if you will is lead times. I would have imagined lead times came in the quarter in which case youd imagine bookings would decline holding everything else equal, did that not happen?
componenttext: The corollary here though is or the plug if you will is lead times. I would have imagined lead times came in the quarter in which case youd imagine bookings would decline holding everything else equal, did that not happen?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Lead times obviously, extended during the earlier part of the year from the February/March period through to about August/September and as you know one of the things that justifies that CapEx is the additional capacity we bought online and our lead t
componenttext: Yes. Lead times obviously, extended during the earlier part of the year from the February/March period through to about August/September and as you know one of the things that justifies that CapEx is the additional capacity we bought online and our lead times are actually coming down in our plums, youre not going to get orders for future shipments when people know the capacity is available.

componenttextpreview: All right, thank you.
componenttext: All right, thank you.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: And the next question will come from the line of Jim Suva, Citi.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. On the inventory question, I realized that you did have more sea shipment this year versus last year and FX, but your inventory did go up 156 year-over-year, 16% quarter-over-quarter and your sales is very different from that. So, can you maybe
componenttext:
Thank you. On the inventory question, I realized that you did have more sea shipment this year versus last year and FX, but your inventory did go up 156 year-over-year, 16% quarter-over-quarter and your sales is very different from that. So, can you maybe take another shot at bridging that gap?
And I guess the second subpart of that is, does Molex benefit from a higher gross margin from running a higher utilization rates, where at some point in the quarter, maybe its the December or March quarter, we would be looking at utilization rates coming back down, because it looks like based upon your inventory you are running things a little bit too hard?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of taking a shot at the year-over-year analysis. I dont have all that data in front of me. But again I would suggest that there is a component of that that is exchange that affects year-over-year even much more significant and not that I
componenttext: Yes, in terms of taking a shot at the year-over-year analysis. I dont have all that data in front of me. But again I would suggest that there is a component of that that is exchange that affects year-over-year even much more significant and not that I mentioned sequentially. We believe our inventory is higher than it should be. Im not suggesting that were going to be running at 85 days for long, but it is very important for us to be able to bring down our transportation cost after moving so much production especially to China and thats where the focus is to getting this transfer from air to sea. That is the main reason why the inventory is building up. In terms of the utilization rates

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of utilization, I think thats a great question, Jim and I would make two comments relative to that. First of all, its important to understand I think during this rapid recovery in the market, we have had a certain amount of production made
componenttext:
In terms of utilization, I think thats a great question, Jim and I would make two comments relative to that. First of all, its important to understand I think during this rapid recovery in the market, we have had a certain amount of production made on the outside, so its subcontracted to the end-user et cetera and we have also have about 25% of headcount around the world today, thats either temporary or contract labor.
So in the events, our revenues did picked down somewhat and our view right now is that we could see it stabilize somewhat on the current levels through Chinese New Year and based on interactions the customers expected to pickup from there if that could easily be absorbed in turn of firstly reducing temporary or contract labor we need to do that and then brining in-house things that we use on the outside.
The other thing is you all know as weve moved tremendous amount of production around the world and what weve seen to help this is the operational efficiencies in those plants has continued to increase. So, I dont think we would see a negative gross margin impact by any of the predicted revenue levels between now and Chinese New Year and certainly would pick up again from there based on normal trends.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: Yes, thanks, good afternoon, guys. Just a couple of questions. First I just want to clarify you guys are basically stating that you expect December quarter to be sub-seasonal because of inventory adjustments in the couple end-markets and then after that things should revert back to normal seasonality is that accurate?

componenttext: Yes, based on what we see today.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: So I guess my question really is youll have four or five quarters of better than seasonal dynamics essentially a year. Why do you think the adjustment will only be a one quarter-ish event not a multiple quarter event?
componenttext: So I guess my question really is youll have four or five quarters of better than seasonal dynamics essentially a year. Why do you think the adjustment will only be a one quarter-ish event not a multiple quarter event?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Because the reduction in bookings is been targeted in some specific end-markets and the key customers we talk to there, have told us that they have excess inventory in the supply chain, they expect to be burned off by the end of the year. A lot of that is
componenttext: Because the reduction in bookings is been targeted in some specific end-markets and the key customers we talk to there, have told us that they have excess inventory in the supply chain, they expect to be burned off by the end of the year. A lot of that is in the info tech capital equipment market. Weve also looked at our CRM pipeline of new projects coming in and if you look at the new products that are going to be released in the new year, were also confident that it will help with the revenue as well. So, its largely based on direct feedback from customers and our own confidence in our new product pipeline.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then a little margin stuff. Operating margin delta has been asked in a whole bunch of different ways, but just so I get this straight, to get from 12% margin that youre roughly guiding for September to call it 14%, 15%, its about $15 million to $20
componenttext: Then a little margin stuff. Operating margin delta has been asked in a whole bunch of different ways, but just so I get this straight, to get from 12% margin that youre roughly guiding for September to call it 14%, 15%, its about $15 million to $20 million operating income delta. Half of that is this logistics costs, the other half is commodities and FX, is that correct?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thats correct.
componenttext: Thats correct.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: How do you recover the commodity part, are you going to have to implement more price increases or how do you recover that $7 million, $8 million delta from the commodities that youre seeing right now?
componenttext: How do you recover the commodity part, are you going to have to implement more price increases or how do you recover that $7 million, $8 million delta from the commodities that youre seeing right now?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two ways, I think one obviously is through the price increase. The other one is obviously pricing them into new products that they released in the new year, and then lastly I think which is a longer-term impact is diversifying sales into the markets, wher
componenttext: Two ways, I think one obviously is through the price increase. The other one is obviously pricing them into new products that they released in the new year, and then lastly I think which is a longer-term impact is diversifying sales into the markets, where I think there is a better pricing opportunity.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Got it, thank you.
componenttext: Got it, thank you.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: Hey, guys, thanks a lot for squeezing me in. Many questions on inventory, let me take a shot at it too. So, would it be fair to say Asia is being impacted primarily by an inventory issue? North America and Europe has both inventory and demand problem. Is that a fair way to characterize?

componenttextpreview: In terms of impact on the end market?
componenttext: In terms of impact on the end market?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: Yes.

componenttext: I would say that there is an inventory issue primarily that we have seen in the info tech market that is largely impacting North American customers, but is also impacting EMS companies that are based in Asia.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Which are once again exposed with North American and European customers?
componenttext: Which are once again exposed with North American and European customers?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think both because I dont know the exact day and I dont think you have a good feel for this either. But obviously an increasing portion of info tech market of those CMs is going for consumption in Asia, but I think the matter in market versus t
componenttext: I think both because I dont know the exact day and I dont think you have a good feel for this either. But obviously an increasing portion of info tech market of those CMs is going for consumption in Asia, but I think the matter in market versus the consumer market, its predominantly U.S. driven.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: So it sounds like youre not blanket statements here, making very end-market specific statements and thats tied to certain geographies basically.
componenttext: So it sounds like youre not blanket statements here, making very end-market specific statements and thats tied to certain geographies basically.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think when I look across something we had six quarters in a row of very strong sequential bookings A 5% decline from record levels, we are not panicking about particularly given September picked up again and October seems to be going pretty well. Largel
componenttext: I think when I look across something we had six quarters in a row of very strong sequential bookings A 5% decline from record levels, we are not panicking about particularly given September picked up again and October seems to be going pretty well. Largely as you saw, it could be explained by some summer slowdowns and some specific end markets. So I think if business will continue at the current level, plus or minus a little bit, I dont see any big cause for panic about that and to expect that bookings will continue sequentially growing ahead of the previous six quarters on an organic basis is just not realistic.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: So, if you look at the past three months, was it in the month of September you really saw some of these things picking up? If you wouldve pick and choose, was it right from the beginning of the quarter you saw these trends, or do you think towards the end of the quarter you saw there was an increased perhaps hesitation from the channel to add-on?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: Interesting enough, in terms of seasonality, July was a pretty good month for bookings, August was the very weak month, which is why I think you saw a bigger impact in North America and Europe because somewhat that explained by the vacation period and also I think that the end-customers who are impacted the most, are in those two geographies and then September picked up again and then Octobers been very good.

componenttext: Finally, if I look at the DSTs, EMS and OEMs, can you talk maybe in terms of the appetite to build inventories? If you were to distinguish across these three guys, is there one versus the other in terms of kind of appetite for building inventories currently or destocking perhaps?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would make a general comment that I think compared to the days when the tech bubble burst, the whole electronic supply chain is far more disciplined about inventory management and you dont get the big bubbles build up that you used to have befor
componenttext:
Yes, I would make a general comment that I think compared to the days when the tech bubble burst, the whole electronic supply chain is far more disciplined about inventory management and you dont get the big bubbles build up that you used to have before and people correct very quickly, the moment they see the number of days increased.
I actually think looking back over the cycle weve been, distributors kind of overcorrected on the downside, they actually made the biggest corrections after Lehman Brothers who were bankrupted in the early part of 09 and then perhaps overcorrected on the upside. EMS companies, its more about actually getting components in place to meet end-customer demand and there where you see the fluctuation is when they are competing for market share versus end-customers. So, thats a very different picture that tends to be customer specific versus the distributors that are obviously managing their overall inventory portfolio.

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: .Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2010 Molex Inc. Earnings Conference Call. My name is Janeda, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for t
componenttext:
.
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2010 Molex Inc. Earnings Conference Call. My name is Janeda, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Mr. Steve Martens, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please proceed.

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Hello, everyone. Thanks for taking some time to join us today for our quarterly call. I'm joined on the call by Martin Slark, our CEO; Dave Johnson, our CFO; and Liam McCarthy, our COO. Please note that this call is being recorded and will be available fo
componenttext:
Hello, everyone. Thanks for taking some time to join us today for our quarterly call. I'm joined on the call by Martin Slark, our CEO; Dave Johnson, our CFO; and Liam McCarthy, our COO. Please note that this call is being recorded and will be available for replay by accessing the Investor Relations section of our website. Presentation materials are also available on the website. As usual, we'd like to limit this call to one hour. [Operator Instructions]
Before we turn our attention to the quarterly results, let's review our Safe Harbor Statements which are on Slides 1 and 2 of the presentation materials. During the course of this presentation, we will be providing forward-looking information and referring to non-GAAP measures. Please read carefully the Forward-Looking Statements section of our press release and Form 10-K for an understanding of the risks and uncertainties associated with forward-looking information and the reconciliation of non-GAAP measures to GAAP. And now, I'll turn the call to Martin.

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you again for joining our call, and thank you, Steve. Before we start the main call, I just wanted to give all of you a quick update on our situation in Japan. As you know, we announced publicly on April 9 that we recen
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you again for joining our call, and thank you, Steve. Before we start the main call, I just wanted to give all of you a quick update on our situation in Japan. As you know, we announced publicly on April 9 that we recently learned that Molex had been a victim of a fraud on the part of an individual in our Japanese subsidiary. We've engaged legal counsel, Jones Day, and they have in turn engaged forensic accountants, AlixPartners, to investigate this matter. Based on the investigators' input and written and oral statements from the individual involved, we believe that he forged documentation that enabled him to borrow money from Japanese banks in Molex Japan's name on an unauthorized basis and then conceal those transactions. We believe he used the unauthorized borrowings primarily to fund losses on unauthorized security trades, also made in Molex's name. At this point, we believe that the total amount involved in this fraud scheme is approximately $193.2 million, of which we have recognized a loss in the quarter of $31 million and disclosed a contingent liability of $162.2 million. The contingent liability represents the current balance of unauthorized borrowings at Molex Japan.
Since this matter is the subject of an ongoing investigation, we hope that you will understand that we will not be able to answer any questions on this call relating to this fraud. But we will certainly update you as soon as we have appropriate information to release. 
Now let's turn our attention on to the quarter's results. And if you could turn to Page 3, I'll start by talking about our order trend.
Overall bookings for the quarter were $838 million, up 8% sequentially and 77% year-over-year. Given that this comparison is to the low point of last year's downturn, we expected strong results. But these results are much stronger than our most optimistic projections. Excluding last year's downturn, our average sequential increase in bookings in Q3 versus Q2 is about 3% to 4% versus the 8% we saw this quarter. The ongoing recovery was clearly far more important than any seasonal factors this quarter. The year-over-year numbers were the strongest that I have ever seen in my career at Molex. And as you will hear shortly, our bookings strength was very broad-based. It's worth noting that our March monthly bookings were a new record for the company, and our April run rate is above the level that we have reported for Q3.
To date, we have not seen any evidence of double ordering, but we have some distributors trying to rebuild inventory, strong orders for new product launches at some customers and some building of inventory in preparation for a predicted stronger second half to this calendar year. And I'll give you a few more data points on your concerns perhaps in that area later in my presentation. Overall, our book-to-bill ratio for the quarter was a very strong 1.11. 
If you turn now to Page 4, I'll talk about the changes in our orders by industry segment for the March quarter. Our booking strength, as you can see from the chart, was very broad-based. The percent of our bookings now coming from focused accounts is over 26% of the total. This is further evidence of the success of our focused account program, which is helping both our growth and our margins. Automotive bookings were up 8% sequentially and 80% year-over-year. We continue to benefit from incentive schemes in Japan and from some countries in Europe. Although, as I'm sure you know, the incentive schemes have now stopped in Germany. In North America, Q1, we saw vehicle sales increase for the whole market by 16% to 2.545 million vehicles. Molex's order increase for the same period was up over 60%.
In China, Q1 calendar year '10 passenger car production was approximately 3.5 million vehicles, up 84% from a year ago. Molex's growth over the same period is up over 120%. We believe there's very strong evidence that we are gaining share to increase sales of standard products across multiple platforms, particularly in Asia. And with increasing electronic content, particularly in telematics and safety and convenience applications, we see plenty of opportunities for this growth to continue. Global vehicle production is predicted to increase 8% percent in calendar year '10 to 61.4 million vehicles, and a further 8% to 66.6 million in calendar year '11.
Automotive Group remains a very large connector market. And with our new structure and our global footprint, we believe we can continue to grow fast in the market and operate far more profitably than we had in the recent past. 
If you now look at the Data segment, we were up 3% sequentially and 81% year-over-year. Calendar year '10 Q1 is normally a weak quarter for the data markets because of a lull following strong calendar year-end hardware purchases. Many companies obviously have capital budgets that are structured on the calendar year basis. This lull did not happen this year. Networking was very strong. And particularly, we had strong orders coming from all of the market leaders in that segment, so it was broad-based even within the Networking segment.
The service sector continues to strengthen, and we are seeing strong growth from new products, particularly our new range of IC sockets. In storage, the migration to new protocols such as SAS 2.0 and 16 gigabit fiber channel is very positive for Molex with the strong product range that we have in that area. Notebooks were also strong, with bookings up over 90% for the quarter year-over-year, and across the entire data sector, we believe that our strong new product portfolio and the strength of our global sales team that is now selling our entire product range is really helping us to gain share in this segment as well. Telecom was up 5% sequentially and 67% year-over-year. The Smart phone sector continues to grow quickly, with Molex particularly benefiting from the Android platform sales. Mid-range was down this quarter but is expected to recover in Q4. Entry-level phones in emerging markets remained strong, but only increasingly supported by local manufacturers and gray market phones.
Overall cell phone shipments were up only 2% sequentially calendar year '10 versus Q4 calendar year '09, but Smart phones were up 15%. What's very obvious and has been very widely publicized is that the incremental revenue growth and profit opportunity in the cell phone market is clearly going to be in the cell phone segment where Molex is very strong. Overall, the market is expected to expand from 1.21 billion units in calendar year '09 to 1.4 billion units in calendar year '10. But some of the major manufacturers that we deal with in this segment are concerned about possible shortages of memory and LCD. If that happens, that obviously could limit the overall growth of the market.
If you look at the telecom equipment market, that was very, very strong last quarter, particularly with customers in Asia and customers supporting the Asian market. There are some players in both North America and Europe who have been very successful in Europe, and we have equally enjoyed that success with them. Migration to new platforms is really what is driving this, along with new product sales for Molex as a company.
Consumer Electronics was up 6% sequentially and 66% year-over-year. The growth here has been driven by consumers in Asia, particularly in the developing markets. Some particularly strong segments for us are the digital still camera market where a transition is taking place from digital still cameras to digital single-lens reflex cameras. The reason we bring up that particular difference is that if you look at the connector bond on the difference between DSC and DSLR is that the connector content is about 3x, and that obviously helps our sales in that segment. Flat-panel TVs where LED backlighting is becoming an increasing trend, obviously, also increases the content in those devices, and that has helped us. 3D TV is still small but is growing rapidly. The other good segments for us in the consumer market are the gaming market, where we are doing very well with all three of the major players, pachinko and e-readers.
Our Q3 Industrial bookings were up sequentially a very strong 20% and 80% year-over-year. And we actually had record bookings in March for the industrial sector. In a market that most people still think is generally weak, we are very excited to see such strong results from the Industrial segment. As we stated last quarter, we're starting to see the benefits of our Woodhead acquisition and the synergy with Molex where we're combining Woodhead's industrial experience with Molex's electronic technology. We've seen particularly strong growth in alternative energy markets, security networks, robotics and the semiconduction production equipment sectors. So we're really pleased to see this, and we're really pleased to see the benefit from our Woodhead acquisition coming through.
Finally, the medical and military markets, which are still small markets for Molex overall, we're up 15% sequentially but were up 188% year-over-year. We're seeing lots of new product wins in both sectors. We have very strong project pipeline in both sectors and we're really pleased to report that during the current quarter, one of the major military contractors named Molex as a preferred supplier. So you can expect to see us to continue to have growth in both of these sectors.
Please turn now to Page 5 where I'll talk about our order growth by channel and by geography. We saw strong growth across all channels, but distribution in EMS were much stronger than the OEM. It's worth noting that both of these channels made dramatic cutbacks in inventory levels in the same quarter last year. EMS did this because customers in some key segments took business back in-house to keep their own plants busy, and distributors' credit to them reacted very quickly so they slowed down their orders that they had placed on suppliers. We are seeing distributors continue to rebuild inventory levels to support increased end demand.
As I stated earlier, we've not seen any evidence of double ordering. But stronger end demand, slightly longer lead times and greater confidence in the back end of the year is obviously driving stronger orders than we expected. One data point here that might be helpful toward our analysts is that normally Molex has about 10% of its backlog, which is scheduled out beyond three months. At the end of March, that number had increased to 13%. So it's higher than normal. But as you can see, it's not materially higher, which gives us great confidence that our backlog is strong and it's certainly shippable. By geography, it should come as no surprise that the strongest year-over-year numbers came from Asia-Pacific sales. The surprise this quarter was the broad-based growth in all of our other regions and in particular, the strong sequential number in the Americas and Europe.
The sequential growth in the Americas was broad-based, and in Europe, it was driven primarily by industrial markets and by the automotive market.  APN, dominated by Japan, was sequentially the weakest, but saw a very good pickup at the end of the quarter as consumer customers started to launch new products for the current calendar year and the lead-in towards the selling season at the back end of the calendar year. By the end of this fiscal, I think it's worth pointing out that Molex will have more than 60% of its revenues coming from Asia, up from just 50% in fiscal year '07. I think that says a lot about the transitioning of the electronics industry to Asia and also the strong presence that Molex has in that very important end geography.
Now turning to Slide 6. Several of our key markets normally suffered in the March quarter. And looking back over the last couple of decades, we'd normally expect our third quarter revenue to be down sequentially 3% to 4%. That was clearly not the case this quarter as revenue increased 3.7% from the December quarter and almost 50% from the March quarter last year. This is the fourth consecutive quarter of improvement, and we are now just 13% below our peak of $872 million that was achieved in the June 2008 quarter. 
And finally now for me, if you turn to Page 7, I'll talk very briefly about the changes in our revenue by industry. As you can see on this chart, all of the markets improved substantially from the same quarter last year. On a sequential basis, the data, telecom and consumer markets were down between 1% and 2% from the December quarter, but that is much, much better than normal seasonality. Automotive was up 6% and Industrial was up 18%. Going forward, we expect to see the strongest sequential growth in the industrial market, as our growing market share in that segment continues. Consumer Electronics, Data and Telecom will exhibit above-average growth, and we expect Automotive could moderate somewhat, because clearly, some of the strength we've seen has been incentive-driven and the expectation is those incentives will be progressively withdrawn as they year continues. 
The June quarter is generally our strongest quarter of the year. And our order rates in April remain strong. We are, therefore, based on our March orders and the April trends we are seeing, providing a revenue guidance of $810 million to $830 million for the June quarter. 
Now let me turn the call over to Dave Johnson, who will take us through the finances in more detail.

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Martin. Please turn now to Slide 8 for our P&L summary. As Martin mentioned, we are very pleased with the revenue results of $756.3 million, which is well above the top end of our guidance and up sequentially in what was normally a down quarter
componenttext:
Thank you, Martin. Please turn now to Slide 8 for our P&L summary. As Martin mentioned, we are very pleased with the revenue results of $756.3 million, which is well above the top end of our guidance and up sequentially in what was normally a down quarter seasonally.
Gross margin of 31.2% reflects favorable product mix, better-than-expected savings from restructuring and the continuation of a very good operating leverage that we have seen coming out of the downturn. SG&A, at $156.4 million, is up sequentially due to R&D costs and variable selling costs, not due to general admin spending. I will skip over restructuring and our loss on unauthorized activities in Molex Japan since we'll cover these on the next slide. Other expense is up sequentially due to higher interest expense, which was $2.3 million for the quarter, and a $1.8 million investment loss primarily due to our 20% ownership share in a Singaporean company that we account for on the equity method. This company is going through its own restructuring activities, which resulted in a loss in that business for that quarter and may continue into the next quarter. The effective tax rate for the quarter was 30.5%, which takes us to net income of $23.8 million or $0.14 per share on 174.8 million shares outstanding. 
The chart on Page 9 is our GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation. As just mentioned, GAAP EPS was $0.14, to which we add back $0.04 for our restructuring program and $0.11 for the unauthorized activities in Molex Japan that Martin explained. This results in a non-GAAP earnings per share of $0.29. This is well above the midpoint of our previous guidance of $0.24, and it's the highest EPS that we have reported in six quarters.
The slide on Page 10 details our balance sheet metrics. Our net cash has dropped to $160 million from $207 million in the December quarter. This is due primarily to the cash impact of the unauthorized activities in Molex Japan, working capital requirements to support the recent growth in our business and higher capital expenditures. The higher CapEx is related to production tooling for significant new product introductions and select capacity increases for production machinery to keep up with the rapidly increasing demand from our customers.
As one would expect in this demand environment, both accounts receivable and inventory were increasing in absolute dollar terms. However, accounts receivable's days sales outstanding has come down from 76 days last quarter to 73 days this quarter. Going in the other direction, inventory days have increased from 74 days last quarter to 80 days this quarter. Inventory increased at the quarter-end to support the record level of bookings that we experienced in March and really due to the buffer inventories for the final stage of our product transfer activities in connection with our restructuring program. It's noteworthy that our vendor-managed inventory remains in very good shape at well below 30 days, and inventory at distributors has not yet increased above normal levels.
We have pulled together gross margin, SG&A and operating margin trends all on one chart on Page 11 primarily to demonstrate the progress we are making toward our goal of 14% operating margins. Gross margin has trended very well from a low of 18.5% a year ago to the current quarter of 31.2%. This really demonstrates the substantial operating leverage of our new cost structure even in the face of transition costs such as freight and duty that remain high and increasing commodity costs. We had better-than-expected cost savings resulting from our restructuring program, approximately $6 million in sequential savings in the quarter versus the $3 million that we had anticipated and most of these savings benefited the cost of sales line this quarter.
Price erosion was not a material factor in the quarter as we continue to see slight downward pressure on this metric, though still at the upper-end of our 3% to 5% annual expected range. SG&A, at 20.7%, reflects spending in absolute dollars of $156 million, which is approximately $4 million higher than anticipated. The much-faster-than-expected recovery in demand has resulted in higher spending for both R&D and variable selling costs, but administrative costs, which are all costs other than R&D and selling costs, actually declined sequentially.
In addition, it's interesting to note that the total SG&A salaries were flat sequentially. This demonstrates that the sequential increase in SG&A is clearly related to the non-people variable costs that I mentioned, which again is caused by the faster-than-expected recovery of our business. As year-over-year growth rates moderate, we expect these variable costs to stabilize.
Most importantly, our operating income margin has improved very steadily from the prior year to the current level of 10.5%, and we would expect a similar sequential increase in Q4 as we have seen in the past two quarters.
On Page 12, we showed a trend of our return on net assets metric or RONA, which increased from the low point of 3.7% in Q4 last year to 14.2% this quarter. This is the metric that, under our new division structure, we have introduced to monitor the overall progress of each division and business unit. This is intended to focus our operating units on the key factors that they can control to improve our return on assets, which are operating income, capital expenditure and working capital. Our internal goal has been to get back to 15% by the end of the year, and we are clearly on track to meet and exceed this number by the fourth quarter. 
Please turn to Slide 13. We are just one quarter away from the completion of our three-year restructuring program. We incurred $9 million in primarily cash charges in the quarter and expect to incur the final $11.5 million in Q4 to complete this $300 million project, which will result in annual savings of at least $205 million. As mentioned previously, we are very pleased to see savings brought forward into the third quarter from the fourth quarter. We had expected $3 million in sequential savings but actually recognized $6 million savings as I mentioned. This then leaves just $1 million of sequential savings for Q4 to get us to our full savings target, but we still expect some additional sequential savings in the first two quarters of fiscal year 2011.
We are down to one final plant closure in Slovakia. And then, of course, the completion and final setup and smooth transition of all the production transfers.
Our guidance for the coming quarter is shown on Slide 14. Based on our strong bookings and backlog position, we estimate that at the midpoint of our guidance, revenue is expected to increase by 8.4% to the range of $810 million to $830 million, as Martin mentioned. After eliminating the restructuring charge of $0.06, our non-GAAP EPS is expected to be in the range of $0.36 to $0.40. And it's important to note that this excludes any cost or charges related to the investigation process in Japan.
In summary, we had strong operating results for the quarter, and we are confident that we will continue to see improved operating results now in the fourth quarter. We will now open up the call for questions, and I would like to state, just once again, that we will not be able to answer any questions related to the fraud in Molex Japan due to the ongoing investigation.

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010

componenttext: Can you talk about the strength in the networking market? And specifically, I'm looking for company-specific. So that's a market thats been turning up, but just how your performance is relative to the overall market, and what that means for just new design win activity and customer penetration, et cetera?

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: As you probably know, I think that market has been generally strong in terms of end customers that we service. What was interesting this quarter was that we had very strong orders from all of the major players in that segment. We've adopted a policy in th
componenttext: As you probably know, I think that market has been generally strong in terms of end customers that we service. What was interesting this quarter was that we had very strong orders from all of the major players in that segment. We've adopted a policy in these calls of not naming specific customers, but I'm sure you know as well as I do who the major players are in that market. We have a good presence at all of those companies. And what's been interesting versus, say, two, three years ago, is the range of products that were selling into those companies, and we did some analysis internally, is significantly broader than it was three years ago. So as that segment has come back, we have not only benefited from the growth in the segment but increased penetration in that segment because of our broader product portfolio. We're doing very well in the integrated connector modules; we're doing very well in the fiber area; we're doing very well in the backplane market. And so I think the breadth of our product line has particularly benefited us in that segment.

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And if I could follow up on the margins. You mentioned that increased R&D investment. How should we think about more of the administrative costs? And as revenue growth continues to exceed expectations, how are you going to balance that with a focus on the
componenttext: And if I could follow up on the margins. You mentioned that increased R&D investment. How should we think about more of the administrative costs? And as revenue growth continues to exceed expectations, how are you going to balance that with a focus on the margins in OpEx?

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me take a stab and that, and then I think Dave can probably add some additional data points. I think the point we wanted to stress in the current quarter was that the increase in SG&A came from variable selling costs. And when you've got bookings grow
componenttext: Let me take a stab and that, and then I think Dave can probably add some additional data points. I think the point we wanted to stress in the current quarter was that the increase in SG&A came from variable selling costs. And when you've got bookings growing year-over-year by 77%, you can imagine what that does to things like sales commissions and things like that. We expect that we're going to continue to grow, but the year-over-year growth rate is not going to be at a 77% rate. So we expect those variable commissions, and we've modeled that out, will certainly slow down. And certainly, we've had an extraordinary amount of new product work going on and new product introductions. I think the R&D, hopefully, will continue to be strong. But we think we are very cappy [ph] with what we're doing with our new structure and the fact that we've been able to maintain our direct people costs, and the admin costs actually sequentially went down. So we think we'll be able to leverage that going forward. So think about that staying very flat and thinking about the variable costs starting to moderate as we move forward. Dave, do you want to add?

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And I would just say, specifically for the fourth quarter, I would expect our total SG&A to be at about the same level as it is this quarter, which reflects the continued spending in R&D and sales cost for the reasons that Martin mentioned.
componenttext: And I would just say, specifically for the fourth quarter, I would expect our total SG&A to be at about the same level as it is this quarter, which reflects the continued spending in R&D and sales cost for the reasons that Martin mentioned.

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And if I could just come back to the comment on R&D, increased investment there. How does that play into how you're thinking about your position within the connector market and potential for share gains as the recovery strengthens?
componenttext: And if I could just come back to the comment on R&D, increased investment there. How does that play into how you're thinking about your position within the connector market and potential for share gains as the recovery strengthens?

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I think, Craig, one of Molex's strategies has always been to reinvest aggressively back into the business and to launch a large number of new products. And we have preferred status with all of the industry leaders that we sell to, and we are a very strong
componenttext: I think, Craig, one of Molex's strategies has always been to reinvest aggressively back into the business and to launch a large number of new products. And we have preferred status with all of the industry leaders that we sell to, and we are a very strong organization, and we believe innovation is our strength. And so we don't intend to back off on that, and we think that's the best way that we can continue to gain share. And coming out of previous downturns, Molex has always grown faster than the market. And we think we are demonstrating that now and we're very confident in our ability to continue to do it, but you do it through new products. And that's why you're seeing us make the investment.

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010

componenttextpreview: Not much of a change. Since the last quarter, the average increase in the cost of copper is up about 8%, and gold is up just under 1%. So we said last time that the Q1 impact would be about $1 million, and this is Q1 2011 of course. And then the Q2 impa
componenttext: Not much of a change. Since the last quarter, the average increase in the cost of copper is up about 8%, and gold is up just under 1%. So we said last time that the Q1 impact would be about $1 million, and this is Q1 2011 of course. And then the Q2 impact next December would be another about $1.5 million. Those numbers will be up slightly because the prices have gone up slightly, but not materially different from that.

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just as a follow-up. I wanted to ask about the M&A strategy. I didn't hear you talk about that. I guess the specific question is with the additional liability on the books now, does that change the thought process behind M&A strategy?
componenttext: And then just as a follow-up. I wanted to ask about the M&A strategy. I didn't hear you talk about that. I guess the specific question is with the additional liability on the books now, does that change the thought process behind M&A strategy?

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: No. And I think if you look under any scenario that you want to project based on the issues we're facing, we continue to have, relative to the industry, a very, very strong balance sheet. As you know, we did three acquisitions last fiscal year. We continu
componenttext: No. And I think if you look under any scenario that you want to project based on the issues we're facing, we continue to have, relative to the industry, a very, very strong balance sheet. As you know, we did three acquisitions last fiscal year. We continue to have a good pipeline there. Many of the companies are family-owned, so the timing of those acquisitions, I think, is hard to predict. But certainly, if we see opportunities that are strategically good fits for us, and we've said we wanted to focus on the RF area, the medical market and potential backward integration for our cable assembly business. As we see good opportunities there, we will continue to pursue them.

componenttextpreview: If you look at Molex's history, generally speaking, from Q3 to Q4, the sequential increase in revenue is about 8%. And we're obviously expecting it'll be much stronger than that. And I think the industrial, we believe, based on the gains we're seeing ther
componenttext: If you look at Molex's history, generally speaking, from Q3 to Q4, the sequential increase in revenue is about 8%. And we're obviously expecting it'll be much stronger than that. And I think the industrial, we believe, based on the gains we're seeing there would be the strongest of that group.

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And just finally, you've had a huge rebound now in sales. It's probably fair to say that you're gaining market share. Do you feel like that's a correct statement, and if so, where do you think it's coming from?
componenttext: And just finally, you've had a huge rebound now in sales. It's probably fair to say that you're gaining market share. Do you feel like that's a correct statement, and if so, where do you think it's coming from?

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it is fair to say, when I look at the year-over-year rebound in our business, I think it is fair to say we are gaining share. And I think we've highlighted which markets they were in. And I think -- we think in the industrial market where we histo
componenttext: I think it is fair to say, when I look at the year-over-year rebound in our business, I think it is fair to say we are gaining share. And I think we've highlighted which markets they were in. And I think -- we think in the industrial market where we historically weren't a big player, I think we're doing very well in that market. And I think the new product launches we have had in the data and consumer markets have helped us as well. I think the automotive market, it's hard to tell, because it's hard to see the impact of the incentives there. But we certainly think that as the automotive market has shifted to Asia and as you know, China is now producing more cars than there are in North America, our strong presence in Asia benefits us there. I think if you're asking the question how are we doing versus our competitors, I think one of the things that came out of this downturn is that some of the smaller players, and there are 2,000 connector companies around the world, have financially found it tough to get through that downturn. And I think the major customers continue to reduce their supply base. So I think if you're a major global supplier, you have the chance to gain share at those customers, and I think Molex is doing that.

componenttext: It amazes me that I think three years ago, when we started our restructuring, we talked about where we wanted to get to. And I think we're now in sight of getting to those numbers and doing what we said we would do. And the first question for an analyst is where do you go beyond that? I think let's just get to our target, first of all. I think we believe that we're improving our operating numbers because we've made some significant structural changes to the company, and we think we can certainly operate more effectively going forward, both in terms of sales growth and in terms of margins. I think we should focus on getting to our target numbers first and then we'll talk about where we go from there.

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I'd rather not give too much detail about where those accounts are and who they are. I will tell they are spread across all of our end markets, with the exception of automotive and consumer. Because we are already very strong in both of those markets and
componenttext: I'd rather not give too much detail about where those accounts are and who they are. I will tell they are spread across all of our end markets, with the exception of automotive and consumer. Because we are already very strong in both of those markets and the markets there are dominated by a small number of large companies. So the companies then are split, really, between the data markets and industrial markets, but more excitedly, I think in some of the emerging areas such as new energy, such as robotics and things like that. So we try to target solid-state lighting, some of the areas where we've historically not been a strong player in. And this is really what's helped us also in the medical and military markets. I'd say if you wanted a ballpark number on the industrial, probably makes up 10% to 12% of the group.

componenttext: Martin, you had mentioned when you were speaking about forward trends of the June quarter is typically, or has been often in the past, the best for Molex. So I'm just curious, was that just -- the intent of that comment just to kind of lay out typical seasonal trends? Or is there anything kind of in the bookings right now that would indicate that you do see a step-back in the September quarter, which is something that you have seen in...

headline: Molex Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think -- I'm not giving any sort of view relative to September. As I said, interestingly enough, one of the best analysis we did, because we had a lot of questions about had we seen any evidence of double ordering and things like that. So one of u
componenttext: I don't think -- I'm not giving any sort of view relative to September. As I said, interestingly enough, one of the best analysis we did, because we had a lot of questions about had we seen any evidence of double ordering and things like that. So one of us announced [ph] is we would actually look to say how far out does our backlog go. And only about 10% of it goes out beyond the next three months. Typically, there's about 13% of it beyond that right now. So there's a little bit of forward ordering going on, but I wouldn't call that a large amount. I think it also reinforces the fact why we want to probably stick to quarterly guidance, because given how short-term the backlog is and how low the visibility in the electronics industry, it's hard to go out beyond that. Now normally speaking, June is normally our strongest quarter, going to the end of our fiscal year. And we obviously see the markets that are consumer-driven, ongoing strength into the first quarter of next year. And then I think what happens as you go into Christmas in Q1 next year depends a lot on consumer demand. But certainly, capital spending across industries where I think it seems a lot of companies have come of out this downturn flush with cash has driven a lot of purchase of data equipment. And consumer spending in Asia certainly seems to be very strong, and we're benefiting from both of those.
