headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the First Quarter 2011 Molex Inc. Earnings Conference Call. My name is Diana, and I will be the operator for today. [Operator Instructions] And as a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purp
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the First Quarter 2011 Molex Inc. Earnings Conference Call. My name is Diana, and I will be the operator for today. [Operator Instructions] And as a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Mr. Steve Martens, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please proceed.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Diana. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. I'm here today with Martin Slark, our CEO; and Dave Johnson, our CFO. Please note that this call is being recorded and will be available for replay by accessing the Investor R
componenttext:
Thank you, Diana. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. I'm here today with Martin Slark, our CEO; and Dave Johnson, our CFO. Please note that this call is being recorded and will be available for replay by accessing the Investor Relations section of our website. Presentation materials are also available on the website. As usual, we'd like to limit this call for one hour. [Operator Instructions] 
During the course of this presentation, we will be providing forward-looking information and referring to certain non-GAAP measures. Please read carefully the forward-looking statements section of our press release and Form 10-K for an understanding of the risks and uncertainties associated with forward-looking information and the reconciliation of non-GAAP measures to GAAP.
And now, I'll turn the call over to Martin.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve, and good afternoon, everybody. If you'd like to turn to Page 3, we've added a new slide to this quarter's deck where we've put in a one-page summary of what we think are the key points emerging from the quarter we just finished. The firs
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve, and good afternoon, everybody. If you'd like to turn to Page 3, we've added a new slide to this quarter's deck where we've put in a one-page summary of what we think are the key points emerging from the quarter we just finished. The first point I obviously want to talk about is the quick update on our unauthorized activities in Japan. As you already know, the unauthorized activity occurred many years ago. And we've restated our financial results in the June 10-K to reflect the liability to this unauthorized activity. During the quarter that was just completed, we were served notice of a lawsuit by the financial institution involved. We responded to this complaint, and we intend to vigorously defend our position that these loans were unauthorized. This matter is now subject to ongoing litigation. We can't provide additional details at this time or answer any more questions about this particular topic. 
Now we'd like to spend the rest of the call talking about our operating results. And we're very pleased to announce the fact that we had record revenues and earnings per share in the September quarter. Given where we were 18 months ago, this is quite an accomplishment and obviously reflects good progress by the company and tremendous recovery in the electronics industry generally. 
Our orders declined from the record levels attained in the June quarter. However, we still had one of our best quarters ever for orders, and our level of business activity certainly remains quite strong. During the quarter, we made progress reducing our unusual logistics costs as well as improving production efficiencies on transferred production. Corrective actions to these items are largely a function of time: time to build inventory to fill ceilings and time for our manufacturing operations to learn the nuances of working with new equipment. We continue to improve in these areas, and we expect to see further progress in the December quarter. 
We also made progress reducing our backlog, which hit an all-time high in the June quarter due to the rapid recovery experienced over the last several quarters. Backlog was reduced by $28 million from the June levels as we brought online additional capacity. 
Finally, we announced the 15% increase in our dividend. We have a long-term commitment to our dividend. And given the increase in earnings potential of our new organization and the projected future cash flows, we are very comfortable increasing the payout at this time. 
If you turn now to Page 4, I'll talk a little bit about our revenue and order trend. Revenues for the September quarter were an all-time high of $898 million, 3% above the previous high reached in June of '08 and 6% above the June quarter and 33% above the same quarter last year. Even though orders declined 5% sequentially from the record set in the June quarter at $868 million, we achieved our third best quarter ever for new orders. And year-over-year orders were still up 20%, and all of that growth was organic. The order rate was slower during the early summer and strengthened during the September, and that strength has continued into October. While previous quarters were helped by incentives and inventory restocking, we believe that our current order rate is now more reflective of end demand. 
It's also worth noting that our bookings in the June quarter were up 9% sequentially and 58% year-over-year. So on a sequential basis, we're comparing ourselves to a record quarter. Given that the major economies in Europe and North America are recovering slowly, it's apparent that the emerging markets, particularly China, are driving most of the growth in the electronics sector. Disposable income in China increased by over 80% during the last 5 years. And this trend is expected to continue as the recovery becomes more consumption-oriented and less dependent on exports. This shift, coupled with the proliferation of mobile devices and related infrastructure and uptick in enterprise spending on tech hardware and many new product introductions, we believe will provide good opportunities to continue to grow our business as we move forward. 
If you turn now to Page 5, I'll talk a little bit about the order trend by channel and by geography. By channel, orders from distribution decreased by the largest amount, by about 12% from the June quarter. Distributors seem to have largely replenished their inventories, and in my own view, perhaps overcorrected on the downside of when the market took its plummet and about overcorrected on the upside, and they are now on the process of adjusting their inventory levels and their order rates accordingly. Orders from OEMs and EMS went only down by 2% and 3%, respectively. We reached -- as I said before, we achieved record orders in the June quarter, so a slight decrease, particularly in the OEM and EMS sectors, is really not surprising in the current quarter. 
By region, Europe decreased by 15% from the June rate largely due to the summer slowdown caused by vacations and holidays. Year-over-year, Europe was only up 8%, and that's largely because Europe benefited the most from stimuluses in the '09 period. Orders in the Americas declined 9% from June due to summer slowdown in July and August and due to lower orders primarily from distribution. 
Asia North increased from the June quarter by 6%. This reflects a strong consumer electronics market for us and strong demand for mobile phones and particularly smartphones. Asia South was down 4% from June, again largely due to seasonal slowdown in orders. But we saw that those orders were up 32% year-over-year, so our business level in Asia South remains very, very high. 64% of our total orders were from Asia in this quarter, and the percent of our business coming from Asia just continues to increase as we move forward. This is somewhat explained by the relative strength in markets where production is largely in Asia, mainly mobile phones, consumer electronics and infotech. It's also the result of increased consumer electronic devices in emerging markets -- increased consumption of those devices. It's worth noting that our orders in the Asia Pacific South region alone exceeded the total of our orders in North America and Europe combined in the last quarter. 
Now if you turn to Page 6, I'll talk a little bit about the change in our revenue and orders by end market. Revenues for the automotive market declined 4% sequentially, and orders declined 9% from the June quarter. This is not expected -- unexpected in that automotive production usually declines in the September quarter. On a geographic basis, we've seen favorable results in North America as the market seems to have stabilized and continues to rebound. September auto sales were the best in 13 months in North America, and it's worth noting that those records were achieved without incentives. And we're now on a run rate to sell about 12.2 million vehicles in North America. Europe slowed down in part due to the end of most of the stimulus packages across Europe, but also due to the summer holiday period, which probably has the biggest impact in Europe. We have also now fully evenly balanced between our automotive revenues in North America, Europe and Asia, that business being split 1/3, 1/3, 1/3. Going forward, we expect that North America and China will post the highest growth rates, while Europe and Japan will stay relatively flat. Longer term, we also believe that the increasing electronic content in vehicles will help to grow our automotive business. 
The data for infotech market performed as expected. Revenues increased 6%, while orders decreased 3% from the June quarter. Revenue increased in large part due to backlog reduction, while the decrease in orders is due to a small buildup in inventory in the supply chain. This inventory is very product and customer-specific and does not appear to be reflective of overall pullback in end market demand. If you recall, many of the large players in the infotech market were impacted by components shortages earlier this year. And at the same time, we're very optimistic that demand would be very strong in the second half and that they would all gain market share. Now that component shortages appear to have been resolved, there would appear to be a modest inventory buildup that is being worked through and we believe will be worked through by the end of the calendar year. Companies still need to upgrade their data centers and add capacity. And we think that, that underlying trend will provide ongoing good business as we move into 2011. We have also seen, just as an anecdote, tremendous interest in tablet computers. And I was recently visiting our operations in Japan. And looking at our customer  relationship module, it's interesting to note that we're actively working on 50 different tablet program computers -- tablet computer programs. It just shows the tremendous interest in that new format. 
If you look now on Page 6, I'll continue the commentary relative to the end market. The telecom market, which include infrastructure, networking as well as mobile phones, performed well overall, with revenues increasing 10% and orders decreasing 4% from the June quarter. Infrastructure revenue was down modestly. However, orders were down by 14%. This business tends to be very lumpy and chunky and has been very strong coming out of the downturn. We're now seeing a pause in the level of business activity. However, both revenue and orders are well above the prior year levels. 
Revenue and orders for the mobile phone submarket were very, very strong, 30% up sequentially and 20% -- 23% year-over-year. This is due in to a large number of new products being introduced and  continued shift to smartphones, as well as a strong seasonal influence. Looking ahead, there are many new products in the horizon for the mobile phone market, including HD screen, 4G devices and continued share gains for smartphones, as well as the introduction of Android and Windows 7-based devices. Many of the major OEMs are also doing a good job of penetrating new geographies with mobile phones. Overall, we believe that this trend will drive the need for infrastructure to support new devices as we move into calendar year '11. 
Despite what you read in the press, the consumer market, at least for us, has been quite strong. Revenues increased 12% for the June quarter and orders declined a modest 1%, which is below the normal seasonal trend that we would see. This is largely due to the number of new product introductions, backlog reductions and the strong influence of a pre-Christmas build. Even in these difficult times, consumers are choosing to spend their discretionary income on an interesting array of devices, which have increasing connective content. For example, LCD panels trends include now 3D technology, LED backlighting and an increasing use of these high-definition displays in public domains. While we do not know the exact percentage of end consumption in emerging markets, we do know that this percentage is increasing due to strong economic growth and  rise in consumers in the developing countries. This is a long-term trend, that coupled with a recovery in the economies of the developing countries and new product offerings, will drive growth in 2011 and beyond. 
Revenue in the industrial market increased 3% from the June quarter, while orders declined 8%. The reduction in orders from distributors had a profound impact on this market, and this is very much a high-mix, low-volume market where distribution is a significant channel. We continue to see opportunities in automotive and semiconductor equipment as well as with our Focus Accounts. Revenues in orders are up 50% and 43%, respectively, from the September quarter last year. So overall relative to a year ago, this market is still very strong. 
Orders from our Focus Accounts grew 3% sequentially versus the June quarter and were up 55% from the prior year, well above the growth rate for the total company. These AD accounts now represent 30% of total Molex orders. We increased the program by 26 accounts this year to further develop our focus markets and find new opportunities for growth. This quarter's success represents another step forward in the success of this program. 
As we move into the December quarter, we see strong activity in mobile phones and smartphones; a modest level of inventory in the infotech sector, which needs to be burned off; a slight pause in networking; and a good but not great Christmas season developing for consumer goods. This leads us to conclude that the December quarter will be below our normal seasonal average in terms of sequential growth, but still at a very positive level relative to the prior year. Our expectation is that bookings would be relatively flat from this point forward through Chinese New Year and, based on discussions with our end customers, will then pick up as we move into calendar year '11. 
Let me now turn the call over to Dave Johnson, our CFO, who will give you greater details on the financial numbers that we released.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Martin. Please turn to Slide 7, which details our key income statement items. As promised previously, this information is only shown on a GAAP basis beginning with this quarter and going forward. The elements that previously were excluded for n
componenttext:
Thank you, Martin. Please turn to Slide 7, which details our key income statement items. As promised previously, this information is only shown on a GAAP basis beginning with this quarter and going forward. The elements that previously were excluded for non-GAAP reporting, specifically restructuring and unauthorized activities in Japan, are separately listed on a statement so that you can easily compare the periods shown. 
Both revenue and gross profit were all-time records for Molex. On an organic basis, excluding the impact of foreign currency translation, revenue was up 5% sequentially and 32% year-over-year. SG&A decreased in absolute dollars by $1.6 million sequentially. And excluding the impact of foreign currency translation, SG&A decreased by $2.4 million. 
The unauthorized activities in Japan for September and June 2010 related to investigation and litigation costs. The $5.5 million expense for the September quarter, or at $0.02 per share, was higher than anticipated but included all costs to wrap up the investigation phase. We are now moving into the litigation phase. Looking ahead to the next quarter, we should expect the Japan litigation costs to be roughly half of the $5.5 million amount that we incurred in the September quarter. 
The other noteworthy item in the P&L is Other Expense. This includes equity income in minority investments, offset by a foreign exchange loss in the quarter. For the coming quarter, you should assume that this will be other income in the range of $3 million to $5 million, and this is a result of the operational results of our equity investments, which are improving. 
Our effective tax rate for the quarter was 32.2%. This includes the tax charge of $2.3 million or $0.01 per share, which is due to options that expired under water for which we had previously recognized the tax deduction. Without this charge, our effective tax rate would have been right at 30%. 
And finally, we reported net income, record net income of $75.1 million and a record earnings per share of $0.43. 
Page 8 summarizes our balance sheet metrics. Net cash of $73 million reflects a reduction in cash to build our inventory for the conversion from air to sea shipments, also the payment of severance related to our restructuring program, as well as a higher-than-normal capital expenditure level driven by new product releases and capital constraints. 
I mentioned at our September 9 Analyst Meeting that positive free cash flow generation would begin in the second quarter. And we are on track as planned to generate free cash flow roughly equal to net income going forward. And because of our confidence in generating positive free cash flow, we have increased our dividend by almost 15% to an amount approximating $30 million for the quarter. 
I would also like to mention that during the quarter, we expanded our revolving credit facility by bringing in 3 additional banks and increasing the size of the facility to $270 million. At the end of the quarter, we had $110 million drawn and therefore $160 million available under this facility. 
The progress toward our 14% operating margin is shown on Page 9. Our gross margin improved 70 basis points in the quarter to 30.6%. We reduced our freight expenses from the high level reported in the June quarter, but much of this benefit was offset by higher commodity costs and the impact of foreign currencies. Commodities and currencies decreased our gross profit by $6 million sequentially, after several quarters of nominal impact from these items. The 2 commodities that impact us the most are gold and copper, both of which increased throughout the quarter and have continued to increase after the present time. We have begun to benefit from the hedges we've put in place at the beginning of the quarter for gold and copper, but the hedge benefits are included in the sequential costs that I just mentioned. 
With respect to foreign currencies, we net the translation impact, which is positive with the weaker dollar; with the transaction impact, which for us is generally weaker -- a negative with the weaker dollar. The weakness of the U.S. dollar versus the yen in particular impacted us in the quarter as, for example, we manufacture in Japan, export to Hong Kong and sell into China in U.S. dollars. We have modeled the impact of both commodities and currencies thus far in the second quarter and expect to have a similar sequential headwind in Q2 as we experienced in Q1 for these items. 
SG&A at 17.5% reached an all-time low and exceeded our target goal of 18% for the first time. Looking forward, merit increases, which went into effect on October 1, will increase salaries and wages by $4.2 million per quarter, of which approximately $2.5 million are related to the SG&A line. 
Of course, the ultimate goal is to improve our operating margin. We have steadily increased this metric from 6.8% a year ago to 12.5% in the current quarter. Note that the 4 previous quarters are adjusted for restructuring and Japan costs. But the current quarter includes the $5.5 million Japanese investigation litigation costs, which reduces the operating margin by 60 basis points.  
I think it is also helpful to look back to the period before the downturn. In the June quarter of 2008 at our previous peak of $872 million in revenue, our operating margin was 11.3%. We are well above that level today and progressing toward our 14% target. 
We continue to show good progress in our return on net assets trend, which is depicted on Page 10. Despite the higher-than-usual inventory and capital expenditure level, our return on net assets surpassed 19% and continues to move rapidly higher, approaching our fiscal 2011 target of 20% to 25%. 
And finally on Page 11, we set forth our guidance for the December quarter. In consideration of the sequential swing [ph] of our bookings in the first quarter and the continued uncertainty in the global economic outlook, we have set the midpoint of our guidance to reflect a 3% sequential decline in revenue from the record level reported in the first quarter. Our outlook for the quarter, therefore, is revenue in the range of $850 to $890 million, with EPS in the range of $0.38 to $0.44. As noted on the chart, this assumes an effective tax rate of 30% and no change in foreign currency rates and commodity prices from today's levels. 
In conclusion, we are pleased with our progress in revenue, EPS and SG&A spending, all achieving new records. Gross margin continues to be a challenge for us, especially with the headwinds caused by recent currency and commodity price volatility. However, we are intently focused on achieving our 14% operating margin target through improvements to our global logistics operations, implementing more effective pricing strategies and mitigating the currency and commodity volatility through our hedging activities. 
This concludes our prepared remarks, and we will now open up the call for questions.

componenttext: Okay. And then as a follow-up. Just on pricing. Martin, at the Analyst Day, you discussed a new software program and pricing strategy. Any update there on where you are and as that gets rolled out over the next 6 to 12 months, the implications of that strategy?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Craig. I guess just to talk about the pricing situation, you're right. We have rolled out this new pricing approach using Vendavo. It's being rolled out in the current quarter. We will expect to see the benefit of that in Q3 and Q4 primarily. I gues
componenttext: Sure, Craig. I guess just to talk about the pricing situation, you're right. We have rolled out this new pricing approach using Vendavo. It's being rolled out in the current quarter. We will expect to see the benefit of that in Q3 and Q4 primarily. I guess the other interesting thing is that you brought up pricing. I think one important thing in the pricing area is as you know, we track our price erosion pretty closely. And price erosion in the quarter actually was relatively low. It was at -- we talked about a 3% to 5% range. It was at the low end of the range. And so I think that, that is helpful as we move forward as it will be hopefully that the price increases that we think we'll see the benefit often in Q3.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, and last  one if I could. You mentioned the inventory adjustment in the infotech area. Just as you meet with customers, Martin, just curious what the latest sentiment is in readthrough in terms of tech refresh end of the year and into next year.
componenttext: Okay, and last  one if I could. You mentioned the inventory adjustment in the infotech area. Just as you meet with customers, Martin, just curious what the latest sentiment is in readthrough in terms of tech refresh end of the year and into next year.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's interesting that I just spent the last 3 weeks actually on the road doing new product reviews in our division and also visiting a number of our major customers, and it varies a lot by customer. But you read a lot, I think, about in the summer about s
componenttext: It's interesting that I just spent the last 3 weeks actually on the road doing new product reviews in our division and also visiting a number of our major customers, and it varies a lot by customer. But you read a lot, I think, about in the summer about some of the components shortages that existed. And in some sectors, it appears that customers over-ordered based on not being able to get product and now have more inventory than they think end demand is going to use up, particularly in the last quarter. And so I think that slowed down orders. But when I talked to those companies, they are very confident about long-term end demand. And they see this as an issue to burn through the inventory, particularly with kind of year-end capital spending. So our expectation is that the bookings in that sector are going to be flat through the end of the year, perhaps to Chinese New Year. It will pick up from there. I would say the bigger impact has  probably been in networking and storage versus sort of notebook and server markets.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the consumer electronics market, maybe even more specifically looking at sort of television, gaming devices, I believe Martin made a comment about a good, not great holiday season. Can you just give us a more color there in terms of whether there's inv
componenttext: On the consumer electronics market, maybe even more specifically looking at sort of television, gaming devices, I believe Martin made a comment about a good, not great holiday season. Can you just give us a more color there in terms of whether there's inventory? Or whether its just early signs that end demand isn't flowing through like it normally is?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, it's a great question. Honestly, there's a number of moving factors here that we're trying to reconcile ourselves in that obviously the concerns about consumer spending in North America and Europe are very well publicized. And I think there is conc
componenttext: Steve, it's a great question. Honestly, there's a number of moving factors here that we're trying to reconcile ourselves in that obviously the concerns about consumer spending in North America and Europe are very well publicized. And I think there is concern about how strong the Christmas season will be here. The other side of the fence is that you go to Asia and consumer spending there is relatively strong. And there seems to be primarily strong demand that the Chinese consumer seems to be very focused on brand-name goods. And so the growth of that market, it tends to be best for the well-known global brands, where obviously we're well designed in. And so as you saw with our results, our consumer revenues were pretty good last quarter. We would typically see those bookings start to slow down because if it's not ordered now, obviously we're not going to ship it in time for the consumer build season, because people have caught up, build those products and get them into the market. So our sense is that Europe, North America will be weaker, Asia is pretty strong, and we kind of even build that out to say it would be sort of flat going into this Christmas.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And if I could, maybe a follow-up on that same point, as we look into orders shifting more to the Asia regions and potentially the Chinese New Year season, how do you expect sort of bookings and revenues to trend in a normal environment going into the fis
componenttext: And if I could, maybe a follow-up on that same point, as we look into orders shifting more to the Asia regions and potentially the Chinese New Year season, how do you expect sort of bookings and revenues to trend in a normal environment going into the fiscal third quarter?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we haven't obviously given any guidance relative to the third quarter. And what I would say is that Q1 is typically back-end loaded, and that happened because September was clearly the strongest month and bookings have continued to be strong in Octo
componenttext: Well, we haven't obviously given any guidance relative to the third quarter. And what I would say is that Q1 is typically back-end loaded, and that happened because September was clearly the strongest month and bookings have continued to be strong in October. This quarter is normally front-end loaded. And then I think what happens in Q3, just looking back over the last 10 years, it depends largely around how much inventory we come out at Christmas with. But we've seen years, we've come out at Christmas with limited inventory, and things picked up very quickly to the point [ph] that at Chinese New Year, with customers asking to keep plants open over Chinese New Year. And we've seen the opposite extreme where there is high inventory and people asking us not to keep the plants open. I think the good news though is that people seem to imagine the supply chain very tightly. And so I think the likelihood of coming out at Christmas with a huge inventory bubble is very slim.

componenttext: And your next question will come from the line of Matt Sheerin, Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: So Martin and Dave, just a couple of questions regarding the margins. You talked about some of the headwinds on the materials cost, also some of the issues that you had in the supply chain in Europe. How much is left in terms of those savings or the costs
componenttext: So Martin and Dave, just a couple of questions regarding the margins. You talked about some of the headwinds on the materials cost, also some of the issues that you had in the supply chain in Europe. How much is left in terms of those savings or the costs that you need to work off in terms of your supply chain issues in Europe?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me say in Europe, the biggest thing that we did in Europe was that we have put in place an automotive distribution center. That is now up and running and doing quite well. The -- I guess when we look at the overall dollar impact of freight, we ac
componenttext: Yes. Let me say in Europe, the biggest thing that we did in Europe was that we have put in place an automotive distribution center. That is now up and running and doing quite well. The -- I guess when we look at the overall dollar impact of freight, we actually were able to reduce our freight by almost $6 million in this quarter sequentially. So we did see some very good improvement in that area. Longer term, of course, our -- and the reason why our inventory is building is because we are converting from sea freight -- from air freight to sea freight, and we have gotten probably about 65% of that converted as of the first quarter. We expect to convert that to maybe 80% to 90% by the end of the second quarter, with the goal of being at 95% in the third quarter, so that is where we're focused. We've been making very good progress, and I think we're on track for that.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. But if you look at the absolute gross margin, you talked about some headwind on the commodities side. All things being equal, and given that you still have some room to improve with those European issues, do you expect gross margin to be up next qua
componenttext: Okay. But if you look at the absolute gross margin, you talked about some headwind on the commodities side. All things being equal, and given that you still have some room to improve with those European issues, do you expect gross margin to be up next quarter or down again because of the lower volumes?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think if you model our guidance, that will imply a sequential reduction in gross margin because of the reduction in volume. Our revenue at this level is down about almost $30 million.
componenttext: I think if you model our guidance, that will imply a sequential reduction in gross margin because of the reduction in volume. Our revenue at this level is down about almost $30 million.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Got you. And then just a question regarding some product shifts and, Martin, you talked a lot about the opportunities in the tablet PC arena. If you look at that market in the dollar content and your opportunities there versus notebook, and as we see a sh
componenttext: Got you. And then just a question regarding some product shifts and, Martin, you talked a lot about the opportunities in the tablet PC arena. If you look at that market in the dollar content and your opportunities there versus notebook, and as we see a shift from either netbooks to notebooks, is that a positive for you or negative when you look at dollar content and you look at the connector content in those types of products?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think for us, I would view it as a positive in that as you know, one of our strengths is all of the microminiature products that come out of our Japanese operations. And frankly, I was surprised when we went through the new product pipeline there, how m
componenttext: I think for us, I would view it as a positive in that as you know, one of our strengths is all of the microminiature products that come out of our Japanese operations. And frankly, I was surprised when we went through the new product pipeline there, how many different programs they were involved in. And I think a lot of the notebook content has been commoditized over time. We have a strong position, I think, in terms of the microprocessor sockets there and the I/Os. I think when you look at the tablet computers, it's good for us in terms of all the microminiature products that are used in that. And I think our share of that market could well be higher because of our strength in that technology.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question will come from the line of Amitabh Passi, UBS.
componenttext: And the next question will come from the line of Amitabh Passi, UBS.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Martin, if I look at the guidance for the December quarter, that's color for revenues down 2% to 3% at the midpoint. Are you able to give us any color how you expect your various end markets to sort of trend relative to the midpoint, which ones you feel b
componenttext: Martin, if I look at the guidance for the December quarter, that's color for revenues down 2% to 3% at the midpoint. Are you able to give us any color how you expect your various end markets to sort of trend relative to the midpoint, which ones you feel better about, which ones you think could perform slightly worse?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. It's a great question and obviously not an easy one to answer, but I think our view is that the cellphone market, the smartphone market is probably going to be the strongest as we go into the December quarter, given what we've seen in terms of
componenttext: Yes, sure. It's a great question and obviously not an easy one to answer, but I think our view is that the cellphone market, the smartphone market is probably going to be the strongest as we go into the December quarter, given what we've seen in terms of order trends. Our view is that the automotive market is pretty stable right now and probably around that midpoint. Our sense is that consumer will be around that midpoint or slightly better. I think that the weak area for us is probably in the infotech market, particularly in networking, and places like that would be the weaker end segment.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just for my follow-up pass for Dave, just around the balance sheet, it looks like receivables grew somewhat faster than your sales growth this quarter. And also with respect to inventory days, it looks like we saw a pretty dramatic jump. And I th
componenttext: And then just for my follow-up pass for Dave, just around the balance sheet, it looks like receivables grew somewhat faster than your sales growth this quarter. And also with respect to inventory days, it looks like we saw a pretty dramatic jump. And I think you explained part of that due to this mix term [ph] with sea freight. How should we think as we look forward for sort of where your inventory days trend? And if you could just shed some color in terms of what happened with receivable days in the quarter.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just mention the first fact that the exchange also has a very big impact on our balance sheet, the translation. Our inventory -- $20 million of the increase in inventory was due just to exchange. And $30 million of the increase in receivables was d
componenttext: Let me just mention the first fact that the exchange also has a very big impact on our balance sheet, the translation. Our inventory -- $20 million of the increase in inventory was due just to exchange. And $30 million of the increase in receivables was due to exchange. So that's why -- that's a big portion of the increase in receivables, that's why the days in receivables really haven't changed. And I'd say, I wouldn't read much into the change in receivables other than, as Martin pointed out, our sales and our business continues to grow in Asia, where we have longer terms to our customers, and that's what's driving that. So receivables I think is still in very good shape. Exchange was the biggest factor for that for the period of time. In terms of inventory, yes, there's really 2 things that have affected that over the last couple of quarters. Number one, which we've talked a lot about, is just the completion of the restructuring and moving production to new locations and the buildup of inventory to handle that. We are still going through some of that, so that is one of the factors. And this very deliberate air to sea shipment process, which is paying dividends already, is increasing our inventory. To give you just maybe a sense of that, I'll give you a couple of numbers. Our in-transit inventory, that is the inventory that is on its way either in air or on a shipment at the end of the period, is at the end of this quarter was $72 million. A year ago, it was about half that level, which gives you a good indication of that. I guess other comments we've talked often about, the VMI, the vendor-managed inventory, hub inventory that is -- our inventory that's on consignment. That inventory has not increased. That is down, still below 30 days and is in quite good control. Anyway that's just some color on the inventories side.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: So should we expect inventory days to remain this mid-80-day range?
componenttext: So should we expect inventory days to remain this mid-80-day range?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have said, if you remember from our Investor Day, we talked about 80 days was this year's level. It shouldn't stay at the -- it should come down from the level it is today, but I would model it down to about 80 days for the balance of the year. This qu
componenttext: We have said, if you remember from our Investor Day, we talked about 80 days was this year's level. It shouldn't stay at the -- it should come down from the level it is today, but I would model it down to about 80 days for the balance of the year. This quarter still, I don't know. We are still so focused on this air to sea transfer. I think it may come down a couple of days but then trend toward 80 days in Q3 and Q4.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question will come from the line of Brian White, Ticonderoga.
componenttext: And the next question will come from the line of Brian White, Ticonderoga.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Who is driving this push from air to sea? Are these your customers or you're doing it yourself?
componenttext: Yes. Who is driving this push from air to sea? Are these your customers or you're doing it yourself?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we are doing it ourselves. And it's largely around our automotive products just because the value, the weight ratio of those products is such that air freighting them is not cost-effective. And obviously, the cost of holding them in inventory, given
componenttext: Well, we are doing it ourselves. And it's largely around our automotive products just because the value, the weight ratio of those products is such that air freighting them is not cost-effective. And obviously, the cost of holding them in inventory, given the cost of money, is a lot less than the air freight cost of shipping. The other benefit in the automotive market is that demand is relatively predictable so allows you -- we have much longer-term full costs, the automotive costs, it allows you to bring the stuff in by sea and put buffer inventories in place and meet the end customer demand.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just looks like orders for Auto were down 9%. And you mentioned that Auto would probably be at the midpoint, I guess, of your sequential decline, sequentially. How do we think about Auto in the December quarter typically? Isn't it generally up v
componenttext: Okay. And just looks like orders for Auto were down 9%. And you mentioned that Auto would probably be at the midpoint, I guess, of your sequential decline, sequentially. How do we think about Auto in the December quarter typically? Isn't it generally up versus kind of a weak September quarter?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's why I told that it was down 9% sequentially but would probably get better in the September -- in the December quarter, largely around the fact -- I think the biggest impact there was in Europe, where you had the big shutdowns during the summer
componenttext: Yes, that's why I told that it was down 9% sequentially but would probably get better in the September -- in the December quarter, largely around the fact -- I think the biggest impact there was in Europe, where you had the big shutdowns during the summer holiday periods. And then you've obviously got a lot of new model launches that take place during the summer too. So our expectation is that relative to the September quarter, it will get better, and so probably flat and you shouldn't see a big decline. So I think the past is marginally better than the midpoint if we're predicting a midpoint reduction overall, but somewhere around that level, certainly better than it was. It was one of the negative factors in the summer. I don't see it as a big negative factor going into December.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Martin, isn't Auto generally up in the December quarter?
componenttext: Okay. Martin, isn't Auto generally up in the December quarter?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, normally it is. I think the one thing that's different there is that such a big part of it now is being driven by China demand. It's normally up in the December quarter because particularly North America and Europe buying cars for Christmas. I think
componenttext: Yes, normally it is. I think the one thing that's different there is that such a big part of it now is being driven by China demand. It's normally up in the December quarter because particularly North America and Europe buying cars for Christmas. I think that would more likely would be a Chinese New Year phenomenon in Asia. So that's the only factor I'd say would be different. You're actually right, seasonally, normally, December's a better quarter than the quarter that's just ended.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just finally, the Golden Week came earlier this year. It's more of a 3-week holiday as we combined 2 holidays in China versus maybe a 1-week holiday. It seems that orders were probably pulled into September quarter. A, do you think that's true? And b,
componenttext: And just finally, the Golden Week came earlier this year. It's more of a 3-week holiday as we combined 2 holidays in China versus maybe a 1-week holiday. It seems that orders were probably pulled into September quarter. A, do you think that's true? And b, what type of an impact does it have on your December quarter outlook?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: We saw, obviously, when you shut down for those Golden Week holidays, obviously, a much lower global bookings during that period. And then we sort of pickup to more normal daily run rates when people came back to work at the end of September. So I don't t
componenttext: We saw, obviously, when you shut down for those Golden Week holidays, obviously, a much lower global bookings during that period. And then we sort of pickup to more normal daily run rates when people came back to work at the end of September. So I don't think that we've seen -- I don't think any of the September bookings were a result of things being pulled forward as a result of that. An interesting thing is the run rate in October is about the same level as in September. So Golden Week at least impacted just a little bit over those days. I don't think it's had an impact on the overall balance of the quarters.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question will come from the line of Shawn Harrison, Longbow Research.
componenttext: And the next question will come from the line of Shawn Harrison, Longbow Research.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: The first question I just want to get back in terms of just commodities. The $6 million headwind in the September quarter and incremental say $6 million along with FX this quarter, do you think the price increases you're putting through the market, starti
componenttext: The first question I just want to get back in terms of just commodities. The $6 million headwind in the September quarter and incremental say $6 million along with FX this quarter, do you think the price increases you're putting through the market, starting in a few weeks and rolling over the next, say, 90 to 180 [ph] days will be able to offset what you're seeing in terms of commodity increases so that we'll get back to a net 0?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I can answer that question. I think what it does do I think is that -- I was actually looking at the New York Times last weekend and saw that, against the basket of global currencies, that the U.S. dollars declined about 16% in the last 4 months. And I th
componenttext: I can answer that question. I think what it does do I think is that -- I was actually looking at the New York Times last weekend and saw that, against the basket of global currencies, that the U.S. dollars declined about 16% in the last 4 months. And I think what it does do is it gives us a lot more leverage to make those price increases stick. What the net impact is, I think, overall -- I mean, what I look at our results at the last quarter, frankly, I think we're really pleased that our new model has worked very well. It's got our SG&A down below our 18% goal. We proved that at the level of revenues we're at, that we can hold up our costs at that level. I think the gross margin was not where we wanted it to be, and it was because of all of those currency and ForEx impacts. And it's interesting, we went back to 2006 and looked at where they stood then, had foreign currencies and the commodities stayed flat since we started our restructuring program, our gross margin this quarter within 34.6%. Now, that's not an excuse. I think our restructuring was to give us a better cost structure. Now we know the pressure's got to be on the gross margin line. And I think we attacked that through price increases. We attacked it by focusing on customers with better margins, which is a lot about what our Focus Account program is. And we attacked it through going after our logistics cost, which is also above the gross margin line. I don't think there are any silver bullets there. But I think we demonstrated through the restructuring that we can get our fixed costs structure in line. Now we've got to go after the gross margin. And the factors we face today are very different from what we faced in '06. But we're not giving up on getting that goal. It just means we have to do some different things and work harder at those to close that gap.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Maybe I guess 2 brief follow-ups on other topics. Just distribution, you saw orders decline. But I mean, what was distribution sell-through of your product during the quarter across the product lines? And I guess in the October, did it near that dec
componenttext: Okay. Maybe I guess 2 brief follow-ups on other topics. Just distribution, you saw orders decline. But I mean, what was distribution sell-through of your product during the quarter across the product lines? And I guess in the October, did it near that decline in orders that you witnessed in distribution? Or is it more just an inventory de-stock of Molex products?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's the latter. Distribution and sales were pretty strong. And you're going to see the major distributors report their results obviously. And at that story [ph], it was more an inventory adjustment versus a drop-off in POS. It was more of POP than a PO
componenttext: That's the latter. Distribution and sales were pretty strong. And you're going to see the major distributors report their results obviously. And at that story [ph], it was more an inventory adjustment versus a drop-off in POS. It was more of POP than a POS impact.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And do you think that was kind of broad-based across connectors? Or was it more just specific product lines that you were selling?
componenttext: Okay. And do you think that was kind of broad-based across connectors? Or was it more just specific product lines that you were selling?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think broad-based across components, at least across our connector product range. It wasn't any specific product lines that we were looking at.
componenttext: I think broad-based across components, at least across our connector product range. It wasn't any specific product lines that we were looking at.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the final question's for Dave. CapEx at 8% of sales this quarter, what should we target for the remainder of fiscal '11?
componenttext: Okay. And then the final question's for Dave. CapEx at 8% of sales this quarter, what should we target for the remainder of fiscal '11?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're still -- we expect to bring that down to about the 7% level, not to our target yet of 6.5% but about 7%. And as we said, it's -- there's been a lot of new product releases that are obviously very positive for us. That's the biggest driver, but also
componenttext: We're still -- we expect to bring that down to about the 7% level, not to our target yet of 6.5% but about 7%. And as we said, it's -- there's been a lot of new product releases that are obviously very positive for us. That's the biggest driver, but also certain areas where we've had to add capacity just because of to catch up on our delivery. So I would assume about a 7% level for the rest of the year.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the last question will come from the line of Steven Fox, CLSA.
componenttext: And the last question will come from the line of Steven Fox, CLSA.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Question on inventories, is there any way to -- I'm sorry, question rather on pricing, is there any way to sort of put a time line or qualify where you have the best opportunities to pass pricing through, and where it's going to be more challenged, and wh
componenttext: Question on inventories, is there any way to -- I'm sorry, question rather on pricing, is there any way to sort of put a time line or qualify where you have the best opportunities to pass pricing through, and where it's going to be more challenged, and where you can do it sooner rather than later? You mentioned with your focus customers as being one area, but I was just curious if you could just sort of go through the list.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Steve. When you look at the overall pricing picture, about, as you know, 26% of our sales is through distribution. We are contractually obligated to notify distributors of those price increases that day orders gone out and it would impact their back
componenttext: Sure, Steve. When you look at the overall pricing picture, about, as you know, 26% of our sales is through distribution. We are contractually obligated to notify distributors of those price increases that day orders gone out and it would impact their backlog from January 1. So orders that are shipped from that date are shipped at the new price. Also customers that buy from our price book, which I would say is another 25%, are also impacted as the price book goes up. Then you've got global customers who have global pricing contracts, and those obviously are negotiated as they come after renewals. So you would see that -- most of it during the second half of the fiscal year. So I think about it in those sectors and those kinds of timings.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And with these global contracts, you're saying you're confident that as the contracts rollover, that you're able to pass it through or -- I mean, you're talking about some of your largest customers, right?
componenttext: And with these global contracts, you're saying you're confident that as the contracts rollover, that you're able to pass it through or -- I mean, you're talking about some of your largest customers, right?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it depends by customer and it depends by product line. Where we have a proprietary product that we are a single source, obviously, you've got a much better leverage. And I think where you've got very competitive end markets where there are mu
componenttext: Yes, I think it depends by customer and it depends by product line. Where we have a proprietary product that we are a single source, obviously, you've got a much better leverage. And I think where you've got very competitive end markets where there are multiple sources, where people are competing for market shares, it's a lot more challenging. So that's why I think when someone says to you what the end results of this is going to, it's a very complex picture. But certainly, there are a lot of other people out there today based on rising raw materials costs and rising labor rates in Asia all talking about the same thing. So it's not an environment where we're the only people trying to do it.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the last question will come from the line of Wamsi Mohan, Bank of America.
componenttext: And the last question will come from the line of Wamsi Mohan, Bank of America.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: So my question is related to both gross margins and SG&A. On the higher revenues out of expected sort of better gross margins and slightly higher SG&A, but sort of the reverse happened in the quarters. So can you rank order the puts and takes on gross mar
componenttext: So my question is related to both gross margins and SG&A. On the higher revenues out of expected sort of better gross margins and slightly higher SG&A, but sort of the reverse happened in the quarters. So can you rank order the puts and takes on gross margin and SG&A quarter-over-quarter from FX moving from air to sea freight, volumes, perhaps other things that you might care to elaborate?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think your summary is correct. I think I made some comments with the earlier question, and that is, I think we were pleased with our SG&A. And I think we've proven that the new global structure we have in place and the restructuring we've d
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think your summary is correct. I think I made some comments with the earlier question, and that is, I think we were pleased with our SG&A. And I think we've proven that the new global structure we have in place and the restructuring we've done enabled us to hit the 18% goal that we established. I think -- but for the ForEx and the raw material costs, we would have hit the gross margin target too, but didn't do that this quarter. But we're not using that as an excuse to say that doesn't mean we're going to hit our 14% goal in the long run. It means that we've got to do some things differently, I think, to close the gap between the 30.5% we're at now and this 32% target we would have been at. As I mentioned, just to give you an order of magnitude, had ForEx and raw materials stayed where they were when we started the restructuring, the gross margin this quarter would have been at 34.6%. And in terms of rank ordering how we close that gap, I would say that short term, focusing on the logistics costs and operational efficiencies in our plants are the things that will benefit us the most in the current quarter. I would say the price increase would benefit us in Q3. And then shifting out our customer mix and looking at some of the smaller fast-growing customers where perhaps the margin opportunities are better, which our Focus Account program is targeted at, is obviously something you see as you move into calendar year '11.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Martin. And as a follow-up, did you see any purchasing, either in distribution or to your other channels, ahead of your proposed price increases in calendar 3Q that could actually exacerbate the order slowdown later in 4Q?
componenttext: Okay. Thanks, Martin. And as a follow-up, did you see any purchasing, either in distribution or to your other channels, ahead of your proposed price increases in calendar 3Q that could actually exacerbate the order slowdown later in 4Q?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, none at all. I think I know a few analysts were concerned that we might in the September quarter see the impact of that. But actually, I think given the inventory adjustment that were taking place -- correction, that's taking place in distribution, th
componenttext: No, none at all. I think I know a few analysts were concerned that we might in the September quarter see the impact of that. But actually, I think given the inventory adjustment that were taking place -- correction, that's taking place in distribution, that was a known factor, and the distribution channel is the only place you would see that.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question will come from the line of William Stein, Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: And the next question will come from the line of William Stein, Crdit Suisse.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick ones. As you talked about some salary increases that are coming in, in the quarter, can you just remind us of those details and which line items they affect?
componenttext: Just a couple of quick ones. As you talked about some salary increases that are coming in, in the quarter, can you just remind us of those details and which line items they affect?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. The total increase is $4.2 million. That is our annual merit increase that we, as you know, didn't have the last year. And of that, $2.5 million impacts SG&A and the balance is in cost of sales.
componenttext: Sure. The total increase is $4.2 million. That is our annual merit increase that we, as you know, didn't have the last year. And of that, $2.5 million impacts SG&A and the balance is in cost of sales.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great. And then the question on the revenue guidance yet again, midpoint's down 3%. I -- In the past, I think that the typical seasonality has been up about 2%. And you've gone into which are the stronger and weaker end markets, so we get that. But the re
componenttext: Great. And then the question on the revenue guidance yet again, midpoint's down 3%. I -- In the past, I think that the typical seasonality has been up about 2%. And you've gone into which are the stronger and weaker end markets, so we get that. But the real question I have here is, is that typical seasonality of up 2% still the same? Or has something changed with regard to the balance of your end markets or geographic dispersion of your sales that would have changed that?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think your analysis, if we went back to the same thing, I think if you look to the last 10 years, the average for the December quarter is up about 2%. I would say that the one factor that's different is that if you look at the bookings that we had
componenttext: Yes, I think your analysis, if we went back to the same thing, I think if you look to the last 10 years, the average for the December quarter is up about 2%. I would say that the one factor that's different is that if you look at the bookings that we had in the June quarter, which were an all-time record and were up to almost 60% year-over-year, and where our revenues are now, I think we've had an unusually high trend. And the other thing, that's because if we look back to that 10-year period, we've had some economic cycles that is kind of distorted where the seasonal trend will be. In total, we would normally have expected to see a slight increase. We expect it to be a slight decrease, so we project -- prudently I think, projected that based on what we saw in bookings trend over the last quarter, just saying that if we see a 5% reduction in bookings. The biggest correlation with Molex generally is -- as we've looked over the years, is sort of looking at what the trend is in bookings in the current quarter versus where revenues go in the next quarter. So seeing the 5% reduction is why we felt that, given the backlog we have to ship, we wouldn't see that bigger drop or why we felt we would be down about 3%.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the corollary here though is -- or the plug, if you will, is lead times. I would have imagined lead times you came in, in the quarter in which case you'd imagine bookings would decline, holding everything else equal. Did that not happen?
componenttext: So the corollary here though is -- or the plug, if you will, is lead times. I would have imagined lead times you came in, in the quarter in which case you'd imagine bookings would decline, holding everything else equal. Did that not happen?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, bookings lead times obviously extended during the earlier part of the year, from the February-March period through to about August-September. And as you know, one of the things that justify that CapEx is the additional capacity we bought online. And
componenttext: Yes, bookings lead times obviously extended during the earlier part of the year, from the February-March period through to about August-September. And as you know, one of the things that justify that CapEx is the additional capacity we bought online. And our lead times are absolutely coming down in our plants. And that does tend to -- you're not get orders for perhaps future shipments when people know the capacity is available.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question will come from the line of Jim Suva, Citi.
componenttext: And the next question will come from the line of Jim Suva, Citi.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the inventory question, I realized that you did have more sea shipment this year versus last year and FX. But your inventory did go up 156 year-over-year, 16% quarter-over-quarter, and your sales is very different from that. So can you maybe take anoth
componenttext: On the inventory question, I realized that you did have more sea shipment this year versus last year and FX. But your inventory did go up 156 year-over-year, 16% quarter-over-quarter, and your sales is very different from that. So can you maybe take another shot at bridging that gap? And I guess the second subpart of that is, does Molex benefit from a gross -- higher gross margin from running at higher utilization rates, where at some point in the quarter, maybe as the December or March quarter, we would be looking at utilization rates coming back down? Because I mean, it looks like based upon your inventory, you're running things a little bit too hot.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of taking a shot at the year-over-year analysis, I'm not sure that -- I don't have all that data in front of me, but again, I would suggest that there's a component of that, that is exchange that affects year-over-year even much more signifi
componenttext: Yes, in terms of taking a shot at the year-over-year analysis, I'm not sure that -- I don't have all that data in front of me, but again, I would suggest that there's a component of that, that is exchange that affects year-over-year even much more significant than -- not that I mentioned sequentially. We have -- we believe our inventory is higher than it should be. I'm not suggesting that we're going to be running it at 85 days for long. But it is very important for us to be able to bring down our transportation costs after moving so much production especially to China. And that's where the focus is to make -- is to getting this transfer from air to sea, and that is the main reason why the inventory is building up. In terms of the utilization rates...

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of utilization, that's a great question, Jim, and I would make 2 comments relative to that. First of all, it's important to understand, I think, during this rapid recovery in the market, we have had a fair amount of production made on the outside
componenttext: In terms of utilization, that's a great question, Jim, and I would make 2 comments relative to that. First of all, it's important to understand, I think, during this rapid recovery in the market, we have had a fair amount of production made on the outside so it's subcontracted to vendors, et cetera. And we have also had about 25% of headcount around the world today of either temporary or contract labor. So in the event that our revenue did pick down somewhat, and our view right now is that we could see it stabilize somewhat in the current levels through Chinese New Year. And based on interaction with customers, it is expected to pick up from there. If that could easily be absorbed in terms of, firstly, reducing temporary or contract labor, we need to do that. And then bringing in-house things that we've used on the outside. And the other thing, as you all know, is we've moved tremendous amount of production around the world. And what we've seen that helped us is the operational efficiencies in those plants have continued to increase, so I don't think we would see a negative gross margin impact by any of the predicted revenue levels between now and Chinese New Year. And certainly, it would pick up again from there based on normal trends.

componenttext: So -- I guess, my question really is, you have 4 or 5 quarters of better-than-seasonal dynamics for the last full year, essentially a year. Why do you think the adjustment will only be a one-quarter event, not a multiple-quarter event?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Because the reduction in bookings has been targeted on in some specific end markets, and the key customers we talk to there have told us that they have excess inventory in the supply chain they expect to be burned off by the end of the year. A lot of that
componenttext: Because the reduction in bookings has been targeted on in some specific end markets, and the key customers we talk to there have told us that they have excess inventory in the supply chain they expect to be burned off by the end of the year. A lot of that is in the infotech capital equipment market. We've also looked at our CRM pipeline of new projects coming in. And if you look at the new products that are going to be released in the new year, we're also positive that, that will help with the revenue as well. So it's largely based on direct feedback from customers and on our own confidence over our new product pipeline.

componenttext: Two ways. I think one obviously is through the price increase. The other one is obviously pricing the means [ph] of new products that were released into new year. And then lastly, I think, which is a longer-term impact, is diversifying our sales into some markets where I think there is a better pricing opportunity.

But I think in that end market versus the consumer market, it's predominantly U.S.-driven.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think when I look at -- we had 6 quarters in a row of very strong sequential bookings. And a 5% decline from record levels, we're certainly not panicking about that, particularly given that September picked up again and October seems to be going pr
componenttext: Yes, I think when I look at -- we had 6 quarters in a row of very strong sequential bookings. And a 5% decline from record levels, we're certainly not panicking about that, particularly given that September picked up again and October seems to be going pretty well. And largely as you saw, it was -- could be explained by some summer slowdowns and some specific end markets. So I think if business will continue at the current levels, plus or minus a little bit, I don't see any big cause of panic about that. And to expect that bookings really continue to sequentially growing at the rate it had the previous 6 quarters on an organic basis is just not realistic.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: So if you look at the past 3 months, was it in the month of September you really saw some of these things picking up? I mean, if you were to pick and choose, was it right from the beginning of the quarter you saw these trends? Or do you think towards the end of the quarter you saw there was an increased, perhaps, hesitation from the channel to add on...

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Interesting enough, in terms of seasonality, July was a pretty good month for bookings. August was the very weak month, which is why I think you saw a bigger impact in North America and Europe because somewhat that's explainable by vacation periods. And a
componenttext: Interesting enough, in terms of seasonality, July was a pretty good month for bookings. August was the very weak month, which is why I think you saw a bigger impact in North America and Europe because somewhat that's explainable by vacation periods. And also I think that the end customers that are impacted the most are in those 2 geographies. And then September picked up again, and October's been pretty good.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And finally, if I look at the -- these TCMs and OEMs, can you talk maybe in terms of the appetite to build inventories? I mean, if you were to distinguish across these 3 guys, is there one versus the other in terms of kind of appetite for building i
componenttext: Okay. And finally, if I look at the -- these TCMs and OEMs, can you talk maybe in terms of the appetite to build inventories? I mean, if you were to distinguish across these 3 guys, is there one versus the other in terms of kind of appetite for building inventories currently or destocking perhaps?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would make a general comment that I think compared to the days when the tech bubble burst, the whole electronic supply chain is far more disciplined about inventory management. And you don't get the big bubbles build-up that you used to have before
componenttext: Yes, I would make a general comment that I think compared to the days when the tech bubble burst, the whole electronic supply chain is far more disciplined about inventory management. And you don't get the big bubbles build-up that you used to have before and people correct very quickly the moment they see the number of days of increase. I actually think, looking back over the cycle we've been, distributors kind of overcorrected on the downside, that they actually made the biggest corrections after Lehman Brothers were bankrupted in early part of '09, and then perhaps overcorrected on the upside. EMS companies, it's more about, actually, I think, getting components in place to meet end customer demand. And there, a way you see the fluctuations is when they're competing for market share versus end customers. And so that's a very different picture that tends to be customer-specific versus the distributors that are obviously managing their overall inventory portfolio.
