headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the First Quarter 2011 Molex Inc. Earnings Conference Call. My name is Diana, and I will be the operator for today. [Operator Instructions] And as a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purp
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the First Quarter 2011 Molex Inc. Earnings Conference Call. My name is Diana, and I will be the operator for today. [Operator Instructions] And as a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Mr. Steve Martens, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please proceed.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Diana. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. I'm here today with Martin Slark, our CEO; and Dave Johnson, our CFO. Please note that this call is being recorded and will be available for replay by accessing the Investor R
componenttext:
Thank you, Diana. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. I'm here today with Martin Slark, our CEO; and Dave Johnson, our CFO. Please note that this call is being recorded and will be available for replay by accessing the Investor Relations section of our website. Presentation materials are also available on the website. As usual, we'd like to limit this call to one hour. [Operator Instructions] 
During the course of this presentation, we will be providing forward-looking information and referring to certain non-GAAP measures. Please read carefully the forward-looking statements section of our press release and Form 10-K for an understanding of the risks and uncertainties associated with forward-looking information and the reconciliation of non-GAAP measures to GAAP.
And now, I'll turn the call over to Martin.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve, and good afternoon, everybody. If you'd like to turn to Page 3, we've added a new slide to this quarter's deck where we've put in a one-page summary of what we think are the key points emerging from the quarter we just finished. The firs
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve, and good afternoon, everybody. If you'd like to turn to Page 3, we've added a new slide to this quarter's deck where we've put in a one-page summary of what we think are the key points emerging from the quarter we just finished. The first point I obviously want to talk about is a quick update on our unauthorized activities in Japan. As you already know, the unauthorized activity occurred many years ago. And we've restated our financial results in the June 10-K to reflect the liability to this unauthorized activity. During the quarter that was just completed, we were served notice of a lawsuit by the financial institution involved. We responded to this complaint, and we intend to vigorously defend our position that these loans were unauthorized. This matter is now subject of ongoing litigation. We can't provide additional details at this time or answer any more questions about this particular topic. 
Now we'd like to spend the rest of the call talking about our operating results. And we're very pleased to announce the fact that we had record revenues and earnings per share in the September quarter. Given where we were 18 months ago, this is quite an accomplishment and obviously reflects good progress by the company and tremendous recovery in the electronics industry generally. 
Our orders declined from the record levels attained in the June quarter. However, we still had one of our best quarters ever for orders, and the level of business activity certainly remains quite strong. During the quarter, we made progress reducing our unusual logistics costs as well as improving production efficiencies on transferred production. Corrective actions to these items are largely a function of time: time to build inventory to fill ceilings and time for our manufacturing operations to learn the nuances of working with new equipment. We continue to improve in these areas, and we expect to see further progress in the December quarter. 
We also made progress reducing our backlog, which hit an all-time high in the June quarter due to the rapid recovery experienced over the last several quarters. Backlog was reduced by $28 million from the June levels as we brought online additional capacity. 
Finally, we announced the 15% increase in our dividend. We have a long-term commitment to our dividend. And given the increase in earnings potential of our new organization and the projected future cash flows, we are very comfortable increasing the payout at this time. 
If you turn now to Page 4, I'll talk a little bit about our revenue and order trend. Revenues for the September quarter were an all-time high of $898 million, 3% above the previous high reached in June of '08 and 6% above the June quarter and 33% above the same quarter last year. Even though orders declined 5% sequentially from the record set in the June quarter at $868 million, we achieved our third best quarter ever for new orders. And year-over-year orders were still up 20%, and all of that growth was organic. The order rate was slower during the early summer and strengthened during the September, and that strength has continued into October. While previous quarters were helped by incentives and inventory restocking, we believe that our current order rate is now more reflective of end demand. 
It's also worth noting that our bookings in the June quarter were up 9% sequentially and 58% year-over-year. So on a sequential basis, we're comparing ourselves to a record quarter. Given that the major economies in Europe and North America are recovering slowly, it's apparent that the emerging markets, particularly China, are driving most of the growth in the electronics sector. Disposable income in China increased by over 80% during the last 5 years. And this trend is expected to continue as the recovery becomes more consumption-orientated and less dependent on exports. This shift, coupled with the proliferation of mobile devices and related infrastructure, an uptick in enterprise spending on tech hardware and many new product introductions, we believe will provide good opportunities to continue to grow our business as we move forward. 
If you turn now to Page 5, I'll talk a little bit about the order trend by channel and by geography. By channel, orders from distribution decreased by the largest amount, by about 12% from the June quarter. Distributors seem to have largely replenished their inventories, and in my own view, perhaps overcorrected on the downside of when the market took its plummet and about overcorrected on the upside, and they are now in the process of adjusting their inventory levels and their order rates accordingly. Orders from OEMs and EMS went only down by 2% and 3%, respectively. We reached -- as I said before, we achieved record orders in the June quarter, so a slight decrease, particularly in the OEM and EMS sectors, is really not surprising in the current quarter. 
By region, Europe decreased by 15% from the June rate largely due to the summer slowdown caused by vacations and holidays. Year-over-year, Europe was only up 8%, and that's largely because Europe benefited the most from stimuluses in the '09 period. Orders in the Americas declined 9% from June due to summer slowdown in July and August and due to lower orders primarily from distribution. 
Asia North increased from the June quarter by 6%. This reflects a strong consumer electronics market for us and strong demand for mobile phones and particularly smartphones. Asia South was down 4% from June, again largely due to seasonal slowdown in orders. But we saw that those orders were up 32% year-over-year, so our business level in Asia South remains very, very high. 64% of our total orders were from Asia in this quarter, and the percent of our business coming from Asia just continues to increase as we move forward. This is somewhat explained by the relative strength in markets where production is largely in Asia, mainly mobile phones, consumer electronics and infotech. It's also the result of increased consumer electronic devices in emerging markets -- the increased consumption of those devices. It's worth noting that our orders in the Asia Pacific South region alone exceeded the total of our orders in North America and Europe combined in the last quarter. 
Now if you turn to Page 6, I'll talk a little bit about the change in our revenue and orders by end market. Revenues for the automotive market declined 4% sequentially, and orders declined 9% from the June quarter. This was not expected -- unexpected in that automotive production usually declines in the September quarter. On a geographic basis, we've seen favorable results in North America as the market seems to have stabilized and continues to rebound. September auto sales were the best in 13 months in North America, and it's worth noting that those records were achieved without incentives. And we're now on a run rate to sell about 12.2 million vehicles in North America. Europe slowed down in part due to the end of most of the stimulus packages across Europe, but also due to the summer holiday period, which probably has the biggest impact in Europe. We have also now fully evenly balanced between our automotive revenues in North America, Europe and Asia, that business being split 1/3, 1/3, 1/3. Going forward, we expect that North America and China will post the highest growth rates, while Europe and Japan will stay relatively flat. Longer term, we also believe that the increasing electronic content in vehicles will help to grow our automotive business. 
The data or infotech market performed as expected. Revenues increased 6%, while orders decreased 3% from the June quarter. Revenue increased in large part due to backlog reduction, while the decrease in orders is due to a small buildup in inventory in the supply chain. This inventory is very product and customer-specific and does not appear to be reflective of overall pullback in end market demand. If you recall, many of the large players in the infotech market were impacted by component shortages earlier this year. And at the same time, were very optimistic that demand would be very strong in the second half and that they would all gain market share. Now that component shortages appear to have been resolved, there would appear to be a modest inventory buildup that is being worked through and we believe will be worked through by the end of the calendar year. Companies still need to upgrade their data centers and add capacity. And we think that, that underlying trend will provide ongoing good business as we move into 2011. We have also seen, just as an anecdote, tremendous interest in tablet computers. And I was recently visiting our operations in Japan. And looking at our customer  relationship module, it's interesting to note that we're actively working on 50 different tablet program computers -- tablet computer programs. It just shows the tremendous interest in that new format. 
If you look now at Page 6, I'll continue the commentary relative to the end markets. The telecom market, which include infrastructure, networking as well as mobile phones, performed well overall, with revenues increasing 10% and orders decreasing 4% from the June quarter. Infrastructure revenue was down modestly. However, orders were down by 14%. This business tends to be very lumpy and chunky and has been very strong coming out of the downturn. We're now seeing a pause in the level of business activity. However, both revenue and orders are well above the prior year levels. 
Revenue and orders for the mobile phone submarket were very, very strong, 30% up sequentially and 20% -- 23% year-over-year. This is due in to a large number of new products being introduced and  continued shift to smartphones, as well as a strong seasonal influence. Looking ahead, there are many new products in the horizon for the mobile phone market, including HD screen, 4G devices and continued share gains for smartphones, as well as the introduction of Android and Windows 7-based devices. Many of the major OEMs are also doing a good job of penetrating new geographies with mobile phones. Overall, we believe that this trend will drive the need for infrastructure to support new devices as we move into calendar year '11. 
Despite what you read in the press, the consumer market, at least for us, has been quite strong. Revenues increased 12% for the June quarter and orders declined a modest 1%, which is below the normal seasonal trend that we would see. This is largely due to the number of new product introductions, backlog reductions and the strong influence of a pre-Christmas build. Even in these difficult times, consumers are choosing to spend their discretionary income on an interesting array of devices, which have increasing connective content. For example, LCD panels trends include now 3D technology, LED backlighting and an increasing use of these high-definition displays in public domains. While we do not know the exact percentage of end consumption in emerging markets, we do know that this percentage is increasing due to strong economic growth and rise in consumers in the developing countries. This is a long-term trend, that coupled with a recovery in the economies of the developing countries and new product offerings, will drive growth in 2011 and beyond. 
Revenue in the industrial market increased 3% from the June quarter, while orders declined 8%. The reduction in orders from distributors had a profound impact on this market, and this is very much a high-mix, low-volume market where distribution is a significant channel. We continue to see opportunities in automotive and semiconductor equipment as well as with our Focus Accounts. Revenues in orders are up 50% and 43%, respectively, from the September quarter last year. So overall relative to a year ago, this market is still very strong. 
Orders from our Focus Accounts grew 3% sequentially versus the June quarter and were up 55% from the prior year, well above the growth rate for the total company. These AD accounts now represent 30% of total Molex orders. We increased the program by 26 accounts this year to further develop our focus markets and find new opportunities for growth. This quarter's success represents another step forward in the success of this program. 
As we move into the December quarter, we see strong activity in mobile phones and smartphones; a modest level of inventory in the infotech sector, which needs to be burned off; a slight pause in networking; and a good but not great Christmas season developing for consumer goods. This leads us to conclude that the December quarter will be below our normal seasonal average in terms of sequential growth, but still at a very positive level relative to the prior year. Our expectation is that bookings will be relatively flat from this point forward through Chinese New Year and, based on discussions with our end customers, will then pick up as we move into calendar year '11. 
Let me now turn the call over to Dave Johnson, our CFO, who will give you greater details on the financial numbers that we released.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Martin. Please turn to Slide 7, which details our key income statement items. As promised previously, this information is only shown on a GAAP basis beginning with this quarter and going forward. The elements that previously were excluded for n
componenttext:
Thank you, Martin. Please turn to Slide 7, which details our key income statement items. As promised previously, this information is only shown on a GAAP basis beginning with this quarter and going forward. The elements that previously were excluded for non-GAAP reporting, specifically restructuring and unauthorized activities in Japan, are separately listed on the statement so that you can easily compare the periods shown. 
Both revenue and gross profit were all-time records for Molex. On an organic basis, excluding the impact of foreign currency translation, revenue was up 5% sequentially and 32% year-over-year. SG&A decreased in absolute dollars by $1.6 million sequentially. And excluding the impact of foreign currency translation, SG&A decreased by $2.4 million. 
The unauthorized activities in Japan for September and June 2010 related to investigation and litigation costs. The $5.5 million expense for the September quarter, or at $0.02 per share, was higher than anticipated but included all costs to wrap up the investigation phase. We are now moving into the litigation phase. Looking ahead to the next quarter, we should expect the Japan litigation costs to be roughly half of the $5.5 million amount that we incurred in the September quarter. 
The other noteworthy item in the P&L is Other Expense. This includes equity income in minority investments, offset by a foreign exchange loss in the quarter. For the coming quarter, you should assume that this will be other income in the range of $3 million to $5 million, and this is a result of the operational results of our equity investments, which are improving. 
Our effective tax rate for the quarter was 32.2%. This includes the tax charge of $2.3 million or $0.01 per share, which is due to options that expired under water for which we had previously recognized the tax deduction. Without this charge, our effective tax rate would have been right at 30%. 
And finally, we reported net income, record net income of $75.1 million and record earnings per share of $0.43. 
Page 8 summarizes our balance sheet metrics. Net cash of $73 million reflects a reduction in cash to build our inventory for the conversion from air to sea shipments, also the payment of severance related to our restructuring program, as well as a higher-than-normal capital expenditure level driven by new product releases and capital constraints. 
I mentioned at our September 9 Analyst Meeting that positive free cash flow generation would begin in the second quarter. And we are on track as planned to generate free cash flow roughly equal to net income going forward. And because of our confidence in generating positive free cash flow, we have increased our dividend by almost 15% to an amount approximating $30 million per quarter. 
I would also like to mention that during the quarter, we expanded our revolving credit facility by bringing in 3 additional banks and increasing the size of the facility to $270 million. At the end of the quarter, we had $110 million drawn and therefore $160 million available under this facility. 
The progress toward our 14% operating margin is shown on Page 9. Our gross margin improved 70 basis points in the quarter to 30.6%. We reduced our freight expenses from the high level reported in the June quarter, but much of this benefit was offset by higher commodity costs and the impact of foreign currencies. Commodities and currencies decreased our gross profit by $6 million sequentially, after several quarters of nominal impact from these items. The 2 commodities that impacted us the most are gold and copper, both of which increased throughout the quarter and have continued to increase up to the present time. We have begun to benefit from the hedges we put in place at the beginning of the quarter for gold and copper, but the hedge benefits are included in the sequential costs that I just mentioned. 
With respect to foreign currencies, we net the translation impact, which is positive with the weaker dollar; with the transaction impact, which for us is generally weaker -- a negative with the weaker dollar. The weakness of the U.S. dollar versus the yen in particular impacted us in the quarter as, for example, we manufacture in Japan, export to Hong Kong and sell into China in U.S. dollars. We have modeled the impact of both commodities and currencies thus far in the second quarter and expect to have a similar sequential headwind in Q2 as we experienced in Q1 for these items. 
SG&A at 17.5% reached an all-time low and exceeded our target goal of 18% for the first time. Looking forward, merit increases, which went into effect on October 1, will increase salaries and wages by $4.2 million per quarter, of which approximately $2.5 million are related to the SG&A line. 
Of course, the ultimate goal is to improve our operating margin. We have steadily increased this metric from 6.8% a year ago to 12.5% in the current quarter. Note that the 4 previous quarters are adjusted for restructuring and Japan costs. But the current quarter includes the $5.5 million Japanese investigation litigation costs, which reduces the operating margin by 60 basis points.  
I think it is also helpful to look back to the period before the downturn. In the June quarter of 2008 at our previous peak of $872 million in revenue, our operating margin was 11.3%. We are well above that level today and progressing toward our 14% target. 
We continue to show good progress in our return on net assets trend, which is depicted on Page 10. Despite the higher-than-usual inventory and capital expenditure level, our return on net assets surpassed 19% and continues to move rapidly higher, approaching our fiscal 2011 target of 20% to 25%. 
And finally on Page 11, we set forth our guidance for the December quarter. In consideration of the sequential swing [ph] of our bookings in the first quarter and the continued uncertainty in the global economic outlook, we have set the midpoint of our guidance to reflect a 3% sequential decline in revenue from the record level reported in the first quarter. Our outlook for the quarter, therefore, is revenue in the range of $850 to $890 million, with EPS in the range of $0.38 to $0.44. As noted on the chart, this assumes an effective tax rate of 30% and no change in foreign currency rates and commodity prices from today's levels. 
In conclusion, we are pleased with our progress in revenue, EPS and SG&A spending, all achieving new records. Gross margin continues to be a challenge for us, especially with the headwinds caused by recent currency and commodity price volatility. However, we are intently focused on achieving our 14% operating margin target through improvements to our global logistics operations, implementing more effective pricing strategies and mitigating the currency and commodity volatility through our hedging activities. 
This concludes our prepared remarks, and we will now open up the call for questions.

componenttext: Okay. And then as a follow-up. Just on pricing. Martin, at the Analyst Day, you discussed a new software program and pricing strategy. Any update there on where you are and as that gets rolled out over the next 6 to 12 months, the implications of that strategy?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Craig. I guess just to talk about the pricing situation, you're right. We have rolled out this new pricing approach using Vendavo. It's being rolled out in the current quarter. We would expect to see the benefit of that in Q3 and Q4 primarily. I gue
componenttext: Sure, Craig. I guess just to talk about the pricing situation, you're right. We have rolled out this new pricing approach using Vendavo. It's being rolled out in the current quarter. We would expect to see the benefit of that in Q3 and Q4 primarily. I guess the other interesting thing just as you brought up pricing. I think one important thing in the pricing area is as you know, we track our price erosion pretty closely. And price erosion in the quarter actually was relatively low. It was at -- we talked about a 3% to 5% range. It was at the low end of the range. And so I think that, that is helpful as we move forward as it will be hopefully that the price increases that we think we'll see the benefit of in Q3.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, and last one if I could. You mentioned the inventory adjustment in the infotech area. Just as you meet with customers, Martin, just curious what the latest sentiment is in readthrough in terms of tech refresh end of the year and then into next year.
componenttext: Okay, and last one if I could. You mentioned the inventory adjustment in the infotech area. Just as you meet with customers, Martin, just curious what the latest sentiment is in readthrough in terms of tech refresh end of the year and then into next year.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's interesting that I just spent the last 3 weeks actually on the road doing new product reviews in our division and also visiting a number of our major customers, and it varies a lot by customer. But you read a lot, I think, about in the summer about s
componenttext: It's interesting that I just spent the last 3 weeks actually on the road doing new product reviews in our division and also visiting a number of our major customers, and it varies a lot by customer. But you read a lot, I think, about in the summer about some of the component shortages that existed. And in some sectors, it appears that customers over-ordered based on not being able to get product and now have more inventory than they think end demand is going to use up, particularly in the last quarter. And so I think that slowed down orders. But when I talked to those companies, they are very confident about long-term end demand. And they see this as an issue to burn through the inventory, particularly with kind of year-end capital spending. So our expectation is that the bookings in that sector are going to be flat through the end of the year, perhaps through Chinese New Year. It will pick up from there. I would say the bigger impact has  probably been in networking and storage versus sort of the notebook and server markets.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the consumer electronics market, maybe even more specifically looking at sort of television, gaming devices, I believe Martin made a comment about a good, not great holiday season. Can you just give us some more color there in terms of whether there's
componenttext: On the consumer electronics market, maybe even more specifically looking at sort of television, gaming devices, I believe Martin made a comment about a good, not great holiday season. Can you just give us some more color there in terms of whether there's inventory? Or whether its just early signs that end demand isn't flowing through like it normally is?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, it's a great question. Honestly, there's a number of moving factors here that we're trying to reconcile ourselves in that obviously the concerns about consumer spending in North America and Europe are very well publicized. And I think there is conc
componenttext: Steve, it's a great question. Honestly, there's a number of moving factors here that we're trying to reconcile ourselves in that obviously the concerns about consumer spending in North America and Europe are very well publicized. And I think there is concern about how strong the Christmas season will be here. The other side of the fence is that you go to Asia and consumer spending there is relatively strong. And there seems to be primarily strong demand that the Chinese consumer seems to be very focused on brand-name goods. And so the growth of that market, it tends to be best for the well-known global brands, where obviously we're well designed in. And so as you saw with our results, our consumer revenues were pretty good last quarter. We would typically see those bookings start to slow down because if it's not ordered now, obviously we're not going to ship it in time for the consumer build season, because people have got to build those products and get them into the market. So our sense is that Europe, North America will be weaker, Asia is pretty strong, and we kind of evened all that out to say it would be sort of flat going into this Christmas.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And if I could, maybe follow-up on that same point, as you look into orders shifting more to the Asia regions and potentially the Chinese New Year season, how do you expect sort of the bookings and revenues to trend in a normal environment going into the
componenttext: And if I could, maybe follow-up on that same point, as you look into orders shifting more to the Asia regions and potentially the Chinese New Year season, how do you expect sort of the bookings and revenues to trend in a normal environment going into the fiscal third quarter?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we haven't obviously given any guidance relative to the third quarter. And what I would say is that Q1 is typically back-end loaded, and that happened because September was clearly the strongest month and bookings have continued to be strong in Octo
componenttext: Well, we haven't obviously given any guidance relative to the third quarter. And what I would say is that Q1 is typically back-end loaded, and that happened because September was clearly the strongest month and bookings have continued to be strong in October. This quarter is normally front-end loaded. And then I think what happens in Q3, just looking back over the last 10 years, it depends largely around how much inventory we come out of Christmas with. But we've seen years, we've come out of Christmas with limited inventory, and things pick up very quickly with a pause for Chinese New Year, with customers asking to keep plants open over Chinese New Year. And we've seen the opposite extreme where there is high inventory and people asking us not to keep the plants open. I think the good news though is that people seem to imagine the supply chain very tightly. And so I think the likelihood of coming out at Christmas with a huge inventory bubble is very slim.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
