componenttext: So Martin and Dave, just a couple of questions regarding the margins. You talked about some of the headwinds on the materials cost, also some of the issues that you had in the supply chain in Europe. How much is left in terms of those savings or the costs that you need to work off in terms of your supply chain issues in Europe?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me tell you in Europe, the biggest thing that we did in Europe was that we have put in place an automotive distribution center. That is now up and running and doing quite well. The -- I guess when you look at the overall dollar impact of freight,
componenttext: Yes. Let me tell you in Europe, the biggest thing that we did in Europe was that we have put in place an automotive distribution center. That is now up and running and doing quite well. The -- I guess when you look at the overall dollar impact of freight, we actually were able to reduce our freight by almost $6 million in this quarter sequentially. So we did see some very good improvement in that area. Longer term, of course, our -- and the reason why our inventory is building is because we are converting from sea freight -- from air freight to sea freight, and we have gotten probably about 65% of that converted as of the first quarter. We expect to convert that to maybe 80% to 90% by the end of the second quarter, with the goal of being at 95% in the third quarter, so that is where we're focused. We've been making very good progress, and I think we're on track for that.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. But, so if you look at the absolute gross margin, you talked about some headwind on the commodities side. All things being equal, and given that you still have some room to improve with those European issues, do you expect gross margin to be up next
componenttext: Okay. But, so if you look at the absolute gross margin, you talked about some headwind on the commodities side. All things being equal, and given that you still have some room to improve with those European issues, do you expect gross margin to be up next quarter or down again because of the lower volumes?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think if you model our guidance, that will imply a sequential reduction in gross margin because of the reduction in volume. Our revenue at this level is down about almost $30 million.
componenttext: I think if you model our guidance, that will imply a sequential reduction in gross margin because of the reduction in volume. Our revenue at this level is down about almost $30 million.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Got you. And then just a question regarding some product shifts and, Martin, you talked a lot about the opportunities in the tablet PC arena. If you look at that market in the dollar content and your opportunities there versus notebook, and as we see a sh
componenttext: Got you. And then just a question regarding some product shifts and, Martin, you talked a lot about the opportunities in the tablet PC arena. If you look at that market in the dollar content and your opportunities there versus notebook, and as we see a shift from either netbooks to notebooks, is that a positive for you or negative when you look at dollar content and you look at the connector content in those types of products?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think for us, I would view it as a positive in that as you know, one of our strengths is all of the microminiature products that come out of our Japanese operations. And frankly, I was surprised when we went through the new product pipeline there, how m
componenttext: I think for us, I would view it as a positive in that as you know, one of our strengths is all of the microminiature products that come out of our Japanese operations. And frankly, I was surprised when we went through the new product pipeline there, how many different programs they were involved in. And I think a lot of the notebook content has been commoditized over time. We have a strong position, I think, in terms of the microprocessor sockets there and the I/Os. I think when you look at the tablet computers, it's good for us in terms of all the microminiature products that are used in that. And I think our share of that market could well be higher because of our strength in that technology.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question will come from the line of Amitabh Passi, UBS.
componenttext: And the next question will come from the line of Amitabh Passi, UBS.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Martin, if I look at the guidance for the December quarter, let's call it for revenues down 2% to 3% at the midpoint. Are you able to give us any color how you expect your various end markets to sort of trend relative to the midpoint, which ones you feel
componenttext: Martin, if I look at the guidance for the December quarter, let's call it for revenues down 2% to 3% at the midpoint. Are you able to give us any color how you expect your various end markets to sort of trend relative to the midpoint, which ones you feel better about, which ones you think could perform slightly worse?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. It's a great question and obviously not an easy one to answer, but I think our view is that the cellphone market, the smartphone market is probably going to be the strongest as we go into the December quarter, given what we've seen in terms of
componenttext: Yes, sure. It's a great question and obviously not an easy one to answer, but I think our view is that the cellphone market, the smartphone market is probably going to be the strongest as we go into the December quarter, given what we've seen in terms of order trends. Our view is that the automotive market is pretty stable right now and probably around that midpoint. Our sense is that consumer will be around that midpoint or slightly better. I think that the weak area for us is probably in the infotech market, particularly in networking, and places like that would be the weaker end segment.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just for my follow-up pass for Dave, just around the balance sheet, it looks like receivables grew somewhat faster than your sales growth this quarter. And also with respect to inventory days, it looks like we saw a pretty dramatic jump. And I th
componenttext: And then just for my follow-up pass for Dave, just around the balance sheet, it looks like receivables grew somewhat faster than your sales growth this quarter. And also with respect to inventory days, it looks like we saw a pretty dramatic jump. And I think you explained part of that due to this mix with sea freight. How should we think as we look forward for sort of where your inventory days trend? And if you could just shed some color in terms of what happened with receivable days in the quarter.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just mention the first fact that the exchange also has a very big impact on our balance sheet, the translation. Our inventory -- $20 million of the increase in inventory was due just to exchange. And $30 million of the increase in receivables was d
componenttext: Let me just mention the first fact that the exchange also has a very big impact on our balance sheet, the translation. Our inventory -- $20 million of the increase in inventory was due just to exchange. And $30 million of the increase in receivables was due to exchange. So that's why -- that's a big portion of the increase in receivables, that's why the days in receivables really haven't changed. And I'd say, I wouldn't read much into the change in receivables other than, as Martin pointed out, our sales and our business continues to grow in Asia, where we have longer terms to our customers, and that's what's driving that. So receivables I think is still in very good shape. Exchange was the biggest factor for the period of time. In terms of inventory, yes, there's really 2 things that have affected that over the last couple of quarters. Number one, which we've talked a lot about, is just the completion of the restructuring and moving production to new locations and the buildup of inventory to handle that. We are still going through some of that, so that is one of the factors. And this very deliberate air to sea shipment process, which is paying dividends already, is increasing our inventory. To give you just maybe a sense of that, I'll give you a couple of numbers. Our in-transit inventory, that is the inventory that is on its way either in air or on a shipment at the end of the period, is at the end of this quarter was $72 million. A year ago, it was about half that level, which gives you a good indication of that. I guess other comments we've talked often about, the VMI, the vendor-managed inventory, hub inventory that is -- our inventory that's on consignment. That inventory has not increased. That is down, still below 30 days and is in quite good control. Anyway that's just some color on the inventories side.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: So should we expect inventory days to remain this mid-80-day range?
componenttext: So should we expect inventory days to remain this mid-80-day range?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: We had said, if you remember from our Investor Day, we talked about 80 days was this year's level. It shouldn't stay at the -- it should come down from the level it is today, but I would model it down to about 80 days for the balance of the year. This qua
componenttext: We had said, if you remember from our Investor Day, we talked about 80 days was this year's level. It shouldn't stay at the -- it should come down from the level it is today, but I would model it down to about 80 days for the balance of the year. This quarter still, I don't know. We are still so focused on this air to sea transfer. I think it may come down a couple of days but then trend toward 80 days in Q3 and Q4.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question will come from the line of Brian White, Ticonderoga.
componenttext: And the next question will come from the line of Brian White, Ticonderoga.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Who is driving this push from air to sea? Are these your customers or you're doing it yourself?
componenttext: Yes. Who is driving this push from air to sea? Are these your customers or you're doing it yourself?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we are doing it ourselves. And it's largely around our automotive products just because the value, the weight ratio of those products is such that air freighting them is not cost-effective. And obviously, the cost of holding them in inventory, given
componenttext: Well, we are doing it ourselves. And it's largely around our automotive products just because the value, the weight ratio of those products is such that air freighting them is not cost-effective. And obviously, the cost of holding them in inventory, given the cost of money, is a lot less than the air freight cost of shipping. The other benefit in the automotive market is that demand is relatively predictable, so it allows you -- we have much longer-term full costs, the automotive costs, it allows you to bring the stuff in by sea and put buffer inventories in place and meet the end customer demand.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just looks like orders for Auto were down 9%. And you mentioned that Auto would probably be at the midpoint, I guess, of your sequential decline, sequentially. How do we think about Auto in the December quarter typically? Isn't it generally up v
componenttext: Okay. And just looks like orders for Auto were down 9%. And you mentioned that Auto would probably be at the midpoint, I guess, of your sequential decline, sequentially. How do we think about Auto in the December quarter typically? Isn't it generally up versus kind of a weak September quarter?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's why I thought that it was down 9% sequentially but would probably get better in the September -- in the December quarter, largely around the fact -- I think the biggest impact there was in Europe, where you had the big shutdown during the summ
componenttext: Yes, that's why I thought that it was down 9% sequentially but would probably get better in the September -- in the December quarter, largely around the fact -- I think the biggest impact there was in Europe, where you had the big shutdown during the summer holiday periods. And then you've obviously got a lot of the new model launches that take place during the summer too. So our expectation is that relative to the September quarter, it will get better, and so probably flat and you shouldn't see a big decline. So I think past marginally better than the midpoint if we're predicting a midpoint reduction overall, but somewhere around that level, certainly better than it was. It was one of the negative factors in the summer. I don't see it as a big negative factor going into December.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Martin, isn't Auto generally up in the December quarter?
componenttext: Okay. Martin, isn't Auto generally up in the December quarter?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, normally it is. I think the one thing that's different there is that such a big part of it now is being driven by China demand. It's normally up in the December quarter because of people in North America and Europe buying cars for Christmas. I think
componenttext: Yes, normally it is. I think the one thing that's different there is that such a big part of it now is being driven by China demand. It's normally up in the December quarter because of people in North America and Europe buying cars for Christmas. I think that would more likely be a Chinese New Year phenomenon in Asia. So that's the only factor I'd say would be different. But you're absolutely right, seasonally, normally, December's a better quarter than the quarter that's just ended.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just finally, the Golden Week came earlier this year. It's more of a 3-week holiday as we combined 2 holidays in China versus maybe a 1-week holiday. It seems that orders were probably pulled into September quarter. A, do you think that's true? And b,
componenttext: And just finally, the Golden Week came earlier this year. It's more of a 3-week holiday as we combined 2 holidays in China versus maybe a 1-week holiday. It seems that orders were probably pulled into September quarter. A, do you think that's true? And b, what type of an impact does it have on your December quarter outlook?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: We saw, obviously, when you shut down for those Golden Week holidays, obviously, a much lower global bookings during that period. And then we sort of pickup to more normal daily run rates when people came back to work at the end of September. So I don't t
componenttext: We saw, obviously, when you shut down for those Golden Week holidays, obviously, a much lower global bookings during that period. And then we sort of pickup to more normal daily run rates when people came back to work at the end of September. So I don't think that we've seen -- I don't think any of the September bookings were a result of things being pulled forward as a result of that. And the interesting thing is the run rate in October is about the same level as in September. So Golden Week at least impacted us a little bit over those days. I don't think it's had an impact on the overall balance of the quarters.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question will come from the line of Shawn Harrison, Longbow Research.
componenttext: And the next question will come from the line of Shawn Harrison, Longbow Research.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: The first question I just want to get back in terms of just commodities. The $6 million headwind in the September quarter and incremental say $6 million along with FX this quarter, do you think the price increases you're putting through the market, starti
componenttext: The first question I just want to get back in terms of just commodities. The $6 million headwind in the September quarter and incremental say $6 million along with FX this quarter, do you think the price increases you're putting through the market, starting in a few weeks and rolling over the next, say, 90 to 180 days will be able to offset what you're seeing in terms of commodity increases so that we'll get back to a net 0?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I can't answer that question. I think what it does do I think is that -- I was actually looking at the New York Times last weekend and saw that, against the basket of global currencies, the U.S. dollar's declined about 16% in the last 4 months. And I thin
componenttext: I can't answer that question. I think what it does do I think is that -- I was actually looking at the New York Times last weekend and saw that, against the basket of global currencies, the U.S. dollar's declined about 16% in the last 4 months. And I think what it does do is it gives us a lot more leverage to make those price increases stick. What the net impact is, I think, overall -- I mean, what I look at our results at the last quarter, frankly, I think we're really pleased that our new model has worked very well and it's got our SG&A down below our 18% goal. We proved that at the level of revenues we're at, that we can hold up our costs at that level. I think the gross margin was not where we wanted it to be, and it was because of all of those currency and ForEx impacts. And it's interesting, we went back to 2006 and looked at where they stood then, had foreign currencies and the commodities stayed flat since we started our restructuring program, our gross margin this quarter within 34.6%. Now, that's not an excuse. I think our restructuring was to give us a better cost structure. Now we know the pressure's got to be on the gross margin line. And I think we attacked that through price increases. We attack it by focusing on customers with better margins, which is a lot about what our Focus Account program is. And we attack it through going after our logistics cost, which is also above the gross margin line. I don't think there are any silver bullets there. But I think we demonstrated through the restructuring that we can get our fixed costs structure in line. Now we've got to go after the gross margin. And the factors we face today are very different from what we faced in '06. But we're not giving up on getting that goal. It just means we have to do some different things and work harder at those to close that gap.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Maybe I guess 2 brief follow-ups on other topics. Just distribution, you saw orders decline. But I mean, what was distribution sell-through of your product during the quarter across the product lines? And I guess in the October, did it near that dec
componenttext: Okay. Maybe I guess 2 brief follow-ups on other topics. Just distribution, you saw orders decline. But I mean, what was distribution sell-through of your product during the quarter across the product lines? And I guess in the October, did it near that decline in orders that you witnessed in distribution? Or is it more just an inventory de-stock of Molex products?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: The latter. Distribution and sales were pretty strong. And you're going to see the major distributors report their results obviously. And that, so -- it was more an inventory adjustment versus a drop-off in POS. It was more of POP than a POS impact.
componenttext: The latter. Distribution and sales were pretty strong. And you're going to see the major distributors report their results obviously. And that, so -- it was more an inventory adjustment versus a drop-off in POS. It was more of POP than a POS impact.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And do you think that was kind of broad-based across connectors? Or was it more just specific product lines that you were selling?
componenttext: Okay. And do you think that was kind of broad-based across connectors? Or was it more just specific product lines that you were selling?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think broad-based across components, at least across our connector product range. It wasn't any specific product lines that we were looking at.
componenttext: I think broad-based across components, at least across our connector product range. It wasn't any specific product lines that we were looking at.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the final question's for Dave. CapEx at 8% of sales this quarter, what should we target for the remainder of fiscal '11?
componenttext: Okay. And then the final question's for Dave. CapEx at 8% of sales this quarter, what should we target for the remainder of fiscal '11?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're still -- we expect to bring that down to about the 7% level, not to our target yet of 6.5% but about 7%. And as we said, it's -- there's been a lot of new product releases that are obviously very positive for us. That's the biggest driver, but also
componenttext: We're still -- we expect to bring that down to about the 7% level, not to our target yet of 6.5% but about 7%. And as we said, it's -- there's been a lot of new product releases that are obviously very positive for us. That's the biggest driver, but also certain areas where we've had to add capacity just because of to catch up on our delivery. So I would assume about a 7% level for the rest of the year.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question will come from the line of Steven Fox, CLSA.
componenttext: And the next question will come from the line of Steven Fox, CLSA.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Question on inventories, is there any way to -- I'm sorry, question rather on pricing, is there any way to sort of put a timeline or qualify where you have the best opportunities to pass pricing through, and where it's going to be more challenged, and whe
componenttext: Question on inventories, is there any way to -- I'm sorry, question rather on pricing, is there any way to sort of put a timeline or qualify where you have the best opportunities to pass pricing through, and where it's going to be more challenged, and where you can do it sooner rather than later? You mentioned with your focus customers as being one area, but I was just curious if you could just sort of go through the list.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Steve. When you look at the overall pricing picture, about, as you know, 26% of our sales is through distribution. We are contractually obligated to notify distributors of those price increases that day or as all gone out and it would impact their b
componenttext: Sure, Steve. When you look at the overall pricing picture, about, as you know, 26% of our sales is through distribution. We are contractually obligated to notify distributors of those price increases that day or as all gone out and it would impact their backlog from January 1. So orders that are shipped from that date are shipped at the new price. Also customers that buy from our price book, which I would say is another 25%, are also impacted as the price book goes up. Then you've got global customers who have global pricing contracts, and those obviously are negotiated as they come up for renewals. So you would see that -- most of it during the second half of the fiscal year. So I think about it in those sectors and those kinds of timings.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And with these global contracts, you're saying you're confident that as the contracts roll over, that you're able to pass it through or -- I mean, you're talking about some of your largest customers, right?
componenttext: And with these global contracts, you're saying you're confident that as the contracts roll over, that you're able to pass it through or -- I mean, you're talking about some of your largest customers, right?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it depends by customer and it depends by product line. Where we have a proprietary product that we are a single source, obviously, you've got much better leverage. And I think where you've got very competitive end markets where there are mult
componenttext: Yes, I think it depends by customer and it depends by product line. Where we have a proprietary product that we are a single source, obviously, you've got much better leverage. And I think where you've got very competitive end markets where there are multiple sources, where people are competing for market share, it's a lot more challenging. So that's why I think when someone says to you, well what's the end results of this going to, it's a very complex picture. But certainly, there are a lot of other people out there today, based on rising raw materials costs and rising labor rates in Asia, all talking about the same thing. So it's not an environment where we're the only people trying to do it.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question will come from the line of Wamsi Mohan, Bank of America.
componenttext: And the next question will come from the line of Wamsi Mohan, Bank of America.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: So my question is related to both gross margins and SG&A. On the higher revenues out of expected sort of better gross margins and slightly higher SG&A, but sort of the reverse happened in the quarter. So can you rank order the puts and takes on gross marg
componenttext: So my question is related to both gross margins and SG&A. On the higher revenues out of expected sort of better gross margins and slightly higher SG&A, but sort of the reverse happened in the quarter. So can you rank order the puts and takes on gross margin and SG&A quarter-over-quarter from FX moving from air to sea freight, volumes, perhaps other things that you might care to elaborate?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think your summary is correct. I think I made the same comment to an earlier question, and that is, I think we were pleased with our SG&A. And I think we've proven that the new global structure we have in place and the restructuring we've d
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think your summary is correct. I think I made the same comment to an earlier question, and that is, I think we were pleased with our SG&A. And I think we've proven that the new global structure we have in place and the restructuring we've done enabled us to hit the 18% goal that we established. I think -- but for the ForEx and the raw material costs, we would have hit the gross margin target too, but didn't do that this quarter. But we're not using that as an excuse to say that doesn't mean we're going to hit our 14% goal in the long run. It means that we've got to do some things differently, I think, to close the gap between the 30.5% we're at now and the 32% target we would have been at. As I mentioned, just to give you an order of magnitude, had ForEx and raw materials stayed where they were when we started the restructuring in '06, that gross margin this quarter would have been at 34.6%. And in terms of rank ordering how we close that gap, I would say that short term, focusing on the logistics costs and operational efficiencies in our plants are the things that will benefit us the most in the current quarter. I would say the price increase would benefit us in Q3. And then shifting of our customer mix and looking at some of the smaller fast-growing customers where perhaps the margin opportunities are better, which our Focus Account program is targeted at, is obviously something you see as you move into calendar year '11.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Martin. And as a follow-up, did you see any purchasing, either in distribution or to your other channels, ahead of your proposed price increases in calendar 3Q that could actually exacerbate the order slowdown later in 4Q?
componenttext: Okay. Thanks, Martin. And as a follow-up, did you see any purchasing, either in distribution or to your other channels, ahead of your proposed price increases in calendar 3Q that could actually exacerbate the order slowdown later in 4Q?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, none at all. I think I know a few analysts were concerned that we might in the September quarter see the impact of that. But actually, I think given the inventory adjustment that were taking place -- correction, that's taking place in distribution, th
componenttext: No, none at all. I think I know a few analysts were concerned that we might in the September quarter see the impact of that. But actually, I think given the inventory adjustment that were taking place -- correction, that's taking place in distribution, that was a non-factor, and the distribution channel is the only place you would see that.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question will come from the line of William Stein, Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: And the next question will come from the line of William Stein, Crdit Suisse.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick ones. You talked about some salary increases that are coming in, in the quarter, can you just remind us of those details and which line items they affect?
componenttext: Just a couple of quick ones. You talked about some salary increases that are coming in, in the quarter, can you just remind us of those details and which line items they affect?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. The total increase is $4.2 million. That is our annual merit increase that we, as you know, didn't have the last year. And of that, $2.5 million impacts SG&A and the balance is in the cost of sales.
componenttext: Sure. The total increase is $4.2 million. That is our annual merit increase that we, as you know, didn't have the last year. And of that, $2.5 million impacts SG&A and the balance is in the cost of sales.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great. And then the question on the revenue guidance yet again, midpoint's down 3%. I -- In the past, I think that the typical seasonality has been up about 2%. And you've gone into which are the stronger and weaker end markets, so we get that. But the re
componenttext: Great. And then the question on the revenue guidance yet again, midpoint's down 3%. I -- In the past, I think that the typical seasonality has been up about 2%. And you've gone into which are the stronger and weaker end markets, so we get that. But the real question I have here is, is that typical seasonality of up 2% still the same? Or has something changed with regard to the balance of your end markets or geographic dispersion of your sales that would have changed that?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think your analysis, if we went back and did the same thing, I think if you looked at the last 10 years, the average for the December quarter is up about 2%. I would say that the one factor that's different is that if you looked at the bookings tha
componenttext: Yes, I think your analysis, if we went back and did the same thing, I think if you looked at the last 10 years, the average for the December quarter is up about 2%. I would say that the one factor that's different is that if you looked at the bookings that we had in the June quarter, which were an all-time record and were up to almost 60% year-over-year, and where our revenues are now, I think we've had an unusually high trend. And the other thing, that's because if we look back to that 10-year period, we've had some economic cycles that has kind of distorted where the seasonal trend will be. In total, we would normally have expected to see a slight increase. We expect it to be a slight decrease, so we project -- prudently I think, projected that based on what we saw in bookings trend over the last quarter, just seemed that if we see a 5% reduction in bookings. The biggest correlation with Molex generally is -- as we've looked over the years, is sort of looking at what the trend is in bookings in the current quarter versus where revenues go in the next quarter. So seeing the 5% reduction is why we felt that, given the backlog we have to ship, we wouldn't see that bigger drop or why we felt we would be down about 3%.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the corollary here though is -- or the plug, if you will, is lead times. I would have imagined lead times came in, in the quarter in which case you'd imagine bookings would decline, holding everything else equal. Did that not happen?
componenttext: So the corollary here though is -- or the plug, if you will, is lead times. I would have imagined lead times came in, in the quarter in which case you'd imagine bookings would decline, holding everything else equal. Did that not happen?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, bookings lead times obviously extended during the earlier part of the year, from the February-March period through to about August-September. And as you know, one of the things that justify that CapEx is the additional capacity we brought online. And
componenttext: Yes, bookings lead times obviously extended during the earlier part of the year, from the February-March period through to about August-September. And as you know, one of the things that justify that CapEx is the additional capacity we brought online. And our lead times are absolutely coming down in our plants. And that does tend to -- you're not going to get orders for perhaps future shipments when people know the capacity is available.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question will come from the line of Jim Suva, Citi.
componenttext: And the next question will come from the line of Jim Suva, Citi.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the inventory question, I realize that you did have more sea shipment this year versus last year and FX. But your inventory did go up 156 year-over-year, 16% quarter-over-quarter, and your sales is very different from that. So can you maybe take anothe
componenttext: On the inventory question, I realize that you did have more sea shipment this year versus last year and FX. But your inventory did go up 156 year-over-year, 16% quarter-over-quarter, and your sales is very different from that. So can you maybe take another shot at bridging that gap? And I guess the second subpart of that is, does Molex benefit from a gross -- higher gross margin from running at higher utilization rates, where at some point in the quarter, maybe as the December or March quarter, we would be looking at utilization rates coming back down? Because it looks like based upon your inventory, you're running things a little bit too hot.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of taking a shot at the year-over-year analysis, I'm not sure that -- I don't have all that data in front of me, but again, I would suggest that there's a component of that, that is the exchange that affects year-over-year even much more sig
componenttext: Yes, in terms of taking a shot at the year-over-year analysis, I'm not sure that -- I don't have all that data in front of me, but again, I would suggest that there's a component of that, that is the exchange that affects year-over-year even much more significant than -- not that I mentioned sequentially. We have -- we believe our inventory is higher than it should be. I'm not suggesting that we're going to be running it at 85 days for long. But it is very important for us to be able to bring down our transportation costs after moving so much production especially to China. And that's where the focus is to make -- is to getting this transfer from air to sea, and that is the main reason why the inventory is building up. In terms of the utilization rates...

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of utilization, that's a great question, Jim, and I would make 2 comments relative to that. First of all, it's important to understand, I think, during this rapid recovery in the market, we have had a certain amount of production made on the outs
componenttext: In terms of utilization, that's a great question, Jim, and I would make 2 comments relative to that. First of all, it's important to understand, I think, during this rapid recovery in the market, we have had a certain amount of production made on the outside so subcontracted to vendors, et cetera. And we have also had about 25% of headcount around the world today is either temporary or contract labor. So in the event that our revenue did tick down somewhat, and our view right now is that we could see it stabilize somewhat at the current levels through Chinese New Year. And based on interaction with customers, expect it to pick up from there. If that could easily be absorbed in terms of, firstly, reducing temporary or contract labor, we need to do that. And then bringing in-house things that we've used on the outside. And the other thing, as you all know, is we've moved tremendous amount of production around the world. And what we've seen that helped us is the operational efficiencies in those plants has continued to increase, so I don't think we would see a negative gross margin impact by any of the predicted revenue levels between now and Chinese New Year. And certainly, it would pick up again from there based on normal trends.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the clarity. A quick follow-up on the transitory costs, are we looking at those all being done at the end of the December quarter? Or do these kind of fold into this March quarter a little bit more? Or kind of looking at forewinds kind of the c
componenttext: Thanks for the clarity. A quick follow-up on the transitory costs, are we looking at those all being done at the end of the December quarter? Or do these kind of fold into this March quarter a little bit more? Or kind of looking at forewinds kind of the clean quarter of getting all this behind us.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: You mean the logistics costs?
componenttext: You mean the logistics costs?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. As Dave said earlier, our expectation is that the unusual inventory -- logistic costs should be cleaned up by December. The benefit of moving everything to sea freight, you would see some of that in Q3.
componenttext: Yes. As Dave said earlier, our expectation is that the unusual inventory -- logistic costs should be cleaned up by December. The benefit of moving everything to sea freight, you would see some of that in Q3.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we have a question from the line of Amit Daryanani, RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And we have a question from the line of Amit Daryanani, RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions. First is, I want to clarify, you guys are basically stating that you expect December quarter to be sub-seasonal because of inventory adjustments in a couple of end markets. And then after that, things should revert back to norm
componenttext: Just a couple of questions. First is, I want to clarify, you guys are basically stating that you expect December quarter to be sub-seasonal because of inventory adjustments in a couple of end markets. And then after that, things should revert back to normal seasonality. Is that accurate?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, based on what we see to date.
componenttext: Yes, based on what we see to date.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: So -- I guess, my question really is, you have 4 or 5 quarters of better-than-seasonal dynamics for the last full year, essentially a year. Why do you think the adjustment will only be a one-quarter event, not a multiple-quarter event?
componenttext: So -- I guess, my question really is, you have 4 or 5 quarters of better-than-seasonal dynamics for the last full year, essentially a year. Why do you think the adjustment will only be a one-quarter event, not a multiple-quarter event?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Because the reduction in bookings has been targeted on in some specific end markets, and the key customers we talk to there have told us that they have excess inventory in the supply chain they expect to be burned off by the end of the year. A lot of that
componenttext: Because the reduction in bookings has been targeted on in some specific end markets, and the key customers we talk to there have told us that they have excess inventory in the supply chain they expect to be burned off by the end of the year. A lot of that is in the infotech capital equipment market. We've also looked at our CRM pipeline of new projects coming in. And if you look at the new products that are going to be released in the new year, we're also positive that, that will help with the revenue as well. So it's largely based on direct feedback from customers and our own confidence in our new product pipeline.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then on the margin, the operating margin delta has been asked in a whole bunch of different ways. But just like at this rate, do you get, from 12% margin that you're roughly guiding for September, to call it 14%, 15%, it's about a $15 million
componenttext: Got it. And then on the margin, the operating margin delta has been asked in a whole bunch of different ways. But just like at this rate, do you get, from 12% margin that you're roughly guiding for September, to call it 14%, 15%, it's about a $15 million to $20 million operating income delta. Half of that is just logistics costs. The other half is commodities and FX. Is that correct?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And how do you recover that commodity fund? Are you going to have to implement more price increases? Or how do you recover that $7 million to $8 million delta from the commodities that you're seeing right now?
componenttext: And how do you recover that commodity fund? Are you going to have to implement more price increases? Or how do you recover that $7 million to $8 million delta from the commodities that you're seeing right now?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two ways. I think one obviously is through the price increase. The other one is obviously pricing them into new products that were released in the new year. And then lastly, I think, which is a longer-term impact, is diversifying our sales into some marke
componenttext: Two ways. I think one obviously is through the price increase. The other one is obviously pricing them into new products that were released in the new year. And then lastly, I think, which is a longer-term impact, is diversifying our sales into some markets where I think there is a better pricing opportunity.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we have a question from the line of Anil Doradla, William Blair & Company.
componenttext: And we have a question from the line of Anil Doradla, William Blair & Company.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Many questions on inventory. Let me take a shot at it too. So would it be fair to say Asia is being impacted primarily by an inventory issue? North America and Europe has both an inventory and demand problem. Is that a fair way to characterize it?
componenttext: Many questions on inventory. Let me take a shot at it too. So would it be fair to say Asia is being impacted primarily by an inventory issue? North America and Europe has both an inventory and demand problem. Is that a fair way to characterize it?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Do you mean in terms of the impact on the end market?
componenttext: Do you mean in terms of the impact on the end market?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say that there is an inventory issue primarily that we have seen in the infotech market that is largely impacting North American customers and -- but is also impacting EMS companies that are based in Asia.
componenttext: Yes. I would say that there is an inventory issue primarily that we have seen in the infotech market that is largely impacting North American customers and -- but is also impacting EMS companies that are based in Asia.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Which are once again exposed to North American and European customers?
componenttext: Which are once again exposed to North American and European customers?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think both, because I don't know the exact data. I don't think you have a good feel for this either. But obviously, an increasing portion of -- in the infotech market of those CMs is going for consumption in Asia. But I think in that end market ver
componenttext: Yes, I think both, because I don't know the exact data. I don't think you have a good feel for this either. But obviously, an increasing portion of -- in the infotech market of those CMs is going for consumption in Asia. But I think in that end market versus the consumer market, it's predominantly U.S.-driven.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And so it sounds like you're not making blanket statements here, making very end market-specific statements, and that's tied to certain geographies basically.
componenttext: Okay. And so it sounds like you're not making blanket statements here, making very end market-specific statements, and that's tied to certain geographies basically.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think when I look across -- we had 6 quarters in a row of very strong sequential bookings. And a 5% decline from record levels, we're certainly not panicking about that, particularly given that September picked up again and October seems to be goin
componenttext: Yes, I think when I look across -- we had 6 quarters in a row of very strong sequential bookings. And a 5% decline from record levels, we're certainly not panicking about that, particularly given that September picked up again and October seems to be going pretty well. And largely as you saw, it was -- could be explained by some summer slowdowns and some specific end markets. So I think if business would continue at the current levels, plus or minus a little bit, I don't see any big cause for panic about that. And to expect that bookings really continue sequentially growing at the rate it had the previous 6 quarters on an organic basis is just not realistic.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: So if you look at the past 3 months, was it in the month of September you really saw some of these things picking up? I mean, if you were to pick and choose, was it right from the beginning of the quarter you saw these trends? Or do you think towards the
componenttext: So if you look at the past 3 months, was it in the month of September you really saw some of these things picking up? I mean, if you were to pick and choose, was it right from the beginning of the quarter you saw these trends? Or do you think towards the end of the quarter you saw there was an increased, perhaps, hesitation from the channel to add on...

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Interesting enough, in terms of seasonality, July was a pretty good month for bookings. August was the very weak month, which is why I think you saw a bigger impact in North America and Europe because somewhat that's explainable by vacation periods. And a
componenttext: Interesting enough, in terms of seasonality, July was a pretty good month for bookings. August was the very weak month, which is why I think you saw a bigger impact in North America and Europe because somewhat that's explainable by vacation periods. And also I think that the end customers that are impacted the most are in those 2 geographies. And then September picked up again, and October's been pretty good.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And finally, if I look at the -- these TCMs and OEMs, can you talk maybe in terms of the appetite to build inventories? I mean, if you were to distinguish across these 3 guys, is there one versus the other in terms of kind of appetite for building i
componenttext: Okay. And finally, if I look at the -- these TCMs and OEMs, can you talk maybe in terms of the appetite to build inventories? I mean, if you were to distinguish across these 3 guys, is there one versus the other in terms of kind of appetite for building inventories currently or destocking perhaps?

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would make a general comment that I think compared to the days when the tech bubble burst, the whole electronic supply chain is far more disciplined about inventory management. And you don't get the big bubbles build-up that you used to have before
componenttext: Yes, I would make a general comment that I think compared to the days when the tech bubble burst, the whole electronic supply chain is far more disciplined about inventory management. And you don't get the big bubbles build-up that you used to have before and people correct very quickly the moment they see the number of days increase. I actually think, looking back over the cycle we've been, distributors kind of overcorrected on the downside, that they actually made the biggest corrections after Lehman Brothers were bankrupted in the early part of '09, and then perhaps overcorrected on the upside. EMS companies, it's more about, actually, I think, getting components in place to meet end customer demand. And there, where you see the fluctuations is when they're competing for market share versus end customers. And so that's a very different picture that tends to be customer-specific versus the distributors that are obviously managing their overall inventory portfolio.

headline: Molex Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: And this concludes the question-and-answer of today's call. Speakers will be available to answer any further questions after today's conference. And now...

componenttext: Great. Thank you very much for your attention and we look forward to talking to you later. Bye bye.
